{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/how-to-diversify-our-economy/article_35485fc8-9e6a-5279-88c8-5f46d843725f.html", "TITLE": " How to diversify our economy ", "DATE": "Jul 24, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "The fall in oil and gas prices is not the only reason the Trinidad and Tobago economy is in the state it is in. Plain and simple, the squandering we need to be concerned about is the squandering of every opportunity to diversify the economy. Since I was a little boy I was told never to put all my eggs in one basket. Every prime minister who had a strong economy failed to diversify the economy. The problem is that they were not innovative and when they tried to diversify they chose the wrong industry, and you need more than one option. What they needed to do was facilitate the inventive and the innovative. That would involve making funds available for research and development and prototypes etc. There are some funds for intellectual property protection, but not enough. There is a need for contract manufacturing factories. These factories would be built on demand, the infrastructure would have to be in place. These industrial parks would have a retail outlet that would sell products from all the manufacturers. Lean and just-in-time manufacturing would be practiced at these factories to reduce start-up costs. These businesses would be start-ups and incubators in one and would be monitored for a year, with help from mentors and other experts. Our small workforce would hamper our productivity and competitiveness. We therefore would have to go high tech. There is a new kind of robot called a \u201cco-bot''; it is designed to work with human beings. This would improve productivity and competitiveness. Companies that need foreign exchange to survive, and they are many, could start a venture capital fund that would be used for manufacturing start-ups. I restricted the playbooks to those of Frank Worrell, Richie Benaud and Mike Brearley simply because they were known as thinking men; able in both the technical and \u201cman-management\u201d aspects of the game. It is time to become more \u00adinvolved in the political process to put an end to the corruption and mismanagement taking place far too often and for too long. She cried out for answers as to the reason the accused, having robbed her son of his \u00adcellphone, had killed him. While the horizon must seem unrelievedly grim to many citizens, once in a while a few specks of bright light appear to \u00adrelieve the gloom. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/concern-over-sluggish-economy/article_7c803e66-0d87-56aa-973b-553032619976.html", "TITLE": " ...Concern over 'sluggish economy' ", "DATE": "Oct 10, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "PRESIDENT of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Andrew Sabga, says his organisation is concerned about the sluggish economy. He also said that several measures in this year's national budget were also discussed in last year's budget. He noted a \"clear indication\" of the sluggish economy could be seen from the continuous decline on commercial bank credit to businesses with the exception of May 2011. He said the sluggishness was also evident in real GDP Growth which in 2009 was negative 3.5 per cent and for 2010 was 0.1per cent, as quoted by the Central Bank. \"And as we heard (Monday) from the Honourable Minister (Winston Dookeran), in 2011, our national economy is projected to contract by 1.4 per cent, when positive growth was originally expected. As representatives of the private sector we were interested in hearing Government's plans to promote local business, ensure our confidence perception is restored and encourage foreign investment against the backdrop of continued global economic instability,\" he said. Sabga was delivering welcome remarks at the Chamber's annual post-Budget panel discussion at the Chamber offices at Westmoorings yesterday. He noted that the promise of a new model of public/private partnerships is one that the business sector has advocated for and was contained in the Chamber's budget recommendations to the Finance Ministry. \"Correctly implemented, this will surely go a long way to creating an enabling environment for business. Similarly, our export capacity must be enhanced, and significant effort must be focussed on the initiatives to facilitate identification and penetration of new markets,\" he said. Dookeran, in his feature address, said that the private sector investment has been a \"troubling situation\" and he had not understood the argument that the sector was \"waiting\" or \"lack of confidence\" but it was a matter of \"inaction\". He stressed that the fiscal regime had provided support for investment, introduced measures to improve efficiency of import and export facilities, the system had excess liquidity so funding was not an issue and there was no restriction to borrowing abroad. \"Where is this confidence issue\" he asked rhetorically. He continued: \"Is it really an excuse, the fact that we are risk adverse people and we are prepared to live on the profits of yesterday without attempting to create new sustainability for tomorrow\" He noted that the private sector was a consumer of foreign trade and it needed to become a net generator of it. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/business/world-bank-europe-economy-stronger/article_ef13a03e-1335-5109-bc75-48ebdbd9ae5d.html", "TITLE": " World Bank: Europe economy stronger ", "DATE": "Jun 2, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "brusselsEconomic growth is expected to continue to pick up across Europe, from zero in 2013 and 1.3 per cent in 2014, to 1.8 per cent and 2.0 per cent in 2015 and 2016 respectively. Central and eastern European countries (EU-CEE) will continue to grow above the European average, with growth expanding over 2.4 per cent in 2015, based on robust consumer demand, the gradual return of investment, and continued export growth, says the new World Bank EU Regular Economic Report launched last week in Brussels.The pick-up in 2014 was particularly strong in Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Poland, and the United Kingdom, while southern European countries finally returned to growth following significant financial and economic restructuring, and despite growing concerns about financial strains in Greece and generally weak global trade.Exports have been the main driver of growth in many EU-CEE countries, such as Poland, Bulgaria, and Romania, said Mamta Murthi, World Bank Country Director for Central Europe and the Baltic Countries. That has been partly due to foreign direct investment (FDI) helping countries integrate into global value chains and push exports. However, as FDI has declined following the crisis, there is greater need for countries to focus on improving business environments, developing skills, encouraging innovation, investing in infrastructure, and reducing regulatory barriers to encourage renewed FDI and export growth.According to the report, strengthening economic growth and improvements at the labour market will help to limit the share of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Since 2008, the EU-CEE share of people at risk of poverty increased to over 23 per cent, as slower growth resulted in job losses, especially among the young and less skilled, pushing them below the poverty line. Going forward, the report says that economic recovery and reduction in unemployment rates, along with increased fiscal space for social expenditures in some EU-CEE countries, will lead to the gradual decline in poverty.While the growth outlook for Europe is moderately optimistic, fuelled by the one-off fall in oil prices and ECB quantitative easing, the report says that several risks need to be carefully managed, including: (1) the potential increase in financial market volatility as the US and EU implement divergent monetary policy; (2) fresh pressure on public finances from the combination of low inflation and modest growth; (3) the limited availability of new lending for investment, due to low returns and incomplete bank reforms; and (4) the potentially negative impact on confidence stemming from ongoing financial strains in Greece or ongoing geopolitical tensions in Ukraine.According to Theo Thomas, lead economist in the World Banks Europe and Central Asia region and Team Leader of the EU RER, The medium and long term challenge in many countries is to shift policy from fiscal and macroeconomic adjustment towards structural measures to promote growth and competitiveness. Structural reforms include continuing to reduce labour market rigidities, enhancing the business environment, reducing barriers to trade (including in services within the EU), and promoting the skills needed for dynamic job creation and innovation. This will need to be combined with affordable social policies that help to protect the most vulnerable, while promoting greater social and labour market inclusion. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-one-horse-economy/article_223dc30f-f89d-5c97-843e-79a25f61afe8.html", "TITLE": " A one-horse economy ", "DATE": "Oct 26, 2008 ", "CONTENT": " Minister Nunez-Tesheira, in agreement with the Prime Minister, told us that our economy is strong, though we remain vulnerable to the general global downturn exacerbated by the financial system's collapse. However, our Government will continue as usual with its spending until we are actually affected and then adjustments will be made. Also, the Minister assured us that there is no intention to use the Heritage Stabilisation Fund to complement the Government's revenues for the present budgeted plans and that the Ministry of Finance has embarked on research to inform future policies in the light of the international situation. The Minister of Finance is correct to say that as long as the prices of petroleum and its products remain high (a fading phenomenon) and we have the resources (now rapidly depleting) to exploit, our economy will earn foreign revenues and our Government will have large amounts to spend. But the economy is a one-horse job and remains extremely vulnerable to external (petroleum-demand decrease) and internal (depleting resources) shocks. Our economy is structurally unsound, i.e. it is definitely not strong. Because of this structure and our current high earning capacity (as we transform our natural resources the country's crown jewelsinto spending money) the current Dutch disease is further disabling and reducing the breadth of the economy. I wrote an article in August 2007, \"Economic Risk Management\", which dealt with our Government's failure to manage the risks of the economy. I repeated that claim in the article, \"Chicken Little\" in October 2008. We have had a response from the Minister of Finance that because of such risk management by the Central Bank we have not suffered any major losses in the investment of our RSF or foreign reserves since these were invested in more conservative securities etc. However, the Minister has failed to address how the Government is dealing with the fundamental risk of operating a one-horse economy in the face of external shocks, characteristic of a petroleum economyin particular in the internal environment of depleting natural resources and the further collapse of the tourism and manufacturing industries. Minister Conrad Enill tells us that he does not see T&T being globally competitive in manufacturing because of China, and the Prime Minister tells us that he does not see any future for tourism in the region. The growing practice of robbing, raping and killing our visitors to Tobago will damage its tourism industry. The closure of the ex-Hilton Tobago because it is not making money does not bode well for that industry's strength in the sister isle. Next year's influx of conference tourists for which we are spending a lot of money is probably a flash in the pan. It is worth noting that both Ministers of Finance hold out much hope for the IFC in the diversification of our economy. I repeat, if the proposed IFC is about creating a local replica of the likes of Lehman Bros. and Bear Stearns, then we had better think again. Their performances on Wall Street were not about economic development and with tighter regulations in T&T (which may discourage their location here) it is difficult to see how such people can facilitate local economic development besides providing some in-house jobs. This column has presented much on the risk of reconstructing the on-shore economy. The fundamental tenet underpinning this is the need to build an Experimentally Organised Economy, a National Innovation System. The objective is to develop innovative small manufacturing enterprises that can become globally competitive both outside and within the energy sector. One of the basic requirements of such a system is the provision of risk financing and in particular venture capital. The proposed IFC is not about meeting this need. Listen to the World Bank on South Korea as it sought to transform itself into a knowledge economy: \"In Korea the emphasis is placed on collateral-based debt rather than on equity. This practice presents a bias against small start-up firms in knowledge-based industries which can incur high costs for knowledge-gathering (and development), but which generate little physical collateral. Improving access to equity capital is important to the success of knowledge-based businesses\". General education, even 60 per cent of the population at the tertiary level, existence of a limping stock market, universities that are geared to the production of certified graduates for the present economy and rich-consumer loan-oriented banks do not form the basis of an Experimentally Organised Economy. The present private sector has developed a survival system in this boom-bust economy and cannot respond to the reconstruction of the economyan observation Sir Arthur Lewis made many years ago. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/looking-at-it-from-a-business-perspective/article_2a1985f9-80ee-5bda-b998-981a33f30f63.html", "TITLE": " Looking at it from a business perspective ", "DATE": "Jan 26, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "In light of declining oil prices, the Employers Consultative Association of Trinidad and Tobago (ECA) recently sought to address the situation from a business perspective by addressing implications for the business community. The ECAs Breakfast Meeting entitled The Business Implications of Falling Oil Prices was attended by representatives from a cross-section of businesses and industries last Wednesday at the Radisson Hotel in Port of Spain. Finance Minister Larry Howai was the feature speaker from a panel that included senior lecturer in the Department of Economics at The University of the West Indies Dr Roger Hosein, director of the ILO Decent Work Team Dr Giovanni di Cola and team leader of HR Solutions at the Employers Solution Centre LaToya Griffith. Howai addressed the governments plan to strengthen tax administration and collection at the BIR as well as accelerate refunds on past VAT arrears to the business community so that they can maintain their operational efficiency and profit levels during this time. This was one of several initiatives the Minster outlined as the Government attempts to implement revenue and expenditure policies to compensate for the decline in revenues from the energy sector, the ECA said in a statement. Howai also articulated his expectation that the business community will reciprocate and make commensurate VAT payments in a timely manner. When asked about the level of inefficiency in the public sector, which seems to impede attempts to make timely payments, the Minister called for a collaborative approach with all stakeholders, including trade unions, in addressing these issues. While he assured that the government does have an intention to address as many of these issues as they can, the Minister cautioned that it may get worse before it gets better. ILO director di Cola indicated that the implications for business depends on how long low prices will last but stressed on the need to focus on skills development and diversification of the economy, a point which Hosein also alluded to in his discussion when he cited the need to improve labour resource allocation. He posited a possible approach to achieving this by halting the decline in manufacturing and increasing productivity in the services sectors. Hosein also gave some potent figures on trends relating to labour and economic growth and maintained that substantive reform of the macro-economy is urgently needed, including CEPEP, and a restructuring of the GATE programme. He also pointed to the need to revamp the agricultural sector in an effort to diversify the economy, which will also assist in reducing the countrys food import bill, the ECA stated. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/dookeran-ministry-to-partner-with-youth-public-on-economy/article_224490d2-db80-59d9-a975-bfc26ce290c4.html", "TITLE": " Dookeran: Ministry to partner with youth, public on economy ", "DATE": "Jun 30, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "The Ministry of Finance has already designed a new approach with the people called a \"dialogue process\", in charting a new budget for Trinidad and Tobago, Minister of Finance Winston Dookeran said yesterday. For the first time, too, the Ministry of Finance, also, will conduct a \"dialogue\" with young people to understand their points of view on the economy. Speaking at the launch of the Tunapuna Partnership Council (TPC), at which he was designated the \"chief servant\" of the executive council which will oversee the work of the TPC, Dookeran said the dialogue was the start of the process of deepening democracy in governance. Reiterating the National Treasury was empty, he said the \"people's energy\" derived from the dialogue process will go towards filling the Treasury. In the past, Dookeran said, the officers in the previous administration claimed they held consultation with the people but, in effect, they did not listen to them. At the end of the so-called consultation process, they designed the programmes without the input of the people. Due to the lack of consultation, the Finance Minister said he recommended they change the name to the \"dialogue process\" to engage in a genuine dialogue with the stakeholders business, labour, civil society, households and young people. Dookeran issued an invitation to young people throughout the country to take part in the sessions on the way forward for the economy with the Government. The dialogue, he said, was part of the change process but change does not come swiftly. \"Change comes by doing, and doing is what I am accustomed to do\", he declared. The dialogue process, he said, was one of the first priorities of the Government to build transparency in the governance structure, get rid of the broken politics of the past and embrace new politics. This process, he said, would aid in including those who would have been left out of the economic mainstream of society. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/innovating-small-business-financing/article_ed572a10-ac73-5bd0-b7eb-fac1b2bcb8ae.html", "TITLE": " Innovating Small Business Financing ", "DATE": "Sep 17, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " It seems these days that the words \"innovation\" and \"innovation policy\" have attained a new found currency in the field of development economics and policy formation. Despite being de rigueur, the terms are often left in academic abstraction with seemingly little real world application. To the average person the word \"innovation\" might conjure images of iPads, hybrid cars, and other technological advances - in essence, the creation of new products, or retooling old ones to make them more efficient. While these are critical in shaping stronger and more competitive businesses, and by extension, economies, innovation can also be systemic. That is to say, innovation can also involve shifting the approaches to doing business so as to build dynamic enterprises. One area which has seen a dearth of such profound change, particularly in the developing country context, is that of SME financing. In the wake of the global economic crisis Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) have become the 'darlings' of economic growth. These companies are well poised, by virtue of their small size, to allow for inclusive, sustainable growth by dynamising industrialization processes, stimulating employment and catalysing development in urban and rural areas. SMEs are also deemed to be better equipped to weather the storms of changing economic climates because of their innate ability to reconfigure and reform to suit the demands of a changing economy. Former minister of finance, Winston Dookeran, estimated that in Trinidad and Tobago, there are about \"18,000 SMEs, employing approximately 200,000 people or close to 35 per cent of the workforce and contributing near to 20 per cent of the gross domestic product.\" Small businesses have historically been hobbled by the inability to access credit and other traditional financial markets. Thus, while the clarion call has been trumpeted for SMEs to become more competitive through product innovation, most lack the requisite financing to make that happen. One of the principal factors affecting small-business lending is the perceived high risk of default rate. Small businesses often have limited sources of capital other than bank lending. This means they have to rely on cash flow to maintain operating expenses and still pay the bank their monthly loan payments. Further, many small businesses are comprised of young entrepreneurs or new managerial staff. This can lead to a work-in-progress organisation where mistakes can often be costly. Thus, banks are sometimes reluctant to support these growing businesses because of the risk involved in losing their investment. Another issue is the perception of greater financial risk, as small businesses have fewer assets to borrow against. If few assets are available and a business finds itself in financial trouble, it may be forced to close. However, banks will often provide asset-based lending, where a commercial loan is tied to a company's assets. Most governments seek to bridge the gaps in SME financing through the implementation of various programmes which take the form of soft loans and grant funding. These, however, are both unstable and unsustainable as they are highly dependent on the vagaries of the prevailing economic climate at the given time. One suggestion has been the establishment of a Junior Stock Exchange designed to allow investors to put capital into fledgling companies that exhibit the potential to develop the local economy by creating established and transparent businesses, jobs and ultimately, economic confidence. The initiative has however been met with some reticence despite the obvious advantages primarily because of the fear that a publicly listed company can be purchased \"lock stock and barrel\" by larger businesses in the market. In Trinidad and Tobago, where SMEs are primarily family owned and are viewed as a legacy to be handed down from generation to generation, this quite naturally is a major concern. Additionally, burdensome rules and regulations, the requirements of reporting, and the overall scrutiny, prove to be further disincentives to small businesses. In small economies such as ours, more innovative financing options may indeed prove to present better options for success. One such 'innovation' is that of 'crowd funding' or 'crowd financing', which allows large numbers of 'regular' people to invest small amounts in the purchase of equity stakes in small businesses online. Using a website platform, small businesses are able to market their ideas to a large number of investors with a local and foreign reach. This level of personalisation in raising seed-funding makes it easier for small businesses to be able side-step the usual red tape that attend larger equity offerings, as well as offers an opportunity for small entrepreneurs to raise capital without giving away too much equity. It is essentially like receiving a gift or a donation that you get to spend on your favourite project. Additionally, people who are raising capital through crowd financing can also use this as a relatively inexpensive marketing tool. Publishing information about a product or a project with a goal of raising capital on a well-read crowd funding platform also raises product or brand awareness. Crowd funding is not just limited to one single website. Supporters of the project disseminate the information using their social networks and encourage people in their networks to do the same. For this reason crowd financing can be a strong complement to cluster development campaigns. Of course there are the downsides to crowd financing such as the lack of protection from 'poachers' of new business ideas, limitations in the amount of money that can be raised, and the regulation of crowd-fund platforms. However, the implementation of proper legislation can help curtail some of the disadvantages. The United States government, for example, recently passed the \"Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act (JOBS)\" which now makes it legal for entrepreneurs to use crowd funding to raise a limited amount of early-stage equity-based financing. Though still in its early stages, it certainly provides a beacon of hope for small businesses. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/rowley-knocks-dookeran-on-stagnant-economy/article_21df4d63-c673-5b1e-a267-cec8e5fe5d6b.html", "TITLE": " Rowley knocks Dookeran on stagnant economy ", "DATE": "Nov 23, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "In six months, the People's Partnership Government has brought the economy to a halt and eroded investor and consumer confidence, Opposition Leader Dr Keith Rowley said yesterday. Rowley tore into the Government's performance since assuming office and criticised Finance Minister Winston Dookeran for failing to turn around the economy as he had promised in his budget presentation. Rowley slammed Dookeran for speaking about the economic crisis of countries around the globe while ignoring the fact the local economy was at a standstill due to Government's inactivity. \"It might very well be that the Minister of Finance is trying to fix our problems against a background of not understanding what the problem is,\" said Rowley. He said Government is too preoccupied with praising themselves as opposed to stimulating growth in the public and private sector. He said Government's failure to quickly appoint boards caused the economy to suffer due to further inactivity. Government's priorities, he said, are not in the right place as they went ahead before appointing a board to the Water and Sewerage Authority (WASA) and made Ganga Singh that company's CEO. He added the failure to appoint the National Insurance Board (NIB) has contributed to the crippling of the economy. Turning to the private sector, Rowley said consumer confidence has been eroded as people are reluctant to spend and also fear for their job security. \"Trinidad and Tobago's banks right now are awash with money, there are $3 billion in local banks now, with nobody to borrow it,\" he said. He noted it is the Christmas season, and nothing is happening as business continues to dry up. Rowley knocked Dookeran for failing to address the unemployment issue or any of the tax measures, such as the property tax or the tax amnesty. In painting a gloomy picture of this country's economy, Rowley also pointed out there is no investor confidence and the cancellation of major projects deepened the economic crisis. He said although the aluminium smelter was cancelled, the partner in that project is still looking for recompensations as Government failed to issue instructions they were no longer proceeding with the project. Rowley also raised concerns over inactivity at the National Gas Company (NGC) where he said millions of cubic feet of gas per day were to be pumped into huge contracts which are either cancelled or at a standstill. In fact, president of the Trinidad and Tobago Manufacturers' Association Dr Rolph Balgobin believes the downgrade by the New York-based ratings firm does not mean that T&T's economy is weak. His view was one of several the Business Express sought last weekfollowing Moody's decision to downgradeT&T's bond and issuer ratings, from BAA1 to BAA2 and revise the outlook from stable to negative. Moody's identified three key drivers behind the downgrade- persistent fiscal deficits and challenging prospects for fiscal reforms, decline in oil prices and limited economic diversification and a weak macroeconomic policy framework given the lack of a medium-term fiscal strategy. ?I don't think that this downgrade was unexpected and the reason I say that is that the mainstay of our economy is energy and the global energy system has been in a tremendous state of flux, and so it is not unexpected when you see the kinds of changes in oil and gas prices we have witnessed, Balgobin said. He said Moody's concerns were legitimate. ?I think that the shortcomings that Moody's has identified are very clear, they are known to all of us. There are things that I think we in the economy have to continue to fix. Does it mean that theeconomy is in trouble I would say most certainly not, the Balgobin said. ?From a manufacturing standpoint, demand remains robust and in fact our big problem is labour and the feasibility of labour, so we have confidence in the economy and we think that we need to continue efforts to diversify. We think manufacturing is a very good option for diversification efforts and we are going to support a sensible diversification drive to the extent that it includes manufacturing, he added. But chief executive of the Trinidad and Tobago Chamber of Industry and Commerce Catherine Kumar had a different view. She said the downgrade was not good for the country. ?Whilst we are still investment grade, the fact that we've moved from BAA1 to BAA2 means that foreign investors will be looking at that, she said. ?I have heard the Minister of Planning say that they are already reviewing the medium term policy framework, taking all of these factors outlined by Moody's into consideration and that Government plans to do so within a short period of time, that's going to be very important. We are in an election year, we are in a year where budgets are due in September and based on the changes we are going to make in that medium term policy framework would impact on budgets also. She said Moody's downgrade should act as a serious wake-up call for this country to further act on strengthening its macroeconomic environment. She said while the Chamber was quite satisfied that the country's macro indicators are sound, T&T must ensure that those indicators do not slide in the wrong direction. ?The Government needs to pay close attention to it. University of the West Indies senior economics lecturer Dr Roger Hosein opined that the indication by Moody's should not be taken lightly. Like Balgobin, he pointed out that the downgrade came as nogreat surprise, particularly as oil and gas prices have been fairly flat between 2011 and June 2014. ?In this setting of stagnating production in the case of gas and falling production in the case of crude oil, and falling prices of both these key products, there has been an increase in Government expenditure, especially on transfers and subsidies, he said. Hosein said what should also be noted is that between 2005 and 2014, Government expenditure more than doubled, transfers and subsidies tripled and the fiscal balance moved into deficit. He said it is clear that T&T's economy is in need of structural adjustment, which has been the case since 2008. He said greater focus on manufacturing is needed. Pointing out that this sector employs 50,000 people, Hosein said if a strategy is designed to double the size of the manufacturing sector then this would accelerate the amount of long term sustainable jobs created. ?The seven e TecK parks planned by the government for various places within the economy have to be brought onto the front burner as the direct employment and indirect opportunities would help stabilise the long term growth performance of the economy, which is at a new normal lower level. As the economy progresses a process will have to be formulated that spurs a greater alignment of wage demand with productivity increases, especially in the now crisis hit petroleum sectors. ?Unreasoned demand for wage increases by trade unions must be a thing of the past as there is no longer any basis for such, logical or otherwise. Unreasoned wage increases which are higher than associated productivity increasingly compromises the overall competitiveness of the economy. Already output per worker in some segments of the economy has fallen and Moody's would have no doubt considered all these factors in its decision to downgrade the economy, Hosein said. Review Transfers and Subsidies Moody's said one of its rationales behind the downgradedwas the country's rigid structure of public expenditurewhich limits fiscal flexibility. It made reference to the fact that wages, subsidies and transfers account for more than 65 per cent of total expenditure. Balgobin, Kumar and Hosein agreed that Government must review its transfers and subsidies. ?I think it is imperative to balance the budget, it is something that any sensible economist or business person would call for, Balgobin said. ?You want to be operating from the fundamental position where you are living within your means, where you are not spending more than you are earning. That being said, the structure of the social economic landscape in T&T is such that a sudden withdrawal of social programmes can actually lead to some social dislocation, he said. While Balgobin acknowledged Government would maintain its position that a significant segment of the population is not competitive and needs help in order to get by, it must move to wean people off the dependency syndrome as soon as possible. Kumar stated: We do believe that the percentage that goes into transfers and subsidies is way too high for this country. Yes we have the energy sector and the rents from the energy sectorallow us to do that but we have to ensure that we save fora rainy day. We recognise there is need for social programmes, there will always be the vulnerable in our society who need to be looked after and certainly as a caring nation and a caring Chamber we would want to see that continue and that Government looks after those who are not able to look after themselves. However, does that have to be to the extent that it is now Hosein said he was hoping that the downgrade helps to persuade the few remaining resistant groups that the fuel subsidy should be adjusted. ?This subsidy comes at a great fiscal cost to the economy and its contribution to the economy's global competitiveness is at best marginal. Indeed the fuel subsidy may have backfired as it may have stimulated an abnormal demand for vehicles in the T&T economy, given low interest rates in the banking system. The rapid increase in the number of vehicles would have increased traffic congestion, decreased worker punctuality and even regularity and also increased overall levels of pollution. Last week Finance Minister Larry Howai hosted a group of representatives from financial institutions, including the Bankers Association, the Insurance Companies Association, Unit Trust and the National Insurance Board. Howai reiterated that the Government recognises the need to address issues raised by Moody's. However, he outlined reasons why he has described the Moody's rating as not properly taking all of T&T's macroeconomic strengths into full consideration: ?Given that Trinidad and Tobago's financial state is just as good if not better than a few months ago when Moody's gave a Baa1-rating to our country, Howai noted in a statement, pointing out that the Moody's statement provided no figures in support of their findings, but cited certain characteristics of the T&T economy which are all affected and shaped by global factors. He listed the many indicators of a strong T&T economy, inclusive of: the Heritage and Stabilisation Fund now standing at US$5.6 billion; the country's official reserves resting at US$10.8 billion; the Debt-to-GDP ratio at a comfortable 43 per cent; inflation in single digits; and unemployment at an historic low of 3.6 per cent, the statement said. Speaking after the meeting, former Minister of Finance and now chairman of Unit Trust Wendell Mottley extended assurances with his perspectives on both the Moody's decision and the opportunity presented to the Government of T&T. He said that the downgrade has not affected the price of the investments which the Unit Trust holds, and he expressed satisfaction at that, the statement said. He added that from his experience in Government during times of economic challenges, we have survived by being proactive; and we are now in such a time again so we simply have to be forward-thinking. Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar gave a sneak-peak of the fiscal package as she addressed, the opening of the International Food Festival, at the Hilton Trinidad, Port of Spain, yesterday. In outlining Government's development plan, the Prime Minister said her administration will create employment by boosting its construction drive. The inflation rate will be kept down, she said, by increasing productivity and putting construction workers back to work. \"This budget proposes to increase infrastructure development specifically in areas that will provide the jobs in engineering and construction sectors so necessary in reducing the unemployment levels,\" she said. It is expected that there will be goodies for the business community as the Prime Minister said the budget will contain incentives for investors and businesses to provide well paying jobs to people. \"It is my hope that our businesses will take advantage of the incentives provided in the budget and play their part to begin the task in earnest of putting our economy back on a growth path. In this regard, we may wish to note that there are a number of investment projects in the pipeline that hold the potential for significant investments for Trinidad and Tobago. In addition there are initiatives afoot to leverage this country's petrochemical services expertise in emerging oil economies,\" she said. The Express understands that a significant allocation will be made to the Sport Ministry to implement programmes to prevent youths from entering into a life of crime. Monies will continue to be injected into the areas of health, national security, infrastructure and education as well as social development. Persad-Bissessar has given the assurance that her Government would ensure that this country overcomes its economic challenges and vowed that under her governance there would be no need to seek help from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). As the nation continues under a State of Emergency, the Prime Minister also assured that her Government will put an end to the crime scourge. \"We will overcome, as we must, this challenge of escalating crime and we will come out of this economic crisis with our heads raised high and our dignity intact. (There will be no resort to the IMF on our watch),\" said Persad-Bissessar. The Prime Minister made the remarks in a pre budget statement where she hinted at some areas which would benefit most from the 2012 multi billion dollar budget which will be delivered by Finance Minister Winston Dookeran at the Parliament's new home tomorrow at Tower D, of the Waterfront Complex, Port of Spain. Persad-Bissessar reminded the nation that the world is in financial trouble as she pointed out that developed countries like the United States and the United Kingdom are struggling to keep unemployment down and attract investor confidence. She said this country is now being inundated with increasing requests for jobs by our diaspora in the United States. \"In Europe, the threat of imminent bankruptcy faces several countries including Greece, Spain, Italy and Portugal. The traditionally defined developed world are facing as I speak, significant economic growth challenges compared to economies like China, India, Brazil and Indonesia. Although, even China, the bright spot in the world economy, has had to revise downwards its forecasts for economic growth due to prospects of declining global demand for its goods and services and the threat of an overheated economy,\" said Persad-Bissessar. She further noted that our Caribbean neighbours are also suffering from financial woes as their market for our goods and services have been severely challenged to the point where the IMF is now being considered as a potential source of assistance. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/world-bank-room-for-improvement-with-caribbean-economies/article_3936b098-9ff7-5469-8a30-5e7a0d827018.html", "TITLE": " World Bank: Room for improvement with Caribbean Economies ", "DATE": "Nov 10, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "A woman looks at sunglasses inside the new Kenneth Cole boutique during its grand opeing inside the Kinam Hotel complex in Petionville, Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last Thursday. A woman looks at sunglasses inside the new Kenneth Cole boutique during its grand opeing inside the Kinam Hotel complex in Petionville, Port-au-Prince, Haiti, last Thursday. A new World Bank Group report finds that over the past year, 50 per cent of economies in the Caribbean implemented at least one reform making it easier for local entrepreneurs to do business-12 reforms in total, an historical high for the region. Doing Business 2015: Going Beyond Efficiency finds that Jamaica had the regions biggest improvement in the ease of doing business in the past year, thanks to three reforms in areas measured by the report. Jamaica streamlined the requirements for starting a business, reduced the cost of getting an electricity connection, and established new credit bureaus while also adopting a new secured transactions law that broadens the range of assets that can be used as collateral. Joining Jamaica in implementing multiple regulatory reforms were the Dominican Republic and Trinidad and Tobago. The Dominican Republic made cross-border trade easier by reducing the number of documents required to import and export, improved the regulatory framework for credit reporting, and strengthened minority shareholder protections. Trinidad and Tobago, among the ten top improvers worldwide in this years report, made resolving insolvency easier by introducing a new restructuring proceeding. It also strengthened the rights of secured creditors during reorganization procedures. And it made starting a business easier by introducing online systems for employer and tax registration. Such reforms are leading to tangible benefits for entrepreneurs. For example, starting a business now takes 11.5 days for an entrepreneur in Trinidad and Tobagoon par with international best practicedown from 35.5 days in 2013, the report said. Entrepreneurs in the Caribbean continue to see gains in the business environment. With half the regions economies making regulatory reforms in the past year, the Caribbean continues to move in the right direction, said Rita Ramalho, Doing Business report lead author, World Bank Group. Yet while the region continues to reform, there is still room for further improvement in the business environment. The report this year expands the data for three of the ten topics covered, and there are plans to do so for five more topics next year. In addition, the ease of doing business ranking is now based on the distance to frontier score. This measure shows how close each economy is to global best practices in business regulation. The report finds that Singapore tops the global ranking on the ease of doing business. Joining it on the list of the top ten economies with the most business-friendly regulatory environments are New Zealand; Hong Kong SAR, China; Denmark; the Republic of Korea; Norway; the United States; the United Kingdom; Finland; and Australia. The Caribbean region includes the following economies: Antigua and Barbuda, The Bahamas, Barbados, Dominica, the Dominican Republic, Grenada, Haiti, Jamaica, St Kitts and Nevis, St Lucia, St Vincent and the Grenadines, and Trinidad and Tobago. About the World Bank Group The World Bank Group plays a key role in the global effort to end extreme poverty and boost shared prosperity. It consists of five institutions: the World Bank, including the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) and the International Development Association (IDA); the International Finance Corporation (IFC); the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA); and the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID). Working together in more than 100 countries, these institutions provide financing, advice, and other solutions that enable countries to address the most urgent challenges of development. For more information, please visit www.worldbank.org, www.miga.org, and ifc.org. About the Doing Business report series The annual World Bank Group flagship Doing Business report analyses regulations that apply to an economys businesses during their life cycle, including start-up and operations, trading across borders, paying taxes, and resolving insolvency. The aggregate ease of doing business rankings are based on the distance to frontier scores for ten topics and cover 189 economies. Doing Business does not measure all aspects of the business environment that matter to firms and investors. For example, it does not measure the quality of fiscal management, other aspects of macroeconomic stability, the level of skills in the labor force, or the resilience of financial systems. Its findings have stimulated policy debates worldwide and enabled a growing body of research on how firm-level regulation relates to economic outcomes across economies. Each year the report team works to improve the methodology and to enhance their data collection, analysis and output. The project has benefited from feedback from many stakeholders over the years. With a key goal to provide an objective basis for understanding and improving the local regulatory environment for business around the world, the project goes through rigorous reviews to ensure its quality and effectiveness. This years report marks the 12th edition of the global Doing Business report series. For more information about the Doing Business reports, please visit doingbusiness.org and join us on doingbusiness.org/Facebook. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/turning-the-economy-around/article_8c7da3ab-e07b-57b6-8aed-582d9d7144d3.html", "TITLE": " Turning the economy around ", "DATE": "Sep 13, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " \u0097Photo: Trevor Watson \u0097Photo: Trevor Watson National budgets are generally overrated things. They help us to understand the priorities of government by affording us a look at spending patterns. On the other hand, there are many strategic moves that a government can take which have little or nothing to do with budgets, or which budgets only imperfectly capture. I suspect however that national budgets in Trinidad and Tobago are this important because they occur in an information vacuum. Since we hardly have any other information about government plans, we grasp at the budget as would a drowning man clutch at a straw. Until better comes therefore, the nation will remain riveted to the media to understand what lies ahead. Already significant because it is the first budget of the new government, it is doubly important because it tells us a lot about how we are going to weather the rest of the slowdown and the pathway we propose to take to get us to safer ground. The government has gone to some lengths to engage stakeholders, and has made several bold moves on a number of fronts (e.g. Alutrint, rapid rail, criminal court), while remaining somewhat vague on others. While the specific aspects of the budget have already been dissected in the media, there are some other things worth thinking about. I was wondering how the government would balance the budget or get close to doing so. The answer, as it turns out, was not to try to. While this makes sense in the short term, because we do not want to collapse the economy, the budget needs to be balanced quickly if we are to avoid the problems attendant to persistent deficit spending. Spending in this budget appears aimed at managing the impact of the economic slowdown on middle and lower income households. As such, the budget at first reading did not spell out an entirely new direction but rather outlined the places that we will definitely not go. So out are smelters and massive rail projects, for example. What will happen to the people in the La Brea region is less clear, but perhaps the government will treat with that in the debate to come. The theme of the budget is 'turning the economy around'. However, it does have more of the overtones of a bailout or clean up budget. If this is a turnaround budget, we are definitely not yet at the point where we stop the bleeding, having instead as it were, to spend more now to avoid spending more later. High on the agenda for help were CLICO and, more surprisingly, the HCU. My view is that Finance Minister Winston Dookeran approached these issues as sensibly as could be done in the circumstances. If CLICO has cost the taxpayer $7.3 billion so far, this approximates to the entire deficit of the previous budget. It was a catastrophic meltdown which inflicted a considerable blow on the public purse. The hemorrhage continues, and if the government were to bail out everyone, then we would go bust in a heartbeat. The cruel fact is that many depositors were chasing above-average returns, and should have to bear the pains such investment moves sometimes bring. The HCU deserves help on a principled basis. The argument that HCU did not threaten the stability of the financial system and therefore did not deserve some help was clearly unsound, particularly given the regulatory weaknesses that failed so spectacularly to protect depositors. I therefore think that an argument can be made to help these people. The only difference between the HCU and CL was size, and this is at best an imperfect justification for intervention in one and a hands-off approach with the other. However, it does somewhat establish the precedent that the government will protect depositors whenever a financial institution goes bust. Nothing wrong with that, but then we need far more sophisticated oversight of the credit union sector, and should pay special attention to the several credit unions that are in an extremely unhealthy financial state as this article is being written. Further, if the public must bail out those who have taken greater risk, then certainly the level of statutory deposits must increase, and the proposed rates of returns adjusted downwards accordingly. Finally, the part I liked best about Mr Dookeran's speech had to do with the consequences of these failures. Those responsible at these organisations should be held to account. At least some should be in jail, and all should be debarred from holding other positions. Their Audit Committees should have to answer for their ignorance of the impending failure which nearly capsized our economy and certainly capsized the lives of many people. The budget speech said that action would be taken. It remains to be seen how the issue of prosecuting some of their own supporters, who may have featured prominently in these meltdowns, will be worked out. Education The education system has received the largest chunk of funding from the budget. This is of course laudable and it represents an investment in our future. Yet a view of the education landscape reveals spotty progress and at the tertiary level, it looks like the Wild, Wild West. The problem with our education system begins, but is not restricted to our primary schools. We aren't doing a good enough job there, and too few pass SEA. The secondary school bottleneck isn't helping, and each year too many of our youngsters are ejected from the system, often to join the criminal underworld at very young ages. The expansion of GATE to cover vocational training (which saves some of these very people later on) is laudable. However, the tertiary system is in disarray and needs badly to be consolidated. The provision of GATE funds to for-profit institutions is of questionable logic, if not integrity. The kind of education Trinidad and Tobago needs requires researchers, not merely teachers. These are not easily built in the private sector because academic research costs money with often little or no economic payback. When we extend a 50 per cent GATE subsidy to private institutions that offer degrees from unknown universities, we are merely lining the pockets of entrepreneurs who have spied and taken advantage of an opportunity presented by a shortage of public spaces. The solution is to expand the public system, or encourage charitable public-private partnerships, not to subsidise the profits of private institutions led by people seeking profit. Of course, these entrepreneurs would disagree. They have honed their arguments and cultivated their political contacts over the years to ensure they get better slices of the GATE pie. But how many researchers have they produced What contribution have they made to the advancement of the reputation of Trinidad and Tobago as a knowledge-driven country This is important because Trinidad and Tobago is becoming an innovation-driven economy and new knowledge matters. Profit isn't evil. It is good. And entrepreneurship is to be encouraged everywhere, including the education system. But state subsidies to the extent that GATE offers should not go so easily into the hands and pockets of private, for-profit institutions. National Security The $1,000 tax free duty allowance is a good start. Crime and theft should now be critically addressed, since these represent the single greatest challenge to business and entrepreneurship in Trinidad and Tobago according to the recent Global Competitiveness Report. The manpower problem in the Police Service should be partially resolved with the shrinking of the Army and retraining of soldiers. Crime poses a greater threat to national security than invasion (which we cannot repel even at full Army strength). We should have the courage to redistribute these resources. Note, Costa Rica has no army and the State has not collapsed. The logic of Lord Mountbatten that we should be able to provide some token resistance against invasion, and the use of this as a qualifying factor for independence should no longer apply. The big-spending SAUTT should be put under the control of the TTPS. It is alarming that such an organisation could continue to be left to its own devices, under the complete control of politicians, without any kind of oversight. The intelligence and training capabilities of SAUTT should therefore be brought into the TTPS and wages and salaries harmonised. CEPEP and URP The recent charm offensive by CEPEP was well done. However, a new coat of paint doesn't change the beast in the slightest and these programmes need to be changed. Specifically, CEPEP needs to be refocused into something productive like agriculture. We need to change our approach from cutting things down to growing them. The URP meanwhile, is a mystery. Trinidad and Tobago has a lower unemployment level than the US and many other developed countries. Yet, URP (which stands for Unemployment Relief Programme) is going strong. How could this be Where is the unemployment problem that this programme is meant to alleviate The private sector is starved for low-end staff to help drive the entrepreneurial engine of the economy. If government is serious about entrepreneurship, these workers should be redeployed instead of being left to lives of low productivity or to fill criminal gangs, both of which make them unemployable later on. Overall, I would say that given the state of the economy they inherited and the time this government had, the budget was a very good effort. It fell short of the austerity measures it might have contained. But it has done its best to soften the blow and to take pragmatic (eg exploration incentives, tax amnesty) and obvious (eg police allowance, special court) steps to change course even if the new route is not yet fully charted. We will have to wait not only for the debate but for the next budget, next year, to perhaps get a fuller picture. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-economy-the-rhetoric-and-the-reality/article_287eb60e-4110-568e-9013-341ac901cb3c.html", "TITLE": " The economy, the rhetoric and the reality ", "DATE": "Jun 16, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " A few weeks ago, in his regular Quarterly Monetary Report, the Governor of the Central Bank, Ewart Williams, described our economy as being in a \"slump\". This description incurred the wrath of the Government. One Minister, Jack Warner, saw something nefarious in the fact that the Governor had released his report on the eve of the People's Partnership's second anniversary celebrations. Finance Minister, Winston Dookeran, for his part, hastened to deny that the economy was in a slump. As far as he was concerned the accurate description of the state of the economy is that \"growth prospects may have slowed but we are still in recovery mode.\" It is perhaps understandable that the Governor of the Central Bank may wish to couch his description of the economy in the most circumspect of terms so as not to give offence to the Government. And we know that the politicians, even those who were once economists, are mortally afraid of giving bad news to the electorate. So between the two we end up with statements which serve only to confuse and obfuscate our economic reality. So what is the true reality of our economy and how can we translate the jargon of the economists and the obfuscation of the politicians into language which the ordinary citizens can understand Let us start from the fact, which neither economist nor politician can deny, that our economy has experienced three consecutive years of economic decline, and even the prediction of very modest growth in 2012 is problematic and may not be realised. What does this mean It means that for each of those three years not only did the economy not grow but in fact it produced less than it did the year before. Now strictly speaking that is not a slump. The term \"slump\", in economic jargon, usually refers to a sudden decline in business or stock market activity. Three consecutive years of economic decline can hardly be described as \"sudden\". After three years of decline the more accurate term to describe the economy is \"stagnated\". The next question, of course, is why is economic growth important Economic growth is the increase in the amount of goods and services produced by the economy. It is conventionally measured as the percent rate of increase in gross domestic product (GDP) which is the market value of the total of goods and services produced by the economy. The importance of economic growth is that it is the necessary condition for achieving an increased standard of living for the population. With an increased production of goods and services people can benefit from consuming more goods and services. The government, through increased tax revenues, can spend more on important public services such as health and education. By stimulating greater investment economic growth helps to reduce unemployment by creating jobs. More jobs means less social problems such as crime and poverty. Now economic growth by itself does not necessarily bring all these benefits. Whether it does depends in large part on attendant governmental fiscal and social policies. But what is certain is that where there is no economic growth these benefits cannot be realised and with prolonged economic decline the standard of living of the population is certain to be reduced and the social problems such as crime and poverty will increase. The next question is why is our economy stagnant and in decline The answer is that growth in our economy has always been dependent almost exclusively upon the energy sector. This sector generates over 90 per cent of exports and foreign exchange and more than 50 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) and government revenue. It is these revenues from the energy sector which, when spent by the government, drive the economic activity and growth in the so-called \"non-energy sector\". Indeed it is something of a fallacy even to say that 50 per cent of our GDP comes from the \"non-energy\" sector. For without the government expenditure which derives from the energy sector revenues the so-called \"non-energy sector\" will swiftly shrink almost to insignificance. But the energy sector, upon which so much of our economic activity depends, is not within our control. In the first place the sector is dominated by transnational corporations which use international enterprise, capital and technology to exploit our indigenous natural resources for their global operations. Second, the prices obtained for these resources, which in turn determine the revenues the government obtains, are set by international market forces over which we have no control and finally, the resources of this sector are depleting assets which require huge dollar investments, which we do not have, to find and generate. Our current economic stagnation and decline therefore stems directly from the fact that after a period of very high international oil and gas prices which obtained from 2002 to 2007, prices of these commodities declined precipitously in 2008 with a consequential significant decline in government revenues. Furthermore, even prior to 2008, the energy sector had been in a state of decline both in terms of production levels and new investments. Oil production has declined from 130,000 barrels a day in 2002 to some 90,000 barrels a day, currently. As far as gas is concerned the situation is even more critical. Not only are gas prices still very depressed, but the country's reserves to production ratio is now less than ten years. This means that at current production rates we won't have any gas in ten years and all the huge petrochemical industry which was created based on the availability of cheap natural gas will shut down. What all of this means should be clear. Government revenues are going to remain depressed for the foreseeable future and are likely to decline even further as the contraction in the so-called non-energy sector continues. As government revenues continue to fall its current levels of expenditure on transfers and subsidies are going to become, even with increases in the national debt, unsustainable. When that time comes no one will need to explain to the population the truth of our economic reality. Michael Harris has been for many years a writer and commentator on politics and society in Trinidad and the wider Caribbean. He is a long-standing member of the Tapia House Group and works as a human resource executive. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/howai-economy-will-be-strong-next-year/article_b8dc630c-3eeb-5a4e-83a2-ec7ff58dbb8a.html", "TITLE": " Howai: Economy will be strong next year ", "DATE": "Oct 22, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "talking about it: Chairman of the International Association of Deposit Insurers Jerzy Pruski, left, chats with Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambaran following the opening ceremony of the association\u0092s 13th annual general meeting on Wednesday at the Hyatt Regency in Port of Spain. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE talking about it: Chairman of the International Association of Deposit Insurers Jerzy Pruski, left, chats with Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambaran following the opening ceremony of the association\u0092s 13th annual general meeting on Wednesday at the Hyatt Regency in Port of Spain. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE Finance Minister Larry Howai has a lot of optimism for Trinidad and Tobagos economy in the near future. It may have a lot to do with the planned construction of the Mitsubishi methanol to petrochemicals plant. In June 2012, the government recieved a proposal from the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan for a methanol to petrochemicals project. The US$800 million plant is a major investment, construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of next year. It is expected to add a further boost to the economy. Howai says the local economy continues to grow and overall will be very robust and strong in 2014. The non-energy sector particularly has been very encouraging for us, the non energy sector has actually grown at a rate of 2.5 per cent which is a strong rate of growth in todays economy, said Howai. The growth in the non energy sector has been able to offset the downturn we experienced in the energy sector because the energy sector itself has been experiencing a downturn as a result of the maintenance works that have been taking place in that sector, we had a major turnaround which resulted in significant reduction in the output of the energy sector but overall the economy has continued to grow and we expect next year to show an even stronger rate of growth because most of the maintenance work has been completed in the energy sector, we expect the non-energy sector to continue to grow and once the global economy continues to hold up, we expect that the performance of the overall economy will be very strong and robust in 2014. Howai was speaking to a audience of customers and regulators at the Bank of Barodas sixth anniversary dinner celebrations at the Regent Star Hotel in Piarco last Wednesday night. One couldnt help but notice that the mood of everyone present appeared to be light and relaxed, perhaps that had a lot to do with the breaking news that flashed on TV screens everywhere earlier in the day which everyone was eagerly anticipating - United States President Barack Obama signed a law ending the 16-day partial government shutdown, extending the US debt limit. This latest news coming out of the US must have had Howai and economists breathing a sigh of relief. Were looking forward to good things next year, we hope the US will get past the shutdown of the government that occurred and we expect that this would happen in the next couple of weeks, certainly it will not go beyond the end of this month so that we hope that the US economy will be back on track we hope- during the course of next year which will keep a number of other economies moving and therefore the T&T economy will continue to benefit. Once those external factors are brought under control we feel reasonably comfortable that next year will be a strong year for the economy, said Howai. Howai also has words of commendation for the Bank of Baroda which he said was a solid addition to the family of financial institutions in T&T. Its an institution that has a long history, and deep roots, its a solid institution with over eight trillion rupees in assets, in TTD I think the profits last year would have been around $4.5 billion, so its a strong institution, very well capitilised, with very strong returns, its the second largest bank in India. Its an institution that has weathered good times and bad in India as well as in the global economy. And that is something that gives confidence to the government of T&T, said Howai. The Bank of Baroda (Trinidad and Tobago) Limited, is a subsidiary of Bank of Baroda, Indias International Bank with over 46 million customers, in 25 countries worldwide and has been successfully banking for more than 105 years and is owned and operated by the Government of India. Its first branch in T&T opened on October 2007, two more branches were opened on July 2009 in Chaguanas and San Fernando. The bank offers a full range of banking products in deposits, loans and advances, remittances, foreign exchange and NRI account services. Bank of Baroda is an Indian state-owned banking and financial services company headquartered in Baroda, or Vadodara in India. It offers a range of banking products and financial services to corporate and retail customers through its branches and through its specialised subsidiaries and affiliates in the areas of retail banking, investment banking, credit cards, and asset management. Its total global business makes it the second largest bank in India after State Bank of India. In addition to its headquarters in its home state of Gujarat, it has a corporate headquarters in the Bandra Kurla Complex in Mumbai. Based on 2012 data, it is ranked 715 on Forbes Global 2000 list. The bank was founded by the Maharaja of Baroda, H. H. Sir Sayajirao Gaekwad III in July 1908 in Baroda state in Gujarat. The bank, along with 13 other major commercial banks of India, was nationalised in July 1969, by the government of India. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/is-this-finance-minister-serious/article_ab65e771-80b3-54d8-8bdf-932cf7aabd99.html", "TITLE": " Is this finance minister serious ", "DATE": "Oct 2, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Budget 2013 has as its theme 'Stimulating Growth, Generating Prosperity', and it sets out on pages 25-30 'Initiatives for Diversifying the Economy' to 'increase the non-energy share of GDP to 66.0 per cent over the next five years', and so achieve this prosperity. The priority non-energy sectors identified are financial services, tourism, information and communication technology, downstream energy industries, agriculture, creative arts, and 'the maritime sectors' seven of them. So how does the government plan to make these areas prosperous Let's choose one area, say financial services, and see what they have to say; it's on page 27. They are going to develop this sector in two ways. First, they are going to create a subsector the financial institution support services industry within the financial services sector, and this industry will launch the International Financial Centre (IFC), which will offer 'shared service centres' to national, regional, and international financial institutions. And secondly, they are going to introduce supportive legislation with tax incentives 'early in the new year', with their activities 'encapsulated in a strong legislative framework' that will be laid during 2013. The latter will include 'a new Securities Act, a new Insurance Act, and the Credit Union Act as well as legislation to effect electronic payments in the Government Services'. With these two 'initiatives', they expect the sector to 'generate substantial benefits': i) absorption of graduates from tertiary educational institutions; ii) provision over the next five years of '3,000 good quality jobs for knowledge workers; iii) on a multiplier effect basis, 6,000-12,000 total jobs'. The impact on GDP will be 'immediate and positive'. Finance Minister Howai tells us that the non-energy share of GDP stands at $30.6 billion, but that it needs to be increased to 66 per cent of GDP. I expected him, therefore, to quantify the result in dollars and cents to tell us how much of that sum he estimates the financial sector services will bring in. But he doesn't; he's content to speak in terms of 'substantial benefits', expressed in job creation terms. How serious can he be I ask. What about the other six priority areas Does he quantify their expected contribution to GDP Tourism: nope. We hear about the Ministry of Tourism and the THA 'increasing' their marketing and promotion programmes. We hear about the establishment of Trinidad and Tobago Business Development Ltd to administer the Tobago Development Fund, which will have an initial capital of $100 million and annual allocations of $50 million in 2013 and 2014. But no, no quantification of the contribution of tourism to GDP in dollars and cents. How serious can he be Information and Communication Technology: Yes Howai promises the building of a competitive ICT industry based on 'our strong tertiary education network, our sophisticated and competitive telecommunications infrastructure, our cheap and reliable electricity supply and our well-educated and capable work force'. But guess what He provides an estimate of the contribution of this initiative to GDP 6.7 per cent over the next five years, but he tells us that it is the World Bank, not he, who did the estimating. Shaking my head. Downstream energy industries (or 'Gasoline Vehicles Conversion to CNG): A big nope. Howai announces that the Government has developed 'a comprehensive business plan which will invest $1.5 billion in converting gasoline vehicles to compressed natural gas Really How's that scientifically possible over a five-year period initially, but there's nary a word on how the investment will translate into a contribution to GDP and in what amounts. Instead, he increases the price of premium gasoline from $4 to $5.75 per litre and hints at other increases of the price of super unleaded in 2013. Is he really serious about increasing the prosperity of the non-energy sector You get the picture It's more of the same for agriculture, creative arts, and the maritime sectors. Announcement of plans that are opaque as to their contribution to GDP, and yet the minister sets out to show us how these subsectors will be managed to grow the non-energy share of GDP. The offering of the Minister of Finance on this matter seems to be quite lazy and insincere. But I may be wrong: the estimates could very well come in the contributions of other ministers . {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/we-must-overhaul-our-economy/article_dc232414-af91-518e-9464-91698432ab3a.html", "TITLE": " We must overhaul our economy ", "DATE": "Apr 29, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "THIS is in response to two articles in a recent Express Business magazine and a follow-up Express editorial (April 27). Dr Roger Hosein of UWI in his address to the Employers' Consultative Association's annual general meeting claimed our economy was suffering from the Dutch and Baumol diseases and was under the threat of shale gas production elsewhere. He saw the Dutch disease, the result of our plantation economy's dependence on the energy sector, which employs some three per cent of the labour force, provides 55 per cent of the Government's revenue and 86 per cent of our export income, as influencing higher wages and salaries in the non-energy sector and driving lower productivity in on-shore manufacturing. Dr Hosein also pointed to the impact of Government transfers and subsidies, which hinders the competitiveness of the on-shore sector since it manipulates the employment levels via make-work programmes that starve this sector of labour and increase its price, a characteristic of the Dutch disease. He recommends that we need to provide long-term sustainable jobs in the economy. How, one may well ask Dr Hosein was also concerned about our increasing debt and that our income from the energy sector is decreasing and is at risk due to shale gas in other countries. He questioned whether we could afford the current level of subsidies, e.g. in fuel and GATE. He was surprised that our government (not the private sector)had not yet addressed the problem of finding new markets or what our new exports should be or even the failure to address the threat of shale gas. Nicholas Lok Jack, new president of the T&T Manufacturers Association, sees that a labour shortage is a major problem for this sector. He also refers to government's employment make-work programmes and the sector's difficulty in competing with the government for these resources. According to him, in order to attract and keep workers the employers have to keep adding incentives and pay increases for what people are supposed to do for a basic wage\u2014the Baumol disease. This drives up the cost of and is destroying the standard of living, increasing inflation again, causing people to demand more money. Both commentators also blame the artificial costs of traffic, port and custom inefficiencies for driving costs up. Lok Jack concludes that we have to look to the global economy since our growth in manufacturing is not going to come from the local and Caricom markets. This is an economist and a businessman just repeating the woes of the economic model that our history has bestowed upon us. The plantation/Dutch economy has imprinted its characteristics on our labour (low skills, high demands), on our government spending, subsidies, transfers to sustain the on-shore economy. The manufacturing sector, generally assembly type, is structurally hamstrung by the problems of low skills, low productivity and by the lack of local and global networking systems that include finance, innovation, marketing and market development. Fixing T&T is not an option. Our economy has to be reconstructed to take advantage of the current global threats, our opportunities. This means providing an economy that can access knowledge, implement it in new high-value products and services and create it (IP). The current on-shore economy is incapable of this on its own and requires an intervention by government, one that results in the building of an experimentally organised economy.
