{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/arithmetic-lessons-for-the-finance-minster/article_1347fad5-fdef-5e4d-8ad3-a81f579990fb.html", "TITLE": " Arithmetic lessons for the Finance Minster ", "DATE": "Apr 23, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "Trinidad and Tobago is one cantankerous country\u2014we always quarrelling. In fact, we invariably have several quarrels raging at any point in time over issues or personalities such that we go off on tangents, forgetting who or what was in dispute in the first instance. It is often said that you cannot please all the people all the time. With respect to Trinis, you cannot please anyone anytime. This characteristic is not to be confused with the proverb, \u201cyou can fool all the people some of the time\u2026but you cannot fool all the people all the time\u201d. In this latter regard, you can fool all Trinis all the time: just inform them via e-mail that they have won the jackpot in a lotto they know nothing about, and you can relieve them of a \u201cprocessing fee\u201d. But back to our quarrelsome nature: before the row over the Tobago ferry could subside, we are barking and biting, pot hound-style, over the introduction of the revised property tax, which we knew would be implemented as far back as when the PNM won the election in 2015, and which we know is a standard form of taxation in most countries. Now, I should say up front that I believe Finance Minister Colm Imbert and those who are advising him in the exercise are playing the ox. The one-month window they have decreed for property owners to submit piles of documents to the Valuation Division for appraisal is unimaginably inadequate. Bearing in mind that citizens can be penalised for failing to comply, let me explain why I say Colm is an ox. Taxable properties under the law are residences, commercial, industrial and agricultural businesses, agricultural lands and other vacant, privately-owned lands. The State is exempt, which means that anyone who is squatting on State lands, whether he is operating a quarry or living in a shack, is not obligated to pay the tax. But you and I, law-abiding citizens, must comply. Which tells you what The law is an ass, and those who formulate it or rigidly enforce it are jackasses. Now, in the 2011 census exercise, the Central Statistical Office determined there were 401,000 residential households in the country. By now, that number might have risen to 450,000. Add, say, 50,000 commercial and industrial properties, and a minimum of another 100,000 parcels of land either vacant or agricultural, and you have a massive 600,000 property owners straining at the bits to board the Valuation Division. As readers may have guessed by now, valuation, which falls under the Ministry of Finance, has a grand total of nine offices! Yes, you read right\u2014nine. And if we factor in under-staffing, subtract lunch hours and social media time, more than likely not more than 500 officials are being asked to accommodate 600,000 sets of documents in no more than 20 working days! Simple arithmetic ought to tell super-bright Colm (so his friends say) that we are talking about 30,000 transactions per day! Madness! The only Government agency that has such capacity is the NLCB, whose hundreds of Play Whe outlets cater for tens of thousands of gamblers every day. No other, not Inland Revenue, not the police, not the courts or the health system, even if they are combined, can handle such a flow of people. Mr Minister, you will need at least one year\u2014and that is optimistic\u2014to simply allow all property owners to submit their documents, and for valuation to commence appraisal where that is necessary. I note this latter because I am crediting officials at Valuation with having established some methodologies for applying the tax, hence not needing to physically assess all properties, a process that could take forever. I have no problem with having to pay property tax, once it's reasonable and fairly applied. While the timing of its implementation is not propitious, what with the depressed economy, many persons on the breadline, and generally people catching hell, it must be done at some time\u2014if not now, when Government should offer deferment to retrenched workers who may have acquired homes when they were employed, but are currently under stress. They will not remain unemployed forever. Also, pensioners who will have worked long and hard to own modest homes, should be given consideration: maybe those who inherit their properties when they die can fulfil this obligation before taking possession. Property tax laws, unlike those that apply to incomes, profits and consumption, should be administered with a heart, if we can conceive of politicians and tax collectors having hearts. I cannot, however, agree with people who willingly pay higher taxes when they visit or reside in developed countries, but who insist on paying nothing in their native land. Such persons are aptly described in Sir Walter Scott's poem \u201cPatriotism\u201d: \u201cBreathes there the man with soul so dead\u2026Despite those titles, power and pelf\u2026The wretch, concentrated all in self\u2026shall go down to the vile dust from whence he sprung\u2026\u201d IN yet another incident which has had the effect of piling \u00adembarrassment upon embarrassment for the authorities, a convict walked out of the Golden Grove facility in Arouca on Thursday, and was on the run up to last night. THE West Indies has had a phenomenal number of exceptional cricketers in its history. The captains have been mostly \u00admiddling. I restricted the playbooks to those of Frank Worrell, Richie Benaud and Mike Brearley simply because they were known as thinking men; able in both the technical and \u201cman-management\u201d aspects of the game. International Youth Day is approaching. It is time for the youth of this country to stand up and make their voices heard. It is time to become more \u00adinvolved in the political process to put an end to the corruption and mismanagement taking place far too often and for too long. Recently, the press \u00adreported that a mother was in tears after her victim impact statement was read out in court during the trial of the accused for her son\u2019s murder. She cried out for answers as to the reason the accused, having robbed her son of his \u00adcellphone, had killed him. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/stock-market-leads-economy-shall-follow/article_438bfb93-8d30-599d-96b8-45e425deb6ad.html", "TITLE": " Stock market leads, economy shall follow ", "DATE": "Nov 2, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "The Standard and Poor's 500 Index (S&P) surpassed the 1,180 threshold on 18 October, a level not seen since April of this year, and extended the monthly rally seen in September into October. But what exactly is causing this rally Economic data remains mixed and is yet to show any clear signs of recovery. Third quarter earnings reports from some of the biggest Wall Street banks show 'profits', but this was largely based on the reduction of loan-loss reserves. For most of 2010, the S&P has traded below the 1,180 level except during the month of April when the index rallied to hit a high of 1,217.28. This rally was backed by strong earnings reports and a surge in new-home sales seen during the month of March. With the market pricing in the expected second round of quantitative easing from the Fed and the 1,200 mark seemingly close on the horizon, it begs the question, is this rally justified Reports indicate that the recession which began in December 2007, lasted 18 months to end in June of 2009, marking the longest recession since World War 2. During that time, the S&P plummeted to a low of 676.53 in March 2009 as the recession deepened and investors became increasingly skeptical. The market has 'recovered' since that low, to end 2009 at a level of 1,115.10 marking a 23.45% gain for that year. Thus far, for 2010, the index has traded above the July low of 1,022.58 when the market sold-off in response to slow growth in manufacturing, an unexpected jump in jobless claims and a slump in new home sales. New home sales data, which has been volatile for the year so far, has had a strong impact on the stock market. After ending March at 1,169.43, the index rallied to 1,217.28 on 23 April on the news that the purchase of new homes in the US had its highest monthly surge in March with sales rising by 10.7% month-on-month. This represented the fastest single-month rate in 47 years as buyers rushed to snatch up properties to qualify for the government tax credit that was set to expire by the end of April. The rally in April was followed by two dips in the stock market seen at end-June and end-August consecutively as new home sales data was released for the months of May and July. The largest negative change was recorded in May with purchases down 31.9% for the month. This dip to 282,000 came soon after the expiration of the tax credit government programme and was exacerbated by a decline in retail sales and a slowdown in private job growth. The dip to follow in July, announced at end-August, showed a monthly decline of 8.1% in sales as the unemployment rate remained above the 9.5% level dampening consumer confidence leading to a plunge in home demand. September was the best performing month of the year for the S&P, yielding a return of 8.71% on the news that the recession which began in December 2007 ended in June 2009 and as the risk of a double-dip recession somewhat subsided. This rally in September was a boost to the S&P's third quarter performance which saw a 10.72% gain over the period to close at 1,141.20. At the time of writing, the market was up 3.41% in the 10th month of the year reaching 1,185.64, a level not seen since the rally in April. This 1,185.64 level was reflective of the slight increase in the consumer confidence index from September to October as the index climbed to 50.2 from 48.6, beyond the 50 level which signals an expansion. The question now is will the 1,200 mark be broken to end the year close to some analysts' forecasted '1,300 closing level' or will the market retreat to levels seen at the end of 2009 The stock market continues to react to a number of factors and fundamentals are yet to signal a strong recovery to consumer confidence which is reflective of consumer demand, the main driver of US growth. It has been argued that unless we see an improvement to the housing market, the downfall of which drove the US into recession, the risk of a double-dip recession still lingers. Unemployment is still high and new home sales remain at some of its lowest levels, rising mainly when the market is boosted by some sort of government support. It is obvious that government support offers short-term relief, but as we have seen, the market quickly retreats to 'pre-government support' levels as these assistance programs expire. The market is vulnerable and remains sticky upwards to the 1,200 mark, which, if it crosses can either lead to a strong uptrend or reverse as it did in April as weak economic data throws investors back into uncertainty and risk aversion. Past research shows that the stock market can act as a leading indicator for economic activity, and as highlighted in a recent article, can be based on a couple of fundamentals such as the wealth effect, a slowdown in IPO and equity financing, a plunge in pension plans and confidence. The wealth effect is reflective of consumer confidence which dwindles as the stock market declines and gives investors the impression of having less wealth to spend. This in turn dampens consumer demand and ultimately economic growth. IPO and equity financing can also slow as companies are deterred by the declining stock prices which inhibit company growth as there is limited access to capital. Declining stock prices also affect company portfolios which can have a direct effect on how businesses choose to organise their spending. The final point highlighted was that of confidence. The perception of economic policies is said to be reflected in the stock market both when positive and negative hence making the stock market \"directly related to broad confidence in the economy\". This in turn impacts consumer confidence and their level of demand for goods and services has a major effect on economic growth. Without a doubt, the US economy and the US stock market performance over the past 3 years have perturbed some analysts as usual 'trends' and 'effects' have been broken. Investors have become highly sensitive to data reacting strongly to any speculation in the market. With that said, giving a clear and accurate view on the market is no small undertaking and investing at this time is not for the faint-hearted. The outcome of the US mid-term elections and the minutes of the FOMC meeting will unquestionably have a strong impact on the market. A break through beyond the 1,200 mark on the S&P will send a strong signal to the market but investors should remain wary and ensure that economic fundamentals and the performance of the US Dollar support a bull run in the market. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-future-for-small-businesses/article_628d859e-3250-58ff-8407-29262835aca6.html", "TITLE": " A future for small businesses ", "DATE": "Feb 20, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " Finance Minister Winston Dookeran addressed the issue of development and security of small and medium-sized companies operating in Trinidad and Tobago during a presentation at the SME Credit Rating Public Sensitisation Seminar, hosted by the Bankers Association of Trinidad and Tobago at the Chamber of Industry and Commerce on January 31. He noted that in Trinidad and Tobago, there are about 18,000 SMEs, employing approximately 200,000 people or close to 35 per cent of the workforce and contributing near to 20 per cent of the gross domestic product. \"The SME is an important pillar for economic survival and growth in Trinidad and Tobago,\" he said. Following is the full text of Dookeran's presentation: \"A World of Uncertainty - Rebalancing of the Economy\" One year ago when the initiative was taken for a joint project between the Inter-American Development Bank and CariCRES, the world was somewhat a different place. We were at the height of much uncertainty, both globally and locally, but during the course of this year, as we are beginning to see the full depth of that uncertainty. What we are facing today is a rebalancing of the global economy, a rebalancing between deficit countries and surplus countries, a rebalancing between creditor countries and debtor countries, a rebalancing between strategies that depend on export growth and strategies that now depend on domestic demand. At first it appeared that this was a crisis that can be contained within the private sector and the bursting of the housing bubble in the United States and elsewhere suggested that we were dealing with a case of market failure. But it became clear that it was only the tip of the iceberg and, as we have seen over the last year, the issue has moved from the private sector to the public sector. The world is now engaged in the manifestation of that crisis through the sovereign debt crisis in Europe, Greece, of course, being the prime example but there are many others. But even before we come to terms with the fact that the crisis has shifted from private sector to the public sector, it is now recognized that the crisis indeed affects the national economies and hence we have seen certain initiatives within recent limes that are responding to the national dimension of this crisis. Europe is trying once again to redo the integration model and to include the fiscal discipline that they felt was absent, A new diplomacy has developed on the issue of currency realignment and that diplomacy has been reflected by the global dynamics between China and the US, and in some sense we have come to the point now where the financing of development as opposed to growth has become the key issue. And therefore, it is appropriate that the Bankers Association took that step one year ago to prepare for the challenges of financing economic development. We must put aside what has turned out to be platitudes for diversification into real changes in the structures of the economy that will facilitate diversification. \"A New Direction is driving the Budget Strategy\" It is appropriate, therefore, for us to reflect on the underlining new directions of the budget strategy over the last two years. The first was widening our economic space, geographically, sectorially and from the point of view of human capability. That has been one of the pillars in changing the structures upon which this economy, so narrowly based, is to be changed. The second has to do with fixing the balance sheet and, more specifically, the public financial balance sheet which was at the risk of falling apart. The third was expanding the capital market. There is an underlying philosophical underpinning in the budget. We must move away from the lime when we look at our budgets as \"What I can get\" to a budget which can answer the question, \"What I can be\". That fundamental philosophical change is what we are using to set the new structures to achieve. It is in that context, therefore, that the role of entrepreneurship was put at the front burner so that we can articulate in concrete terms the change in philosophical direction from \"What I can get\" to \"What I can be.\" In the past it is fair to say, that budget exercises have been seen by all as \"What I can get from the State\". Our attempt therefore to restructure the expectations of the budget to what I can be is a much more difficult role and is one that will not succumb to shortterm political aspirations but to longer-term directional change. The role of entrepreneurship has become important, more important now than at any time. It is in that context that we can look at the outcome of some of the measures that have been put into place to change the structures of the economy. There's no doubt that our financial balance sheet has now been largely restored to a level of stability. There is no doubt that we have begun to think about investment, although, we have not yet seen the investment required for expanding the space of these economies across the region, within the country, and in the creation of new sectors. There's no doubt that in the process we have begun to see steps to strengthen the capital market. Expectations for change have been the political framework within which this Government began this journey for economic transformation, but there's no doubt that such expectations will indeed result in some anticipated pain. Such pain is, in fact, one of the political issues that must be faced as we grapple with the journey of realizing the new expectation not only for us but for times ahead of us. \"Steps in Transforming Structures of the Economy\" What we are engaged in is not only a quick fix solution to today's problem, but indeed a systematic change, a transformation in the structures upon which this economy will operate in the future. Part of this transformation clearly lies with the small and medium enterprises. This is one of the major pillars for growth creation in our country. There is no doubt that the small and medium-sized sector is significant worldwide. In Trinidad and Tobago, there are about 18,000 SMEs, employing approximately 200,000 persons or close to 35 per cent of the workforce and contributing near to 20 per cent of the gross domestic product. The SME is an important pillar for economic survival and growth in Trinidad and Tobago. What we must now do is build some new structures that will further support the efforts of the SMEs as the single sector that will generate employment in the short term. To do so we have engaged in a policy perspective on five major changes. \"Lending in Banking Sector\" The first has to do with the banking sector itself and we have argued that the focus of lending in the banking sector should shift, not to rely as heavily as it has done on debt financing of the Government for its profits but on loan financing to the private sector for its sustainability, and to do that we have had discussions with the private sector, with the banking sector and with the Tobago Chamber on the issue of derisking funding arrangements for the revival of the Tobago economy. Such measures are being worked out in light of the fact that Tobago has become the first area of vulnerability in the Trinidad and Tobago economy. Derisking, therefore, is an important new measure in the structure of financing of the banking sector. Much work needs to be done in this regard. \"Recapitalising State Enterprises\" The second area is to recapitalise the State Enterprises sector. Much of this sector has become inefficient, has not added value to the country's economy but remains a call on the public Treasury. To recapitalise this sector was announced in 2011, and further reinforced in the 2012 budget with our desire to move towards a public offerings programme. Public Offerings are not about privatisation. Public Offerings are about the distribution of the wealth of the country. It is about seeking efficiency measures. It is also about building the capital. \"Encouraging Growth for SMEs\" The third area in building new structures is to reignite the capital market and its growth for SMEs and you will recollect in the budget we introduced an additional window that will bring SMEs into direct opportunities for raising capital in the public by having what some refer to as a junior market and I hope that the stock exchange will accelerate its efforts to sell the idea as well as to make it happen, and that is part of the programme of recapitalising or reigniting the expansion of the capital market. \"Refocusing on Fiscal Discipline\" The fourth area is refocusing on fiscal discipline. Fiscal discipline at the national level is but a mirror of fiscal discipline at the enterprise level. To fix the fiscal discipline at the national level, can only be sustained by fixing the fiscal discipline at the enterprise level. It is in this context that the rating agency is important. We are engaged in trying to build a new momentum and a new awareness of fiscal discipline. The time has come where our enterprises must meet the standards of fiscal discipline and be measured and assessed and used as the basis upon which growth will take place. \"Developing Private and Public Sector Partnership\" The fifth area in changing the structures ahead of us has to do with the creation of the platform of private/public sector partnerships. It is a new dimension to financing. In the past we have been accustomed with public sector financing through its Public Sector Investment Programme, either directly from central government or with central government and state enterprises. In the past we have depended heavily on private sector financing of investment proposals for themselves and for our country. The lime has come to find a new partnership between private sector and public sector financing. We must find new ways and models by which we can share the risk, so that the private sector can get the returns and the public sector can reap the dividends on behalf of the people. This is, in Trinidad and Tobago, a somewhat new direction. We are currently engaged in working out the modalities of private/public sector financing. We hope that the banking sector will get very much involved in this particular dimension of financing development for, through them, we can add better access to financing SMEs. These, therefore, are some of the fundamental steps that have been taken in order to provide the new structures upon which SMEs growth can depend. These steps begin to address in a systematic way this new way of financing economic development. In so doing, we must of course build a new confidence that these new structures are sustainable in the future and are, in fact, going to meet the demands of today's population. \"Maintaining and Increasing Levels of Employment\" It is therefore important, in designing our investment plans, to ensure that we maintain, if not increase, our employment levels. In our current national environment this can only be achieved at the enterprise level. Careful thought must now be given to all enterprises in the new structure to maintaining and increasing employment levels. \"Increasing Profitability\" Especially in today's world, it is also important to have deliberate strategies for a more competitive environment, and to find ways and means to increase one's productivity. The profitability of the national economy is dependent on the profitability and as well as the enterprises in that industry. \"Ease of Doing and Operating Business\" The third area focuses on changes required to make it easier to do business and operate business in Trinidad and Tobago. We have engaged the International Financial Corporation of the United States, a private sector arm of the World Bank, to work with us and devise ways and means to make it easier to do business in Trinidad and Tobago. The indicators of doing business need to be improved. These are changes must take place rather quickly. \"Conversion of Financial Liquidity Economic Development\" In terms of growing confidence, we must convert the financial liquidity existing in the banking sector to production and income. The existence of excess financial liquidity does little to advance the economic development of Trinidad and Tobago. Prudent use of such liquidity is absolutely essential and, in that sense. What we engage in today would add to our ability to use in a most prudent way, to ensure that it is sustainable for the future. It must be converted into production and income. \"Participation of Business Community in Economic Development\" Public policy is but one complement to economic development momentum. Beyond public policy lie the decisions of the wider community, the banking sector, investors sector, small and medium enterprises sector, credit agencies. It is a combination of all working in the same direction. It will allow us to begin to change the structures so that we can truly say we are on the path of real transformation. It is going to be a long road but it is a road that we cannot afford not to start it is a road that we must be engaged in if we are to achieve a sense of confidence for the next generation. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/growing-pains-for-economy/article_f5a91feb-5cd2-561d-8063-02b5219a0834.html", "TITLE": " Growing pains for economy ", "DATE": "Dec 9, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "While the national economy is expected to grow marginally in calendar 2013, likely by 1.5 per cent, there is little cause for celebration. The year closes amidst heavily overcast conditions, much the way it began. In its latest Monetary Policy announcement (November 29), the Central Bank paints a bleak picture of severe contraction in the production sub-sector of the energy sector in the third quarter; high liquidity in the banking sector; and a contraction of borrowing by the business sector for the tenth consecutive month last September. According to the Bank, large-scale maintenance works in both upstream and downstream energy resulted in a sharp 4.0 per cent contraction, year-on-year. The Bank proffers that with maintenance works coming to an end, oil and gas production, and operations at downstream plants, should return to normal levels by 2014. Just what are normal levels, however, remains debatable at this time. Daily oil production (crude and condensate) seems stuck at around 80,000 barrels, sometimes declining below that, for more than a year. A few years ago, 100,000 bopd was considered normal. Are we likely to see a return to this level anytime soon While there are vigorous exploration and secondary recovery activities offshore and onshore, and some new wells are coming into production, nothing suggests a quantum leap soon from the current levels. Worse, this sluggish performance that some might label post-peak oil is happening when prices are buoyant. From this perspective, the countrys opportunity losses are enormous. Meanwhile, elsewhere in the economy, the picture is gloomy. Liquidity in the banking system remains stubbornly high. According to the Central Bank, commercial banks excess reserves reached a record daily average of $8.4 billion in September, and averaged $7.8 billion for the year. This huge sum of money is floating around after at least two billion-dollar bond issues by the Bank, a one billion-dollar bond by Nipdec that was over-subscribed, and a billion-dollar initial public offer (IPO) of shares by State-owned First Citizens that was also over-subscribed. In other words, concerted efforts to mop up excess liquidity in the banking system have failed to reduce idle capital. Curiously, last week Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambarran and Finance Minister Larry Howai travelled to North America to promote the issuance of a sovereign bond in the sum of US$500 million. Government has not explained what it hopes to achieve by this initiative. Even as commercial banks remained flush with cash, chief executive officer of the Chamber of Commerce, Catherine Kumar, pointed to disincentives to investment in the country, hence the paucity of projects in the commercial sector. There are two multi-million-dollar commercial complexes under construction in South Trinidad, but little else of significance. Ms Kumar listed the disincentives as uncertainty in the face of four elections and intense politicking during the year, continuing high crime, government bureaucracy, and an aversion to risk by commercial banks. On this latter score, Ms Kumar noted that small and medium enterprises that are more likely to invest in new projects encounter difficulties as they seek financing from banks, in spite of the banks holding excessive liquidity. The economic indicators are not all negative as we approach year-end. In the twelve months to October 2013, headline inflation slowed to 2.7 per cent, with food inflation much lower than it was one year ago. Consumer lending remains robust, with increases in motor vehicle loans, home renovations and debt consolidation. Overall, though, the economy is experiencing growth pains. While a 1.5 per cent growth for 2013, if we achieve that, could signal a turnaround of sorts, sluggishness in the vital energy sector for the fourth consecutive year is worrisome. For how much longer can the banks continue to thrive off fees and charges when they are swamped with billions of dollars in excess liquidity unmatched by investment loans With minimal activities in commercial construction and investments of any significance, the country seems to be in a state of stasis. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/sea-of-change-in-global-economy/article_642d539b-d156-57d8-a9b0-6b2a9dacaa87.html", "TITLE": " 'Sea of change' in global economy ", "DATE": "Jan 30, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Citibank chairman Suresh Maharaj speaks with Finance Minister Winston Dookeran at the handover of the bank's investment guide at Chaud Restaurant, Port of Spain on January 16. \u0097Photo: Ishmael Salandy Citibank chairman Suresh Maharaj speaks with Finance Minister Winston Dookeran at the handover of the bank's investment guide at Chaud Restaurant, Port of Spain on January 16. \u0097Photo: Ishmael Salandy Citibank (Trinidad & Tobago) chairman Suresh Maharaj last month handed over the 2011-2012 investment guide produced by the bank to Finance Minister Winston Dookeran. The guide highlights key information on Trinidad and Tobago, such as the economy, services, infrastructure, and the opportunities for investment. At a ceremonial handover hosted by the bank at Chaud Restaurant in Port of Spain, Maharaj commented on what he described as the \"sea of change we are witnessing in the global economy\" and what countries like Trinidad and Tobago needed to do to effectively compete for business. Following is an excerpt of Maharaj's presentation: First of all, the emerging and developed countries are gradually decoupling from one another. Emerging markets growth no longer depends on growth in developed economies and sometimes even continues strongly when developed markets are in recession. Second, emerging markets are growing much faster. They suffered less from the Great recession and recovered more quickly, Today China is back near ten per cent annually and India is close to eight per cent, for instance. I don't need to tell you how bad the growth figures are right now for the developed world. The US economy grew less than half a per cent in the first quarter of 2011 and just above one per cent in the second. The EU's numbers are even worse and the Japanese economy has actually shrunk for the past three quarters of 2011.The developed world is grappling with serious debt problems - both as a consequence of over-borrowing before the crash and long-term liabilities in popular pension, health care and other programmes. It is the general consensus that the developed nations will never again grow at anywhere near the clip that has become routine in the developing world. Research conducted by us has concluded that China and India will be the world's largest economies by around 2030. Such disparities would have been unthinkable only a few years ago. The developed markets drove world growth and the emerging markets hitched a ride. Not anymore. Now they speed off on their own. Third, the decoupling of the two economic zones is not only largely complete already, it is likely to be permanent. The biggest driver of this decoupling is the maturation of emerging markets and the consequent rise of intra-EM trade and capital flows. This is one of the most important economic trends of our time maybe the most important. Trade within the emerging markets has risen sharply from six per cent of total world trade to 13 per cent between 1995 and 2009. The advanced economies' share of global trade is now 65 per cent, down from 79 per cent in 1995 and this will continue. Fourth, the growing emerging market consumer base has the power to drive global GDP. Around the globe, millions of people rise above poverty and enter the middle class every year - by one estimate, some 70 million in 2009 alone. According to another estimate, by 2020, three-quarters of incremental consumer spending will come from emerging markets. If that estimate is correct, then by that year consumer spending in Asia will overtake North America to become the world's largest consumer bloc. To highlight the changes that have taken place, The Wall Street Journal ran an article last (month) headed \"Lessons in Humility\", and I quote: \"Who could have imagined that following the worst of the 1990s Asian financial crisis that in November 2011 the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William Dudley, would tell cadets at the US Military Academy at West Point: \"We can learn from the example of emerging nations that took the tough decisions necessary to emerge from past crises stronger, more competitive and better positioned ... \" \"Or that the sovereign debt of the US, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Ireland, and Japan would be downgraded while debt in Angola, Brazil, Bulgaria, Colombia, the Czech Republic, Estonia, and Peru would be upgraded.\" So that ladies and gentlemen, the point I want to leave you with is that a lot of the future growth is in the emerging markets and that Trinidad and Tobago is one of the emerging market countries that have much potential for growth. So, what are the factors that investors consider when they make a decision to invest in a country Some of these are political stability with a democratic elected government Economic stability and a well developed, domestic economy easily accessible to international companies A pro-business government who understands the development opportunities in finance, and other sectors of the economy An educated, efficient, and skilled labour force Predictable legal system, easily enforced Efficient public infrastructure, such as transport, schools, and healthcare Adequate technological capacity and country infrastructure From my vantage point where I manage fourteen countries where we have a physical presence for Citi, stretching from Bahamas to Ecuador, I would easily confirm that Trinidad & Tobago has most of the above and is one of the most attractive for investment in my region. Ladies and gentlemen, there is a simple fact that CAPITAL GOES WHERE IT IS WELCOMED AND REMAINS WHERE IT IS WELL TREATED. Within Citi, I compete for capital with the 110 countries we operate. Similarly all countries around the world are competing for capital and new investments so it is important that the Government and the private sector continue to play a key role in making Trinidad and Tobago competitively attractive. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/survey-confidence-falls-again-as-economy-takes-a-hit/article_8223ac8b-164a-5ee6-9366-f3d7fc4787c6.html", "TITLE": " Survey: Confidence falls again as economy takes a hit ", "DATE": "Dec 10, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " More than half of Caribbean respondents believe the global economic recovery is not on track according to the latest Global Economic Conditions Survey. Confidence in the global economy fell in Q3 2012 according to a worldwide survey of 2,500 finance professionals with 67 per cent of respondents now believing that the global economy is stagnating or reversing. Further analysis suggests that this latest fall in global confidence is due almost entirely to changing business fundamentals - such as demand, access to finance, prompt payment and inflation - as opposed to respondents' sentiment. Globally, the downturn is firmly focused on the real economy with small and medium sized enterprises being the worst hit. The 15th edition of the quarterly Global Economic Conditions Survey (GECS) undertaken by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Management Accountants (IMA), shows that for the Caribbeanonly 15 per cent of respondents reported confidence gains, against 40 per cent who reported losses. Just under a third (32 per cent) believed the global economic recovery was on track, while 62 per cent did not. Both measures of economic optimism were exactly in line with the average in non-OECD countries. Brenda Lee-Tang, head of ACCA Caribbean, said: \"The Caribbean has seen much instability, like the rest of the world, with economic conditions. But the islands have seen tourism boosts and growth in the oil and mining industries, which has seen government investment in the infrastructure of those countries. Being in close proximity to the US, this region is heavily influenced by the American economy and so to the effects of its sluggish recovery.\" One theme that emerges strongly from the survey is the interconnectedness of the global economy. Raef Lawson, IMA's vice president of research commented: \"The slowdown in Asia; the Eurozone debt crisis; and the sluggish US recovery all are feeding into each other and no region is unaffected. In fact, the degree to which movements in the GECs indices are synchronised between regions is uncanny.\" Survey editor Manos Schizas, senior economic analyst with ACCA said: \"This quarter has seen business confidence fall for all the right reasons. Around the world, and with few exceptions, the fundamentals of the business environment are deteriorating, and businesses are once again having the kinds of liquidity problems we thought we had put behind us.\" The Caribbean picture suggests that: Much of the tone for the third quarter in the region was set by the countries' relations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Jamaica was unable to reach an agreement with the Fund that would release IMF loans, which in turn led to a sharp reduction in government spending. The prolonged uncertainty leading up to this (including the delaying of the Budget) hit investor sentiment and business confidence hard, while wage freezes have had an effect on demand. Meanwhile, currency devaluation has driven up fuel prices in Jamaica, driving up fuel prices. Officials in Barbados spent much of the third quarter of 2012 denying that they were going to seek IMF support or devalue the dollar. Tourism and commodities, the region's main exports, have generally grown. According to respondents, tourism rose in Bermuda but fell in Barbados. Guyana's mining sector and Trinidad and Tobago's oil industry have been expanding and both governments have ploughed some of their proceeds into investments in infrastructure. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/challenge-for-the-business-class/article_ca7f0f7d-fb95-5319-a5b4-2491f2153509.html", "TITLE": " Challenge for the business class ", "DATE": "Oct 12, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Women\u0092s winner: Tonya Nero Women\u0092s winner: Tonya Nero Finance Minister Winston Dookeran is apparently aiming to prod the consciences of local business people and investors by suggesting that an aversion to risk could be one underlying cause of the economic stagnation now enveloping Trinidad and Tobago. Speaking last Tuesday at the post-Budget forum hosted by the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Mr Dookeran pointed out that the financial system now had excess liquidity, so funding for new ventures should not be an issue. He also asserted that the fiscal regime provided support for investment and that measures had been introduced to improve export and import facilities. On these bases, Mr Dookeran held that business persons should have confidence in the economy. Nonetheless, the private sector was not, he complained, stepping up to the challenge of economic regeneration. \"Is it really an excuse, the fact that we are a risk-averse people and we are prepared to live on the profits of yesterday without attempting to create new sustainability for tomorrow\" he asked. There is some irony in this query from the Finance Minister, given that he has just delivered a Budget in which several billion dollars have had to be committed to clearing up the mess caused by the excessive risks taken by persons linked to the CL Financial group. The difference there, however, was that the principal players in that fiasco were not risking their own money, but that of policyholders who, for the most part, were middle-income citizens with salaried jobs. Business persons are by nature risk-takers, but the degree of risk they are willing to stand depends to a great extent on guarantees provided by the State. Such guarantees range from physical security to property rights to rule of law. In this sense, the State must be held to its responsibility to facilitate business activity and competitiveness, and to preserve a favourable investment climate. Certainly, however, it's up to T&T's economic movers and shakers to explain why so much commercial credit remains unused in local banks, with opportunity costs incurring to growth, job creation, and even exports. Is it indeed fear of risk, as the Finance Minister claims Or is it lack of confidence in the apparatus of the State Is it concern that the T&T economy remains at the mercy of international financial trends Or is it a cultural barrier in which business persons cannot move from the merchant mindset to the entrepreneurial one Any or all of these factors may explain the inertia in the private sector. But it is the existence and application of the entrepreneurial spirit and a make-it-happen drive that will make the difference for T&Tand it's not clear that enough of this is making itself felt. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/route-to-self-sustaining-economy/article_41a4edc1-02f2-5fda-97c6-56b5b1653a8c.html", "TITLE": " Route to self-sustaining economy ", "DATE": "Sep 26, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "I am of the view that were it not for the addiction to freeness and a lack of fairplay\u2014features which unfortunately seem to be ingrained in much of our population\u2014the economy of Trinidad and Tobago, given the country's past wealth in human and financial resour\u00adces, should today be on a more self- reliant path. Therefore, it requires the Minister of Finance to send signals by addressing some definite imperatives in his budget statement on Friday. In general, when subsidies are being provided by the State to an entity, it tells us that services are being made available below cost. It may be that certain social considerations might dictate that this be done. However, apart from this, providing services below cost generates a ten\u00addency to encourage waste, a lack of competitive edge and a general lack of accountability. In this regard, Trini\u00addad and Tobago has been a happy haven for subsidies. The suggestions which are made herein are therefore confined to a few areas which impinge significantly on the failure of Trinidad and Tobago to have an economy that is more self-sustaining. Here are some: 1. The fuel subsidy The case for elimination of fuel subsidies has been discussed extensively and accepted generally and, therefore, the Minister of Finanace should continue the programme of reducing subsidies on fuel by a further reduction of, say, 25 per cent, thus leading to their complete elimination in four to five years. 2. State enterprises The definition of a State enterprise, even though it happens to be owned by the State, implies that such an entity should be business-oriented and from which a profit is, in normal circumstances, to be expected. Unfortunately, in Trinidad and Tobago, there has arisen a plethora of State-owned entities, many of which have been created for two main purposes: a) as tools for employment creation, and b) to fill gaps in the economy which, it was felt, were not being addressed properly by private enterprise. Unfortunately, many of these enti\u00adties have been making large demands on the public purse, with doubts being expressed as to whether the public interest demands their continuing exis- tence. Therefore, here is an area for serious consideration by the minister. 3. Utility and other service rates Utility rates have been stagnant for several years. Thus, water and sewerage rates have been unchanged since 1985, ie, over 30 years. What manner of management is this Here again, the Finance Minister should take the bull by the horns by addressing the matter of the mechanisms which have been put in place to ensure that \u201cthe cost of providing services to the public is being met by revenues collected\u201d. 4. Agriculture and agro-based industries This is one area where there ought to be an increase in subsidies. Pivotal must be action aimed at establishing viable agriculture-based industries, with the aim of employment creation and import substitution. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/dookeran-ministry-to-partner-with-youth-public-on-economy/article_4ff302cb-fff4-5af4-a689-670060183e67.html", "TITLE": " Dookeran: Ministry to partner with youth, public on economy ", "DATE": "Jun 12, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "The Ministry of Finance has already designed a new approach with the people called a \"dialogue process\", in charting a new budget for Trinidad and Tobago, Minister of Finance Winston Dookeran said yesterday. For the first time, too, the Ministry of Finance, also, will conduct a \"dialogue\" with young people to understand their points of view on the economy. Speaking at the launch of the Tunapuna Partnership Council (TPC), at which he was designated the \"chief servant\" of the executive council which will oversee the work of the TPC, Dookeran said the dialogue was the start of the process of deepening democracy in governance. Reiterating the National Treasury was empty, he said the \"people's energy\" derived from the dialogue process will go towards filling the Treasury. In the past, Dookeran said, the officers in the previous administration claimed they held consultation with the people but, in effect, they did not listen to them. At the end of the so-called consultation process, they designed the programmes without the input of the people. Due to the lack of consultation, the Finance Minister said he recommended they change the name to the \"dialogue process\" to engage in a genuine dialogue with the stakeholders business, labour, civil society, households and young people. Dookeran issued an invitation to young people throughout the country to take part in the sessions on the way forward for the economy with the Government. The dialogue, he said, was part of the change process but change does not come swiftly. \"Change comes by doing, and doing is what I am accustomed to do\", he declared. The dialogue process, he said, was one of the first priorities of the Government to build transparency in the governance structure, get rid of the broken politics of the past and embrace new politics. This process, he said, would aid in including those who would have been left out of the economic mainstream of society. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/fresh-ideas-needed-to-stimulate-economy/article_0b110a76-6366-5201-afd9-0cb3668e25f5.html", "TITLE": " Fresh ideas needed to stimulate economy ", "DATE": "Jul 12, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "T&T SPRINTER: Marc Burns T&T SPRINTER: Marc Burns By the end of fiscal 2009, this figure dropped to $9.7 billion. The latest decline as at June of this year showed that total cash balances had plummeted to $5.43 billion, a loss of $12.27 billion in only two years. The data is contained in a June 11 report by Finance Minister Winston Dookeran titled \"Report on the Nation's Business - the state of our finances and initiatives for future action\". The decline was primarily due to the \"generation of the fiscal deficits which began in 2008\", the report states. \"In simple terms, the government's balances in the Treasury declined substantially over the last two years as the previous administration sought to maintain its high expenditure levels in the face of drastically falling revenues,\" the Dookeran report noted. Over the 2009 fiscal year Trinidad and Tobago recorded its first deficit in seven years. This deficit amounted to $7.4 billion or 5.3 per cent of GDP as compared to a surplus of $12.1 billion of 7.8 per cent of GDP in fiscal 2008. The deficit was the direct result of declining oil prices which \"substantially trimmed\" government revenues without a concomitant decline in the level of spending by the previous administration, the report observed. \"A further overall deficit of $7.7 billion or 5.4 per cent of GDP is projected for this fiscal year. This trend towards fiscal deficits contributes significantly to the country's indebtedness and if it is not reversed urgently could result in the virtual mortgaging of several generations to come,\" the report warned. For the first time since the late 1980s, a recurrent fiscal deficit of $722 million has been projected for this fiscal year. \"This means that the country is now borrowing to finance recurrent expenditure which includes components such as wages and salaries, transfers and subsidies and interest payments,\" the report stated. \"If this situation is not curtailed, it poses tremendous downside risks for fiscal sustainability and debt management in the future. This is quite like borrowing to finance the government's capital programmes which create employment and generate economic activity.\" The Central Bank said recently that to finance the deficit, the former government increased its borrowings on the domestic capital market. Several public sector enterprises also increased their borrowings from the capital market as well as through loans from the banking system to finance an expansion in infrastructural investments, the Central Bank said in its recent Financial Stability Review. Low energy and petrochemical prices combined with a slackened export demand in the context of the global recession led to a fall in the value of total exports in the order of 50 per cent, the Bank said. The Dookeran report describes the current situation as \"challenging economic circumstances confronting policymakers in Trinidad and Tobago\". Dookeran suggests that in light of these challenges a new approach that will bring fresh ideas and new perspectives on how to respond to the current economic circumstances of the local economy is necessary. In this context his report has proposed the establishment of an Economic Development Board which will provide external and independent advisory inputs into the formulation of financial and economic policies to be pursued by government. The report also suggests that even as attention is focused on revitalising the economy, considerable effort must also be directed towards securing sustainable long term growth. Former People's National Movement (PNM) minister in the ministry of finance and former trade minister Mariano Browne said recently that the government borrowing level at 50 per cent of GDP while his party held office was well within acceptable international benchmarks which fall in the 50-60 per cent range and could be compared favourably with regional and other international economies at this time. For the record, the world has been in the grip of a recession occasioned by a financial crisis which originated in the world's largest economy, the USA. As a result of this international financial crisis, governments everywhere have attempted to reflate their economies by the use of deficit financing. This is a well accepted macro economic technique and agreed to by various international agencies (the IMF for example) who were consulted (by the TT government) prior to the adoption of this specific strategy, he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/why-consult-with-finance-minister/article_f13f4c1f-18f9-597c-aadc-c4033f014dbf.html", "TITLE": " Why consult with finance minister ", "DATE": "Dec 8, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "The recent tiff among key players in our financial/economic institutions\u2014Finance Minister, Central Bank Governor, Bankers' Association of T&T, etc\u2014underscores the inherent ills of politics in this country and the need for Constitution reform to facilitate greater autonomy for institutions such as the Central Bank and the Office of the Attorney General, etc. Traditionally, the Central Bank Governor, given his/her strategic and pivotal role, has always disseminated crucial information on the economy to the public. This current regime assumed office with the assurance that the nation's business will be conducted with more transparency and less corruptly than any previous administration. Why then was it necessary for the Central Bank Governor\u2014presumably an \u201cindependent\u201d official\u2014to consult with the Finance Minister before issuing statements to the public One can only assume the Finance Minister wanted the opportunity to manipulate the information to suit political expediency. And what's wrong with the Central Bank Governor's disclosure regarding the allocation of US dollars Was there something to hide Was there political interference to favour one business over another The resources of this country belong to the people and we have a right to know. Besides, secrecy breeds and suggests corruption. Recent statements by the Finance Minister served not only to undermine the Government's initial stance regarding the economy, but has sent mixed signals to the population. To a large degree, the citizenry had implicitly accepted the Government's rationale that, like the rest of the world, our economy had contracted and some degree of austerity measures was necessary. Among the measures were salary cuts at State enterprises starting with the National Gas Company. Surprisingly, the trade unions did not rant and rave. They too have seemingly accepted the Government's position. By formally declaring the country is in recession mode, the Central Bank Governor has authenticated the Government's stated position on the economy. And too, exponentially increasing the borrowing limit by $50 billion does little to convince the population of the grim reality of our economic climate. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-economy-is-robust/article_0cbf939b-b09d-5372-ac20-ada85e3a3c84.html", "TITLE": " The economy is robust ", "DATE": "Jul 14, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Minister of Finance Larry Howai Minister of Finance Larry Howai Minister of Finance Larry Howai recently reviewed the state of the economy in a presentation to Parliament. It formed part of his request for approval of Government expenditure supplemental to the 2014 National Budget. Howai explained that when he first presented the 2014 Budget last year, he had announced total expenditure of $61,397.9 million and Revenue of $55,040.8 million, resulting in an overall projected deficit of $6,357.1million or 3.6 per cent of GDP. In his presentation of the Supplementation and Variation of Appropriation Bill recently, Minister Howai revealed that despite the projected increase in Expenditure by $3,820.6 million, there is also a projected increase in Revenue of $4,525.5 million that will in fact result in a significant decrease in the projected deficit. The projected net savings amounts to $500 million more that had been anticipated in September 2013. Saying that the economy was robust, Howai cited similar projections by Moodys Investor Services forecast of 2.9 per cent growth of the economy as well as the forecast by the International Monetary Fundof 2.5 per cent growth in the economy of Trinidad and Tobago. Minister Howai quoted figures to show that the non-energy sector had grown approximately 2.5 per cent on average over the last six quarters and as a result of the initiatives which the government is putting in place, the country can expect this growth to actually accelerate towards the end of 2014. Pointing to figures received from the Ministry of Planning and Sustainable Development which show unemployment at 3.7 per cent,Howai noted that this was the lowest in the countrys history. He also spoke of the over 13,000 new businesses registered in 2013 as a sure sign of growth and confidence in the local economy. Howai added that Investor confidence is high both locally and internationally, with Trinidad and Tobago ranked sixth in Latin American and the Caribbean to receive Foreign Direct Investments for 2012. While overall foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows to Central America and the Caribbean fell by 17 per cent in 2012 compared to 2011, Foreign Direct Investments coming into T&T grew by 38 per cent over the same period, according to figures from the World Investment Report 2013 released by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). The total FDI flowing into T&T in 2012 was US$2.527 billion, the highest since 2008 when RBC of Canada re-acquired RBTT for US$2.2 billion. FDI flows into T&T in 2011 totalled US$1.831 billion. It was US$549 million in 2010 and US$709 million in 2009. The pre-crisis annual average for T&T was US$884 million between 2005 and 2007 (Source: UNCTAD). He said: Headline inflation continues to trend downward. The latest figure for April showed inflation at 3.5 per cent and core inflation which excludes food prices decelerating to two per cent at the end of last year. Food inflation, which dipped to an annual low of three per cent in September last year, was the main impetus behind the reduction in the rate of growth of headline inflation. The countrys balance of payments continue to be healthy, registering a surplus of US$226.8 million for the first nine months of the year, and it is estimated to have closed the year with an even larger surplus of $786.3 million for 2013. As a result, gross international reserves have climbed to over US$10 billion equivalent to 12 months import cover. He presented these facts and figures on the economy as a precursor to his Finance Supplementation and Variation of Appropriation Bill 2014. The Bill brought Governments request for additional funds in the sum of $3,820,601,879 to fund urgent and critical expenditure to September 30, 2014 to the House for approval. Of this figure some $1.02 billion goes towards the payments of salaries, NIS COLA, allowances, stipend, travelling, subsistence and arrears for Public Servants. This includes the settlement of the Collective Agreement for over 20,000 Daily Paid Workers. $1.6 billion is scheduled to go towards Infrastructure Development including such major improvement projects as the Diego Martin and Point Fortin Highways to bring relief to hundreds of thousands of commuters in north and south Trinidad, it was stated. Our economy is slowly grinding to a halt and we need your intervention to change this trajectory. Let's examine the facts everyone said after the budget was passed in 2010, and again in 2011, things would start moving again. Even the IMF advisers approved a US$1.3 billion loan for Winston Dookeran to spend on projects to get the economy moving. Did anyone see any new projects other than the South highway start in 2011 Toward the last quarter of 2011, we had both the president of the Chamber of Commerce and the president of the Manufacturers Association complaining about the lack of stimulation of the economy. We keep hearing the mantra from the Finance Minister that we have no funds available for this, but why did the Central Bank Governor ask how come the Current Account showed a surplus $2 billion instead of the $7 billion deficit we were supposed to be posting The implication was: there were funds to invest in capital projects, which was not done! Even Mr Dookeran embarrassingly admitted in Parliament in January that he indeed had a $2 billion surplus... the Central Bank Governor was right. The brutal fact is we had negative growth in 2011... guess who got screwed Ask the 25,000 construction workers who lost their jobs during this period. Here we are in 2012, once again the budget was approved, with even an addendum of a further $3 billion tacked on... will this be dj-vu Already a no-confidence motion was brought up in Parliament, with a major part of the reason being the weakness of our economy. To make matters worse, ask some of the 200 contractors who have had their vehicles and businesses re-possessed due to Education Facilities Co Ltd (EFCL)'s non-payment of their invoices (valued roughly at $170 million) for work done, but not paid for. Don't forget the ripple effect this has on the construction employees and their families, hardwares and others who these contractors have not been able to pay. Madame Prime Minister, the fastest way to stimulate any economy is via construction. You should chair the Project Implementation Committee, where meetings are held on a weekly basis, to fast-track these projects. Alternatively, I would re-assign Mr Dookeran to another ministry and appoint Vasant Barath Finance Minister. This man knows how to get things done. My comments here are not meant to embarrass anyone, but are made out love for my country and with a genuine concern to help get our country back on a vibrant development path once again. If nothing is changed, we will end up with negative growth once again, with all the unnecessary human suffering and tragedy which goes hand-in-hand with non-action. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ailing-economy-needs-govt-boost/article_b50c8801-7c62-54d5-9f9a-bdec145c9b39.html", "TITLE": " Ailing economy needs Govt boost ", "DATE": "Sep 5, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "ONE year has passed since the People's National Movement (PNM) led by Dr Keith Rowley assumed the seat of government. The Express sought the opinions several stakeholders in South and Central on the Government's performance so far. Some complained, others praised. But they all agreed on one thing. Much more work needed to be done. Richie Sookhai: 7/10 President of the Chaguanas Chamber of Industry and Commerce (CCIC), Richie Sookhai, said the Chamber was grateful for positive changes in Chaguanas, including having the Ministry of Agriculture's head office there instead of Port of Spain. But there were several concerns. He said: \u201cThe CCIC remains concerned over the abrupt and unannounced drawing down of funds from the Heritage and Stabilisation Fund and the failure, so far, of the Government to produce other promised financing to deal with our growing debt. The CCIC also remains concerned about the difficulties faced by small businesses with the changes in VAT.\u201d \u201cIt is our hope that the budget plans for the 2017 financial year will reflect better incentives for the growth and scope of business so that our stagnating economy can finally get the kick-start that it desperately needs from the Government. \u201cCrime continues to plague our nation. In Chaguanas we are hoping that Government will finally make the urgent decision to introduce the wide use of CCTV (closed- circuit television) cameras in the borough and ensure that they are connected to the national grid so that we can have some level of monitoring and control.\u201d There should be at least one E-teck park in Chaguanas in order to stimulate economic growth. His grade for the Government out of ten (one being the lowest and ten the highest): seven. Joseph Rahael: 5/10 Developer for South Park shopping centre Joseph Rahael said Government has not yet done anything outstanding and much more needs to be done in order to boost the economy. He said: \u201cOne of the things they (Government) ought to be focusing on is making life easier for the private sector to continue doing what we do, which is positive contributions to the economy and the society through our business, our commerce.\u201d Measures should be in place to make business transactions and processes more efficient \u201cso that the private sector can rely on these agencies for better output and better productivity,\u201d he said. The Government got a grade five from him. Rahael added: \u201cClearly they have been doing what they can do to keep the country going with very limited resources because of what is happening in the oil and gas sector. I will give them a fair grade for that but they could be doing a lot more. They need to push a lot harder on the diversification away from the oil and gas and make life easier for the business people and for commercial people to do those things, to do the diversification.\u201d Shiva Roopnarine: 5/10 President of the Penal/Debe Chamber of Commerce Shiva Roopnarine said: \u201cThe inheritance of an empty treasury and low revenues in oil and gas should not be an excuse for the shortage of medication on CDAP along with other essential commodities in the health sector. The chamber can support the completion of the much-anticipated Tarouba Stadium, but not at the expense of the health of the nation. The Government needs to urgently prioritise expenditure in the interest of the country\u201d. Roopnarine gave the Government five out of ten. He said: \u201cThis fear that is permeating our land needs to cease and can only happen with a meaningful reduction in crime, a concerted effort in prosecuting criminals and a reduction in legal red tape bugging the judicial system. As the Dr Keith Rowley-led administration approaches its first anniversary in office, the chamber along with the nation continues to await the implementation of proposed policies.\u201d In Debe, several key projects, including the Debe segment of the extension of the Solomon Hochoy Highway to Point Fortin, were still incomplete and contractors not being paid for work done continues to have a crippling ripple effect on the businesses. Unemployment is higher than before and underemployment is very de-motivating to young and aspiring graduates, Roopnarine added. He is hoping to see conservative estimates for oil and gas in the upcoming budget. And more emphasis needed to be placed on agriculture, he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/new-bank-of-brics-whats-in-it-for-small-economies/article_c90262cd-5254-51bb-8731-382bed96be03.html", "TITLE": " New bank of BRICS: whats in it for small economies ", "DATE": "Jul 20, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "It is news that should awaken the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) from their complacent attitude toward developing countries. It is also news that should confirm to the G20 that what used to be the G7\u2014 a group of the seven industrialised nations\u2014no longer controls the world's financial affairs. On July 15 Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa (BRICS) established the New Development Bank (NDB) and alongside it a Contingent Reserve Arrangement (CRA). The two institutions will serve the needs of the five countries for financing infrastructure and industrialisation, and to provide support in the event of a balance of payments crisis. The NDB will be headquartered in Shanghai, with India as its President for the first term of six years. It will be capitalised initially with US$50 billion. Each BRICS member state will subscribe an equal share. The CRA will be funded with US$100 billion. China is contributing the largest share of about US$41 billion while Russia, Brazil and India will put in US$18 billion each and South Africa US$5 billion. The creation of the NDB and the CRA is motivated by frustration with the pace of reform of the IMF and the World Bank to give a greater voice to the BRICS. In the Fortaleza Declaration after their meeting in Brazil, the five BRICS leaders stated that international governance under its current structure and power configuration show increasing signs of losing legitimacy and effectiveness. They said \"the BRICS are an important force for incremental change and reform of current institutions toward more representative and equitable governance capable of generating more inclusive global growth\". The BRICS are also concerned that the new vision for global economic governance, articulated by the G20 in 2009, has not materialised. It will also be at least two years before the NDB becomes fully operational, and the parliaments of the five countries are still to ratify the bank and the CRA\u2014certainly in India, this will be a contentious process. Whether the NDB and the CRA remain open only to the BRICS or they widen their lending to all other developing countries, their establishment signals that it cannot be business as usual for the World Bank and the IMF, and that decision-making in the G20 will have to change rapidly. BRICS represent 42 per cent of the world's population and roughly 20 per cent of the world's economy based on GDP. Total trade between them is US$6.14 trillion, or nearly 17 per cent of the world's total. Importantly, together they are the world's largest market and their combined GDP grew by more than 300 per cent in the last ten years. Those are not figures to be scoffed-at, and the BRICS have now shown that they are serious about demanding change. Other developing countries, including those in 15-nation Caricom, should applaud the BRICS for creating their two new institutions. They have all endured the harsh terms, rigid conditionalities and unyielding dictates of the IMF and the World Bank. They would welcome any move that rattles the Washington-based institutions, which are controlled by the US and Europe, and encourages them to reform and to be more flexible in the treatment of developing countries that are confronted with crises. The NDB could be a much needed source of financing to developing countries for infrastructure, industrialization and productive development that many nations, such as those in the Caribbean Community (Caricom), are now denied. Except for Haiti, Caricom countries (13 of them) have been \"graduated'' from access to concessional financing by the World Bank. The CRA could also allow developing economies to draw on pooled reserves in the event of balance of payments crises on terms that are more appropriate and more sympathetic than those now applied by the IMF. Risk management, a high-quality loan portfolio that improves development but keeps default to a minimum, surveillance and profits are all crucial to any bank's successes, and they will be vital to the NDB's survival\u2014so standards will have to be high. But within those important parameters the BRICS should devise ways in which they could allow other developing countries, particularly small and medium-sized ones, to buy into the NDB and the CRA on terms they can afford. Arrangements should also be made for borrowings by developing countries on less onerous and more sympathetic conditions than the requirements of the IMF and World Bank.
