{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/new-frontier-for-financing/article_9d20331c-8e11-58d1-93b2-6431cb64761d.html", "TITLE": " New Frontier for Financing ", "DATE": "Apr 7, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Christopher Columbus is best remembered as the man who discovered the Caribbean. While his maritime exploits are well highlighted in the pages of history, he is less considered for what was probably a more remarkable featconvincing Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand of Spain to fund his fanciful start-up venture of trying to find a westward route to the Far East. It perhaps seems an odd analogy, but it is one Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambarran used to great effect to highlight the role of venture capital funding in supporting innovative ideas that despite the great inherent risks, can produce even greater returns for the investor. For a region discovered some 525 years ago thanks to venture capital financing, the Caribbean has failed to develop a vibrant and indigenous venture capital industry, Rambarran said in his address at the Caribbean Centre for Money and Finances seminar on Venture Capital Financing last Friday at the Hyatt Regency (Trinidad), Port of Spain. The regional venture capital landscape is, at best, in an embryonic stage, Rambarran said, and in Caribbean economies, venture capital fundraising (as a per cent of gross domestic product or GDP) is negligible, or at zero. Several venture capital funds have closed since 2008. In Trinidad and Tobago, the venture capital industry has collapsed, and most venture capital investment, even when finally deployed, has financed start-ups of small to medium enterprises without any discernable positive economic impact, he said. The global environment that is likely to be less favourable than in the recent past because of tighter financing conditions as well as slower growth in some advanced economies and major emerging markets. Caribbean policymakers, in their search for new sources of development finance, are rekindling their interest in venture capital to help spur innovation, create jobs and support economic growth, he said. And thats where Columbus comes in. Rabarran said: Think about it. Christopher Columbus created a model for the modern Caribbean entrepreneur to follow. He spent seven years pitching his business plan to Genoese bankers (the worlds first angel networks) before convincing Ferdinand and Isabella (institutional investors at heart, if not in name) to fund his risky start-up venture in 1492. His business plan called for using three ships to discover a faster sea route to India and China by sailing west into the Atlantic. He persuaded Ferdinand and Isabella that a new route to Asia would disrupt Portugals monopoly on Asian exploration and give Spain vast riches such as silk, spices, gold and precious stones. He also convinced the royals that a new sea route would give Spain the glory of a new discovery, expand the Spanish Empire and propagate the spread of Christianity. Columbus, the explorer and adventurer, had no spectacular track record nor demonstrated any remarkable abilities as a mariner but he did invest some of his own resources into the venture. Like all entrepreneurs, Columbus miscalculated the risks of his westward voyage. Many things could have gone wrong that would prevent Columbus from returning to Spain: getting lost, starving, shipwreck and mutiny. At the same time, all Ferdinand and Isabella risked was investment capital but couldand ultimately did benefit from the upside potential. Their risky venture paid off handsomely, and the mineral wealth extracted from the New World laid the foundation for Spains domination of Europe for the next century. The world is not so different today than 525 years ago, Rambarran continued. Financing entrepreneurial ventures has changed little over the centuries. Today, we know that venture capital involves long term investments in risky, young companies, often with unproven management teams addressing new technologies in uncertain markets. Yet the innovation that occurs in these small companies is an important force in moving a country into the knowledge economy, he said. In this regard, Caribbean governments have an important but carefully balanced role to play in creating a healthy ecosystem in which venture capital can truly thrive. He suggested three key lessons upon which Caribbean policymakers could base their economic transformation agenda. Borrowing from Babson College Professor of Management Practice Daniel Isenbergs June 2010 article in the Harvard Business Review, Rambarran said the first thing is to stop attempting to replicate Silicon Valley in California, USAthe internationally renowned hotbed of technology innovation. Silicon Valley could not even replicate itself today if it tried. Its ecosystem evolved from the convergence of a unique set of circumstances: a large pool of skilled engineers and scientists from major universities in the area; the laid-back but driven for speed California culture; generous funding from a strong aerospace market with the Defence Department; development of an efficient network of venture capital firms; the institutional leadership of Stanford University; and pure luck, among other things, he said. He noted the governments failed attempt to create its own Silicon Valley in 2008, investing an estimated US$150 million in the Caribbeans first Science and Technology Park the Tamana InTech Park. The principal purpose of the Tamana InTech Park was to drive economic diversification in Trinidad and Tobago through the establishment of technology intensive, knowledge-driven industries in the non-energy sectors. The Park would be home to major technology players and the place where ground-breaking and innovative ideas would emerge. One of the Parks largest tenants, The University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT), would provide the necessary synergy between industry and academia in bringing emerging technologies to market. Unfortunately, despite several expressions of interest, Tamana InTech Park has yet to sign one tenant, he said. This brings me to my second lesson. Trinidad and Tobagos experience with Tamana InTech Park shows that governments cannot build ecosystems alone. Governments should engage the private sector, ideally from the start, and let it keep or acquire a significant stake in the ecosystems success. The government can directly approach technology investment firms and technology researchers to determine what they need to develop a world-class industry. If the private investor then offers to match say half of the funds, ambitions would be tempered and targeted to meet the specific needs of the market. Furthermore, requiring matching funds not only ensures the private sector is willing to risk its own money but also tests the potential of the technology or investment firm, he said. Thirdly, Rambarran suggested that small, open Caribbean economies need to favour scale-up rather than start-up ventures. Since small size is the major constraint to economic growth in the Caribbean, there is a compelling argument for policymakers to stop treating the quantity of start-ups as an indicator of success and to start looking at the quality of those start-ups that grow and eventually scale-up. One high-potential venture which grows to 100 people in five years will create the same number of jobs as 50 bottom-of-the-pyramid ventures which stagnate at two people, he said. Contrary to popular opinion, high-potential is not always synonymous with high-tech, Rambarran said, and it is not the surest path to competitiveness and prosperity. In fact, Caribbean economies may get more development bang for the buck by supporting low tech sectors like food processing and forestry than by trying to develop a few high-tech niche products and industries. In Trinidad and Tobago, for example, the agricultural sector offers many high-potential, low-tech, foreign exchange generating business opportunities such as cocoa, pineapple, tilapia and coconut, waiting to be fully exploited by private investors, he said. Five centuries later, it is time for the Caribbean to continue the venture capital voyage started by the master entrepreneur, Columbus, he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/payouts-won-t-help-economy/article_ed870787-ec84-56dd-b0e5-05bef0823251.html", "TITLE": " Payouts won't help economy ", "DATE": "Dec 24, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "SIMPLY doling out money to contractors, CLICO policyholders and anyone else with an IOU from the Government will not magically bump up confidence in the local economy, Minister in the Ministry of Finance, Dr Patrick Watson, said last Thursday. Watson said that energising the economy and luring more investment is not going to be as simple as a few payouts as global financial conditions and the economies of Caribbean neighbours dependent on tourist dollars would still be factors out of the control of the Trinidad and Tobago Government. Last Monday, Central Bank Governor, Ewart Williams, joined those calling for greater efforts by the Government to revive investor and consumer confidence in the local economy. \"I don't think confidence is something restricted to local conditions or to paying off these debts. It is related to all kinds of things,\" Watson said in a telephone interview. \"It sort of poses the question of what came first, the chicken or the egg. The business community as a whole is responding to things both local and international.\" Watson pointed out that the majority of goods manufactured locally are exported, particularly within the Caribbean. Most Caribbean countries who consume these goods also rely heavily on tourism, which is currently mild at best, coming out of the United States and Europe, he said. (See Pages 8&9) And even restoring confidence in the local economy, he said, will not boost local manufacturing if there is no one to consume the goods. \"If the region is not prepared to receive the goods, then local manufacturers will not be able to produce more,\" Watson said. He said the Government was in no way trying to avoid the issues facing the local economy nor was he denying the part played by factors such as debt resolution, in restoring a robust economy. \"I'm saying that people are not going to rush because of some magic wand,\" he insisted. \"I'm not saying that some local conditions to do not contribute to a lack of confidence and I am not running away from the challenge of trying to restore confidence but confidence will not be reinstated precisely from these issues. The thing is quite complicated.\" Watson said he felt that a series of incentives would be a better start towards getting the economy moving than simply paying off CLICO policyholders, which he called \"an intractable matter\" and \"one of the worse that anyone could contend with\". The construction of the proposed highway through Point Fortin, he said, would also be a strong stimulus that he felt would prod a certain amount of local spending. \"But that is not going to help the economy of Antigua,\" he said. \"Their mainstay is tourism and until that sector recovers, they are not going to buy our manufactured goods.\" Watson said the Government was committed to resolving its debts. \"If it is one thing that is happening in the Ministry of Finance, the ministry is taking the bull by the horns and dealing with it,\" he said. Referring to the CLICO issue, Watson said: \"You have a group of people who were promised by a government that they would get back every cent and continue to enjoy the interest rates they previously enjoyed. These are matters not easily dealt with and no matter what you do, someone will always be upset.\" Some of the resolutions would run late and this too will not serve to restore confidence in the economy, he said. \"Are you saying that if we solve the CLICO problem tomorrow that businesses will start to produce It's not that simple,\" Watson stressed. \"True, it is part of the formula but I cannot imagine that anything could be so facile as that.\" Watson also suggested that the CLICO matter may never be fully resolved, adding: \"The only way to stem the anger of the CLICO people is to give all of them back every cent and that would put this economy into a tailspin you cannot imagine. We are paying off a certain amount now and from then on, every year we are committed to finding half a billion dollars. \"Even that is risky. God knows what could happen next year and whether we will be able to find that half a billion dollars.\" Finance Minister Winston Dookeran had, in November of this year, said the Government was moving towards a Christmas payout to policyholders of a lump sum of $75,000, the amount announced in the September budget. That payout did not come to fruition and Dookeran said last Saturday he was looking instead to a payout next month. Commenting on the delay, Watson said \"every gear\" in the Ministry of Finance has been engaged in resolving the CLICO matter and the delay is not an indication that the State will back away from its promise. \"Every claim has to be processed, verified, a system has to be worked. There will be delays,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/why-america-will-power-world-economy-in/article_ffb5554a-5790-5ada-867c-bca211d4ad7a.html", "TITLE": " Why America will power world economy in 2015 ", "DATE": "Jan 5, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "The United States is back, and ready to drive global growth in 2015. After long struggling to claw its way out of the Great Recession, the worlds biggest economy is on an extended win streak that is edging it closer to full health. But the new year doesnt look quite so bright in other major countries. China is slowing as it transitions from investment to consumption. Japan has slid into a recession. Russia appears headed for one. Europe is barely growing. And the US Six years after its financial system nearly sank and nearly that long since the recession ended, the United States is expected to grow in 2015 at its fastest pace in a decade. Its expansion from July through September a five per cent annual rate was the swiftest for any quarter since 2003. That pace will likely ease a bit. Still, the economy is expected to expand 3.1 per cent this year, according to a survey by the National Association for Business Economics. It would be the first year of three per cent growth since 2005. The acceleration of US growth is a key reason the global economy is also expected to grow faster, at about three per cent, up from 2.5 per cent in 2014, according to economists at JPMorgan Chase and IHS Global Insight. CHEERING CHEAPER OIL Plunging oil prices are a big reason for the optimism. Prices have been cut roughly in half since last summer. In some areas of the country, gasoline prices have slipped below US$2 a gallon. The drop, along with more fuel-efficient cars, will save the average US household US$550 on gas this year, according to the US Energy Information Administration. That means consumers have more to spend on items like cars, furniture and appliances. Whats more, Americans finances are in firmer shape. Job growth is accelerating. Businesses are investing in buildings and software, and home building is expected to pick up. Lower oil prices will also help Europe and Japan, and the global economy should expand faster than it did last year, economists say. But the divergence between the United States and most of the rest of the world is striking and carries some risks. Big exporters, from China to Germany to Japan, will depend heavily on a recovering US to boost their economies. A pick-up in global growth is highly dependent on the assumption that the US economy continues to improve, said Douglas Porter, chief economist at BMO Capital Markets. If that doesnt play out, theres not much left for the global economy to fall back on. SWIRLING GLOBAL HEADWINDS Even if the US economy does strengthen further, the rest of the world could struggle. For one thing, faster growth will likely lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in 2015, which could draw more investment from overseas. The inflow of capital would raise the dollars value and potentially cause destabilising drops in other currencies. Governments and businesses overseas that borrowed in dollars would find it harder to repay those debts. The hot economies of the last decade the emerging markets of Brazil, Russia, India and China collectively known as the BRICs will likely grow in 2015 at their slowest pace in six years, according to Oxford Economics, a forecasting firm. Falling oil and commodity prices have smacked Brazil and Russia particularly hard. China may expand 6.5 per cent or more. Yet thats a far cry from the nearly double-digit growth it enjoyed for decades. Europe and Japan will be lucky to expand even one per cent. The gap between the US and the rest of the world reflects a fundamental trait of the US economy: Its more insulated from the rest of the worlds ups and downs than other major economies are. Exports account for just 14 per cent of US output, the smallest share among the 34 mostly rich members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. One US company largely protected from overseas trends is Globe Specialty Metals, a Miami-based producer of silicon metals that draws 90 per cent of its revenue from North America. Its silicon is added to aluminium and rubber parts used in cars, and robust auto sales have boosted the companys revenue. CEO Jeff Bradley says hes optimistic about 2015. As gas prices have sunk, Americans have been buying more SUVs and pick-ups, which use more aluminium. Demand for solar power panels is also lifting sales. Things are lining up for next year to be one of the best years in the history of our company, Bradley said. POWERING CONSUMERS In the United States, consumers are the main drivers of growth. And fortunes are looking up for more households. Employers were on track to add the most jobs in 15 years in 2014. As a percentage of income, Americans debt has dropped to 2002 levels. In some ways, the US economy actually benefits from slower growth abroad. Investors in search of safety have plowed money into Treasurys, thereby helping hold down inflation and US loan rates, including for mortgages. Lower rates, in turn, could fuel more home sales and construction next year. Stan Humphries, chief economist at Zillow, thinks Americans ages 25 to 34, stung by higher rents, will buy homes in greater numbers by the end of 2015. Mortgage giants Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae have relaxed their down payment requirements, which were a strain for younger would-be buyers. Humphries also thinks developers will build more lower-priced homes that millennials can afford. Some signs of hope overseas have emerged. Falling oil prices should benefit people in Europe, Japan and China, all of which import oil. And analysts expect the European Central Bank to ramp up its stimulus efforts, possibly by buying government bonds. That step would inject more cash into the economy to boost lending and keep rates low. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/global-economy-grows-in-st-quarter/article_22d965a9-e1e9-52cd-94a0-9919caf6a269.html", "TITLE": " Global economy grows in 1st quarter ", "DATE": "Apr 30, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "GAVE WITNESS STATEMENT: Lawrence Duprey GAVE WITNESS STATEMENT: Lawrence Duprey The latest edition of the Global Economic Conditions Survey, conducted by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Management Accountants (IMA) suggests that the global economy recovered substantially in early 2012 and regained some of the dynamism it had lost over the last year. The survey findings, representing the views of about 2,200 professional accountants around the world, were welcomed by the two professional bodies: the share of respondents reporting confidence gains in their own organisations had nearly doubled from 16 per cent in late 2011 to 29 per cent and while the majority (54 per cent) still believed the global economy was deteriorating or stagnating, that figure was down from 73 per cent in the previous quarter. Brenda Lee-Tang, head of ACCA Caribbean said in a statement of the latest findings: \"Business confidence in the Caribbean does not appear to have risen in early 2012, with the region underperforming the rest of the Americas. But the biggest winner in relative terms has been Jamaica, where confidence grew more than anywhere else in the region. The Bahamas, on the other hand, has underperformed compared to the rest of the region amidst pre-election uncertainty, ending 2011 with lower confidence levels and additionally gaining less confidence than other Caribbean countries in the first months of 2012. Although the employment outlook and general business conditions across the region appear to have improved, businesses are still under a lot of pressure and respondents have cited fewer new value-added business opportunities.\" Emmanouil Schizas, editor of the ACCA/IMA Global Economic Conditions Survey, said of the global findings: \"When all the results came in, we were a little sceptical and had to consider all of the likely objections first. Much of the rise in confidence is being reversed as we speak, as the relief factor subsides, but a lot of it is here to stay.\" ACCA and IMA attribute much of the rise in global business confidence to objective improvements to the business environment, especially new orders, but also warn that relief is an important driver in the short term - especially due to the fact that a number of nightmare scenarios that had seemed likely in late 2011, such as an escalation of the European sovereign debt crisis or a hard landing in China, appeared more remote in the last quarter. There also appears to be a renewed faith in the prospects of the global economy and the strength of the recovery. These developments were also reflected in rising business investment and employment. Confidence gains were fairly consistent across regions and industries, although the Americas and Western Europe seemed to benefit the most in early 2012, as did manufacturers and distributors, particularly in the high-tech sectors. The survey reported increasing business dynamism, mostly in the Americas and Asia-Pacific, with businesses securing new orders where previously they would not have and responding with increased investment and hiring. ACCA and IMA welcomed this development, noting that investment has been subdued at the global level since the end of the 'green shoots' stage of the global recovery which lasted from mid-2009 to mid-2010. Africa is still the most confident of the seven major regions covered by the survey, but it is clearly losing ground. \"ACCA and IMA believe that the bounce in investment is focusing on two kinds of opportunities in particular. Customer insights, namely the need to understand and benefit from spending decisions under new constraints, is one; the other is supply chain optimisation through deepening relationships and a stronger focus on quality.\" The professional bodies also acknowledge the contribution of governments in their major markets, many of which showed signs of loosening their fiscal policies to boost a flagging recovery. It is not clear how much longer they can afford to do so, as respondents generally continue to believe that many major economies, including both the US and China, are likely to spend unsustainably in the medium term. On the other hand, finance professionals in Western Europe and other countries experiencing austerity also doubted the sustainability of their own governments' fiscal policies. Emmanouil Schizas said: \"It's too early to say whether the pattern of the modest recovery in 2012 is sustainable, but it seems to rely on a sustained recovery of demand in the West, supply in the East and confidence in sovereigns. It's a precarious balance.\" Finally, ACCA and IMA noted that the global economy's new-found dynamism has come at the price of rising input prices, and note that if even a timid recovery is accompanied by rising inflation, then a full-blown recovery, if and when it occurs, is likely to provide a challenge for central banks and other policymakers. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/innovation-best-way-to-diversify-economy/article_c842dd63-75b2-55eb-b1f7-2ac8c6fb0c7f.html", "TITLE": " Innovation best way to diversify economy ", "DATE": "Jul 8, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The Central Bank governor has now joined the refrain that we need to diversify our economy from its dependence on our depleting energy resources. So much so that he wondered why governments have been so hesitant to recognise that the energy sector will not be able to sustain our economy for much longer. Further, the governor warns, with the sustained low prices of natural gasthough the price of oil is relatively high, our production is droppingat this stage, the energy sector can only support the economy at a reduced level. The Minister of Planning, in his presentation at the Fourth Biennial Conference on Business, Banking and Finance, also recognised that we need to diversify the economy as he compared our overall performance in the 2010-2011 Global Competitive Index, in which we stood at number 84, as compared with Barbados at 46, Costa Rica at 56 and Chile at 30. What this overall position for T&T hid is that in the category of innovation, we were second to last out of 139 countries. This is a critical condemnation of our economy since in today's world, innovation is the key to competitiveness in the export and local markets. He blamed our poor showing, for example, on the mismatch between our education system and the labour market, the reluctance of people coming out of our tertiary education system to start businesses, instead of looking for a job. Hence, according to the minister, we need to transform the economy and get into services and knowledgethings that use human talentand move into things that employ natural assets, beyond oil and gas. He also saw Government's role as improving the business environment, making it business-friendly not standing in the way of people who want to do business. And this role has to include building a quality education and training system that fits with the economy because it produces the talent pool that the private and public sectors draw from. Yet T&T is the largest exporter of its trained personnel in the region, and even the Planning Minister admits, at the moment, 25 per cent of our university graduates are under-employed, implying the present private and public sectors have no need for such skills skills that were readily employable abroad. The minister concludes that efficiency is what makes companies competitive, and they are productive when you have a good match between skills of the people, their technical level and the companies that are producing at a level of effectiveness since these are the minimum standards required worldwide. Gregory McGuire, in the July 2011 T&T Review, also recognised the need to diversify the economy and questioned the Planning Minister on how he intends to proceed continue to implement the non-policy Vision 2020, or follow the lead of his predecessor or even create his own policy direction The economic model as it exists in T&T cannot conceive the required diversification, and this is evident since governments, academia, business, etc, have been talking about economic diversification for at least the past thirty years. The current economy has certain systemic failures, characteristics that prevent its evolution into a globally competitive export economy, outside of the energy sector, which itself is a contributory factor to the onshore systemic failures. Hence, many of the minister's comments are pure rhetoric. The required economic development today demands certain key activities. These include: the provision of knowledge inputs to an innovative production process, via the encouragement of R&D (research and development); the building of a related human resource in innovation and R&D activities; and the identification of new product markets. The critical requirement is the provision of an innovation system that creates and modifies organisations needed to develop new fields of R&D and innovation; the building of networks through marketing and interactive learning among the different innovative organisations; provision of R&D investment; and removing obstacles to innovation. A cursory examination of our economy will demonstrate that even the embryo of such a system does not exist in our economyon or offshore. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/survey-small-businesses-stronger/article_6e24e0d7-8107-5555-b099-ee337f271792.html", "TITLE": " Survey: Small businesses stronger ", "DATE": "Dec 27, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "A worrying number of small businesses believe they do not have enough cash reserves to survive another economic downturn, a study by Forbes Insights in association with ACCA (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants), Certified General Accountants Association of Canada (CGA-Canada) and CNDCEC, the professional body for certified accountants in Italy, has found. The study was based on a survey of more than 1,750 small and medium sized enterprises (SMEs) in Canada, China, Italy, Singapore, South Africa, and the UK, with 30 per cent of the sample micro businesses employing fewer than ten people. It shows that while most SMEs believed the worst of the recession had past, there was an unexpectedly high number of businesses - between 31 per cent and 54 per cent in each country, including those which have seen high growth and were less affected by the global downturn, who felt they did not have adequate cash reserves to survive another financial crisis. SMEs surveyed said the recession has forced them to become better businesses and if they take on risk it is only where they can have control. Growing businesses, especially in the more dynamic economies, appear to be facing stiffer competition and rising costs, putting profit margins under pressure. According to respondents, lenders appear to be directing funds to larger SMEs and big corporations rather than micro and small enterprises. The study also found that credit is being directed away from working capital towards capacity building investments and is increasingly likely to be secured against personal or business assets, while equity investments are drawn to acquisitions and to financing local or international expansion. As commercial providers of finance have become reluctant to finance working capital, assume customer credit risks or refinance debt, the weight of expectation has shifted to shareholders and trade creditors. The study found that those businesses that value professional or expert advisers above others have performed better - professional advice has given lean SMEs more confidence about their chances of survival, by ensuring that they have fewer urgent financing needs and better access to credit. The study has made a number of recommendations. SMEs must consider factors such as interest rate increases, exchange rate volatility and inflation when developing business plans and risk management policies. Governments can help reduce uncertainty through early and reliable commitments on tax, spending, monetary policy and regulation. Governments must consider strengthening loan guarantee schemes for SMEs to provide solutions where sufficient collateral cannot be provided. More businesses should explore supply chain finance: whereby large customers provide credit to small suppliers by factoring their own invoices, and governments, commonly the most creditworthy customers of SMEs, should consider similar means of financing their suppliers. Business advisers and government-funded enterprise support agencies must prioritise improving credit- and investment-readiness among SMEs by explaining the information needs of capital providers and championing other sources of finance, such as business angels, where appropriate. Providers of capital must be clear about their lending or investment criteria and consider the need for security or personal guarantees flexibly, case-by-case. Businesses should use financial and credit information on their customers and ensure their information is available to prospective trading partners. Governments must acknowledge the critical importance of trade credit as a financial market, ensuring that credit information is widely available and that creditors have access to reasonable means of enforcing their claims. Business advisers and government-funded enterprise development agencies should be looking for undercapitalised SMEs and actively encouraging action if necessary. Providers of capital should acknowledge the value of professional advice in their communications with SMEs and consider directing unsuccessful applicants to professional advisers. Helen Brand, chief executive of ACCA, says: \"It has been a challenging two years for small businesses around the world but they have emerged, on the whole, somewhat wiser, more in control and cautiously optimistic. However the recovery, such as it is, presents its own unique risks. As this research demonstrates, having the tools, the support and the confidence to navigate these risks can make all the difference between continued growth and stagnation for small businesses.\" \"Although there are signs of economic recovery, the SME sector is not out of the woods yet,\" says Anthony Ariganello, president and CEO of CGA-Canada. \"We believe it's vitally important to understand the issues faced by this sector - and having taken an in-depth look at the current situation - it's clear there are things to be done by policy-makers, by business advisers, by financial institutions and by the businesses themselves.\" Giancarlo Attolini, board member in charge of International Affairs at CNDCEC, says: \"Professionals can play a crucial role in the current financial crisis, supporting SMEs in their decisions concerning financing decisions and business planning. Good budgeting of financial resources and ability to secure third-party capital proves to be key in surviving the crisis. The survey shows that financing needs to change, based on enterprises' needs and geographical location. Micro and small enterprises, which represent the main clients of most practitioners, went through great difficulties in securing finance during the credit crunch; professional skills and advice can adequately support them in accessing finance and managing their cash flows.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/howai-should-encourage-spending-to-stimulate-the-economy/article_394807d5-5cf1-5d64-ade5-7e2a20832e7e.html", "TITLE": " Howai should encourage spending to stimulate the economy ", "DATE": "Aug 13, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "THIS is addressed to Minister of Finance Larry Howai. I think the simplest and most effective way of helping to stimulate the economy would be to encourage spending. Spending stimulates business activity, it encourages businessmen to invest more of their profits back into their businesses through expansion of facilities and manpower, thus lowering unemployment and increasing business activity, which in the long-run would lead to increased tax collections. The best and most effective way to achieve this is to simply increase the personal allowance from $60,000 per year to, I suggest, $180,000. This radical adjustment automatically precludes persons earning less than $15,000 per month from paying taxes. Why is this important Well, the majority of persons earning $15,000 or less would fall into the middle class. This automatically increases their spending power, and the amount of money available for savings, say, for a new home or purchase of land. Also, the cost of living has gone up tremendously since this allowance was raised several years ago. It also means the majority of public servants would be paying no taxes. This is something that unions should be lobbying the government for also, as it benefits their membership directly. Secondly, an incremental increase in the price of both premium gas and diesel, in the order of, say, 50 cents. It is a 33 per cent increase in the price of diesel, but we have to bite the bullet now if we are really serious about lowering the subsidy on fuels. If the subsidy was really $4 billion, then this increase would cut $1.3 billion immediately. Finally, the issue of VAT returns to businesses. This process needs to be sped up, as some businesses are on the verge of closure, especially those that are buying VAT inputs to sell zero-rated products. The cash flow is severely hampered, and solving this issue seems to be a problem, no matter which government is in power. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/imf-t-t-economy-turning-the-corner/article_fc98e920-deb9-59dd-b80d-139b0d35950c.html", "TITLE": " Imf: T&T economy turning the corner ", "DATE": "Apr 16, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "From February 1-10, an International Monetary Fund (IMF) team conducted its 2011 Article IV consultation on the Trinidad and Tobago economy. The IMF team which came to Port of Spain was headed by Judith Gould. It observed that there was \"concrete evidence that the economy is turning the corner and that economic growth will resume in 2012 notwithstanding the ongoing technical disruptions in the energy sector.\" While economist Dr Dhanyshar Mahabir has criticised the IMF's statement as being \"dead wrong\" when it comes to the local economy , Finance Minister Winston Dookeran believes the latest IMF report represents major positive news for T&T's economy. The full-length report, which received the blessings of the T&T Government before it was posted on the IMF's website focused on specific issues the country's Heritage and Stablisation Fund and Developments and Prospects in the Energy Sector. The IMF is of the view that T&T should amend the HSF Act to provide a greater weight to the savings objective in line with current practices while preserving its stablisation objective to provide some scope to manage the impact of high volatility of energy price on public finance. It observed that: \"Although the HSF has dual heritage and stablisation objectives, in practice it has served more as a heritage fund. The lack of withdrawals when energy revenues have fallen sharply together with conservative budget assumptions for energy prices suggest a strong preference to safeguard and to increase savings rather than to rely on the HSF for fiscal stablisation.\" By the same token the IMF believes the 25 per cent ceiling on the maximum withdrawal during a given year could be reduced. \"If greater emphasis were given to the savings objective, this limit could be revised downward to ten per cent to the HSF balance in any one year with a cumulative withdrawal of at most 25 per cent, which would also be consistent with the proposed capital floor. This would imply a narrowing of the space for withdrawals if there are several years of weak energy prices. At the same time, a persistent need for withdrawals could indicate a need to revise the assumed energy price projections.\" The IMF has put the onus on the Government to have greater clarity over the HSF's objectives with updating the withdrawal rules in determining investment strategy. The IMF believes this could provide a basis for pursuing a longer-term investment strategy. Also, there's scope to adjust the procedures for calculating and making deposits into the HSF to increase transparency and reduce the administrative burden. It recommeded that the government \"make deposits into the HSF semi-annually rather than quarterly, on a year-to-date basus, and with a lag after the end of the period so that deposits can be made based on finalised data.\" Observing that the energy sector accounts for 44 per cent of nominal GDP, the Fund noted that the energy sector is poised to recover but it is also facing significant risks. \"Nothwithstanding a number of setbacks in recent years, natural gas output is expected to rebound in 2012 as upgrade and maintenance work in the upstream sector is completed. The petrochemical sector is also forecast to resume operating at more normal levels with a recovery in the availability of gas,\" it observed. The IMF concluded that: \"Over the longer term, increased exploration in Trinidad and Tobago could reverse the downward trend in oil and gas reserves. However, uncertainties in the global gas market, on account of the potential of rapid growth of shale gas production worldwide, pose a challenge for the development of longer-term investment plans.\" A statement issued to the media last Friday on behalf of the Ministry of Finance noted that commercial bank credit particularly to the business sector, has expanded steadily since mid-2011, for the first time since early 2010, and that retail sales increased by 6.4 per cent up to the third quarter of 2011. The statement observed that Trinidad and Tobago's recovery comes after an extended slowdown lasting three years, in which \"ample buffers have provided room for manoeuvre,\" accommodating an expansionary fiscal stance in 2010/2011, and resources to deal with the collapse of \"a systemic insurance company.\" Among its major highlights, the report listed the following: 1. There was \"weaker than anticipated energy sector activity\" which contributed to a decline in 2011 2. The central government's finances were \"nearly balanced\" in fiscal 2010/2011 3. Monetary policy remained \"accommodative in the face of subdued inflation\" 4. Strain had emerged in the financial system \"as a consequence of the prolonged slowdown and the collapse of the CL Financial Group and its insurance subsidiary CLICO\" but progress was made in compensating CLICO claimants although on-going legal issues could lead to further delays. 5. Regarding the rebounding of the country's external accounts, the report said current account surplus increased to 20 percent of GDP in 2010, and was estimated to be 21 per cent in 2011, up from eight per cent in 2009. This would have stemmed mainly from the improvement in energy prices and a recovery in non-energy exports. 6. Gross official reserves grew to US$9.8 billion. This represents 13 months of import cover, at the end of 2011, increasing from US$9.1 billion at the end of 2010. 7. Surveying the outlook in the short term, the report said real economic activity is expected to increase by 1.7 per cent in 2012, \"as the energy sector resumes normal operations later in the year, and the non-energy sector picks up momentum with the acceleration of public investment and the restructuring of CLICO liabilities. 8. Inflation is expected to remain moderate. 9. Mediumterm growth is expected to rise to 2.5 per cent. This was described as having been \"significantly less than in the years preceding the crisis, in part due to the weak outlook for the energy sector.\" 10. Further to this, the report said the non-energy growth is expected to reach its potential of 3.5 per cent in 2012. Dookeran said: \"The report confirms that confidence has returned significantly to the Trinidad and Tobago economy.\" He believes that this confidence will now have positive impact on the cost of doing business, which will help to further spur growth and development in many sectors. However, Dookeran said that \"both domestic and international developments could put at risk, our competitiveness and our inflation expectations. The IMF report said if the 2012 budget is implemented as envisaged, this will provide appropriate stimulus to support the country's recovery. More than 200 economists, bankers and regional government officials are gathered for the Forum which will address topics like harnessing growth in the region, private/public sector partnerships and competitiveness and jobs. Anthony described the economic development of the Caribbean as \u201canaemic\u201d, pointing to average growth of just 1.1 per cent from 2008 to 2013. But he remained optimistic, saying: \u201cWe need to dispel the widespread view that we are all managing failed economies. I do not subscribe to that perspective. These economies may be broken but I believe we can pick up the pieces. I believe that our task is to conceptualise, shape and define and economic model that answers to the times and to our needs.\u201d He recalled that the launch of the Forum three years ago initiated dialogue for development amongst business groups and governments. Trinidad and Tobago, St Lucia, Jamaica and the Dominican Republic are some of the 12 countries that have committed to construct reforms in areas of investment climate, skills and productivity and connectivity, Anthony recalled. But problems remain. He said that foreign direct investment flows into the region declined by 4.7 per cent in the region. Declines in tourism, commodities prices and workers' remittances have \u201cexacerbated the negative impact that the financial crisis had on economies\u201d, he said. T&T has recently been downgraded in its currency sovereign rating by Standard and Poor\u2019s (S&P) from BBB+ to BBB. The reasons given for this are; lower than expected energy production and economic growth which will weaken Government\u2019s revenue base and delay its plans to balance its budget by fiscal year 2020-2021. Further, S&P said that institutional reforms to strengthen revenue collection and improve the provision of timely economic data have taken longer than expected, hence material benefits from these reforms are not expected in the near term. S&P estimated that T&T\u2019s real GDP grew by 0.8 per cent in 2018 and the rate of economic expansion will decrease to 0.4 per cent in 2019. To S&P, the energy sector contributed to lower and sometimes negative growth over the last several years and this is expected to continue\u2014particularly now in the gas sector where there is a lot of uncertainty, and oil production continues to be low, continuing a decline seen over a long time. And, as usual for these agencies, the exchange rate certainly limits the monetary policy flexibility and this comes at a cost for defending the rate. S&P expects that this rating of T&T will continue over the next two years. The one positive was that the economic outlook was raised from negative to stable. S&P\u2019s downgrade did not meet with the approval of the Government in that it disagreed with S&P\u2019s assessment of a projected decrease in natural gas production given its recent intervention via meetings with the major energy players\u2014these meetings were supposed to make sure that the reduction in gas production does not come about. Though S&P also predicted a loss in oil production, Heritage was now drilling 16-18 wells. Still, the Prime Minister admitted that Government\u2019s assignment to run the country on TT$10 billion less is unpleasant, a shortfall that is due explicitly to the reduction in the performance of the energy sector. Indeed, the Government\u2019s ability to spend, its budget, depends on the vagaries of the local and international energy industry over which the Government has no control. Hence Government\u2019s decisive role in the economy is reactive, modified only by its ability to save, spend counter cyclically and in the longer term transform the economy. One of our economists tells us that this downgrade was not unexpected, a view that was also expressed by the CEO of the T&T Chamber of Industry and Commerce. This is because the continuing decline in the energy sector- oil and gas production- is common knowledge. To date this one-horse economy depends on the energy sector for its very survival; the horse is now lame! As a small open economy we depend on exports, the earning of foreign exchange, to purchase at least the necessities of life that we cannot produce for ourselves. With the energy sector (oil, gas and petrochemicals) producing some 85 per cent to 90 per cent of our foreign exchange earnings and as price takers economic downside risks are extremely high. Thus, the crucial requirement to diversify the economy was/is always there. Some attempts have been made in the past by government- building industrial parks to attract on-shore foreign investment; negative listing to encourage the private sector to undertake import substitution with the longer term aim of producing export goods; building Pt Lisas to offer the private sector local commodities to go downstream. None of these produced any positive results since the economic horse, energy, was always there to shoulder the load, which has shaped the local investment rules of the economic game on shore that favour the non-tradable sector. Successive governments have failed to appreciate the dynamics of economic diversification especially when one has to start from an economy based on the sole exploitation of a natural resource as virtually its only foreign income earner in a small open economy. Hence, the recent talk about turnaround in the local economy is simply random fluctuations from being a rentier economy in the global energy industry. Still, the projects on the plate of this Government now include; the building of a dry-dock; the building of another industrial park and the invitation to the Chinese to locate some companies there; the establishment of an aluminium processing plant to produce wire, flat plate and motor car wheels; and vague talk about constructing highways to open up the interior for economic activity. But one which was fundamentally strategic was the plan to build out Tobago\u2019s tourist system into a global value chain by engaging Sandals to do the global market development, marketing and operating of government-owned hotel plant. Unfortunately this project fell apart because the population at large, goaded on by a few, did not understand the need for such a global value chain and how this could come about in Tobago. There are two characteristics of the T&T economy which inhibit diversification. These are; the investment rules of the economic game on shore which favour business in the non-tradable sector and such businessmen; the lack of appreciation that to be globally competitive the activity should not simply be mimicking what others are doing, but eventually doing something new, creating a differentiated product or service, done by entrepreneurs who are, as Schumpeter termed them, men of action, something which all of our governments\u2019 attempts at diversification ignored. Even if we can create this new group of entrepreneurs we need to put in place the institutions that will provide the knowledge, the ideas, the innovation, the finance, the market development and the marketing. If we were to take another look at what is at present on the government\u2019s plate and the activity of the private sector on-shore it is painfully evident that diversification may be beyond our reach! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/world-bank-team-looks-to-economy-impact/article_3190660f-4b3c-5838-ab86-a57dde5ec99e.html", "TITLE": " World Bank team looks to economy impact ", "DATE": "Feb 3, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "The government needs a moveable property registry that will allow banks to consider these assets as collateral, therefore allowing businesses, especially small and medium enterprises, to access more financing, the World Bank has suggested. Most of the credit in this country is based on immovable property your house as collateral, but more than 70 per cent of the property are goods and other moveable assets, so can we move towards a framework to allows small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to use these moveable assets to get credit World Bank representative Marialisa Motta said last week. Motta, the Banks director of Finance and Private Sector for Latin America and the Caribbean Region told reporters at a media conference hosted by the Ministry of Trade and Industry at Nicholas Tower, Port of Spain that Trinidad and Tobago already has a good legal framework in place to get this done, but requires a moveable registry that works very well and is efficient to speed up and make more effective the registration of the assets for use as collateral. She cited China as a successful example, where the Bank worked with the government to change collateral lending laws, and after five years, saw a US$1.5 trillion increase in lending. All of this lending has happened using moveable property deeds, accounts receivables and a significant amount of it is going to SMEs and we are seeing a similar striking impact in Africa and Mexico and other Latin American countries; we want to help Trinidad and Tobago as well, she said. Motta was part of a delegation from the World Bank who arrived in Trinidad and Tobago last Monday for a two-day visit, to, among other things, discuss the Banks engagement with the government in particular areas of reform that can have a transformational impact on the economy, competitiveness and job creation. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/overheating-economy/article_d948b8a1-390b-56b4-9694-554db151d4a8.html", "TITLE": " Overheating Economy ", "DATE": "Feb 23, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambarran in his first monetary policy presentation for 2015 announced recently that Trinidad and Tobagos economy was approaching full capacity. He explained that this meant that much of the countrys resources were being used up, which could result in rising food prices. He pointed to several factors which indicated that the economy is nearing full capacity, including the increase in headline inflation (from 5.5 per cent at the beginning of 2014 to 8.5 per cent in December 2014) and the low unemployment rate (three per cent) which he said could drive up private sector wages as businesses were unable to find skilled workers. The pickup in headline inflation is mainly due to food price inflation, which remained in double-digit territory (almost 17 per cent) for the sixth successive month in December 2014. The acceleration in food prices largely reflects rising prices for locally produced vegetables and fruits, Rambarran noted. The Business Express sought the views of the business community as well as economists on the matter. They highlighted the need for diversification as well as an in-depth look at the countrys productivity levels. Diversification critical The University of the West Indies economist and lecturer Dr Roger Hosein said the signs that the countrys economy is approaching full capacity have been there from as early as 2007 to 2008. The situation has since become more dynamic and the signs of full capacity that remain may need much closer examination. Indeed at this stage a number of factors seem to be indicating that the medium term prospects for the T&T economy is one of a new normal, he said. In the time period 2009-2014 real economic activity averaged -0.005 per cent and in the period 2003-2008 averaged 8.13 per cent. In the time period 1997-2002 real economic activity averaged 5.5 per cent. Even more amidst this stagnating level of economic activity the number of people employed increased although the unemployment rate fell. This is no doubt because of greater employment by the State. Worryingly, in this time period government expenditures and transfers and subsidies also increased sharply and the gross public sector debt also climbed, he added. He said the sharp fall in the price of oil and gas and the weakened external strength of these commodities, as the international energy market undergoes a shale gas and shale oil overhaul, point towards a need for diversification. In this setting there is a need for civil society, the mass media and academia in the remaining months of this election cycle to challenge the political parties to make diversification a front burner issue and to pursue it more aggressively than ever done in the last few decades. More focus on productivity Economist Dr Ronald Ramkissoon believes more attention should be placed on Trinidad and Tobagos productivity levels. Noting that this countrys unemployment rate is just under four per cent, which he said in economic terms means that the country is at full employment, Ramkissoon raised concern that there is little or no economic growth. Early last year, the Central Bank projected 2.5 per cent. However Governor Rambarran noted that because of the dismal performance of the energy sector growth for 2014 was estimated at just 0.8 per cent. We have had marginal growth over the last few years so one then has to ask how can we be at full employment of capital and labour yet we are not booming in respect of growth Ramkissoon said. I think there is need for an analysis of the relationship of the data and of the relationship between the employment of capital, the employment of labour and economic growth, he stated. It is possible that there is full employment but that productivity is extremely low, so we might find we are employing a fair amount of capital and labour but that it is not generating any major increases in output which suggests that in local parlance we might be spinning top in mud, he added. Ramkissoon said the issue of productivity must also be looked at when it comes to the governments make-work programmes such as Unemployment ReliefProgramme(URP) and the Community-Based Environmental Protection and Enhancement Programme (CEPEP). Agricultural rehabilitation President of the American Chamber of Commerce Hugh Howard believes the rehabilitation of the countrys agricultural sector will result in lower food imports which will then result in decreased food prices and lower demand for foreign exchange. If you look at our manufacturing sector it has done fairly well particularly as we were able to corner the whole of the Caribbean market under the Caricom arrangement. But a lot of the inputs into manufacturing, when you look at food and beverages, a lot of the stuff we import. So unless we take agriculture seriously that heavy demand for foreign exchange will continue. He added: They only way that you can find yourself with enough foreign exchange, particularly with the price of oil trending downwards, is to export more non-oil and gas goods and services. It becomes absolutely necessary for Government and private sector to get together to collaboratively determine what aspects can Trinidad and Tobago seriously be competitive with, what are the demands internationally for goods and services, where we can have a comparative advantage and get out there and seriously market those goods and services to improve the inflow of foreign exchange. What Rambarran said: There are signs the Trinidad and Tobago economy seems to be approaching full capacity. This is reflected in the movement of a number of economic indicators. Headline inflation is creeping up, reaching 8 per cent in December 2014 from the 5 per cent at the start of the year. The pickup in headline inflation is mainly due to food price inflation, which remained in double-digit territory (almost 17 per cent) for the sixth successive month in December 2014. The acceleration in food prices largely reflects rising prices for locally produced vegetables and fruits. Unemployment is exceptionally low at a little over three per cent of the labour force, with the business community reporting shortages of skilled workers which could push up wages in the private sector. Consumer credit continues to expand at a strong pace, helping to finance substantial imports of consumer durables and contributing towards significant excess demand pressures in the foreign exchange market. In the face of declining crude oil prices, the Government substantially revised downwards its energy price assumptions for the 2014/2015 Budget, but it intends to return to the original fiscal deficit target of roughly 2 per cent of GDP. This suggests the Government is likely to maintain its expansionary fiscal stance that would further add to elevated liquidity levels (currently around $6 billion) and push up core inflation. The positive momentum in the non-energy sector has delivered fairly respectable growth for 15 consecutive quarters to December 2014 and the near-term outlook is for continued steady performance in non-energy output. Boosted in part by strengthening growth in the United States and softer oil prices, the tourism-based economies of CARICOM should see some uptick in activity in 2015, providing further support to Trinidad and Tobagos non-energy exports. Central Bank has put in place a programme of intensified open market operations to aggressively remove excess liquidity from the banking system in coming months in order to support its Repo rate adjustments. Larger and more frequent foreign exchange interventions aimed at preventing systemic foreign exchange shortfalls will indirectly contribute to absorbing some of the excess liquidity. Central Bank is prepared to further position its monetary policy stance to address any challenges that may arise from unanticipated changes in global energy markets. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/central-bank-caribbean-economies-lagging-behind/article_1b5eeb84-bdc8-5515-baf1-288e1f14a124.html", "TITLE": " Central Bank: Caribbean economies lagging behind ", "DATE": "Jun 27, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Ellen Lewis with her beautiful daughters, from left, Kenya who attends Hillview College, the youngest Rosalind who attends Bishop Antsey High School East and the eldest Skylar who is studying medicine. Ellen Lewis with her beautiful daughters, from left, Kenya who attends Hillview College, the youngest Rosalind who attends Bishop Antsey High School East and the eldest Skylar who is studying medicine. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is warning that an economic speedbump could hamper the pace of global economic recovery in developed and developing countries. Central Bank Governor Ewart Williams brought that information to the 4th Biennial International Business, Banking and Finance evening reception at the University of the West Indies principal's home at St Augustine last Wednesday. While this hiccup was mainly due to be greater than expected, US-based weak economic climate, emerging markets in Asia and Latin America heated up, but were now facing an inflation rate that kept pace with their growth. \"The Caribbean economies are still digging themselves out of the global crisis of 2008 and unfortunately the recovery of the region is lagging behind that of other developing countries,\" Williams said. Statistics from the World Bank paint a dismal picture; in 1980 the Caribbean's average per capita income was twice as high as the average for developing countries, whereas today it is only a third higher. \"Countries in the region have been growing at an average rate of two per cent per year while small island states have been growing at an average rate of 3.6 per cent per year, roughly the average for the world economy,\" he said. Williams said if the major economic players sought to reverse that trend, they would have to address the long-term viability. \"The region faces the reality that it has lost some comparative advantage at a time when the global economy has become less friendly,\" he said. Williams expanded on what constituted the \"less friendly\" atmosphere. \"The traditional preferences fro bananas and sugar are now practically at an end and the region still finds itself unable to compete with lower-cost producers. Second, foreign aid flows to the region, with the exception of Haiti, have all be dried up. Third, while Caribbean tourism continues to be a viable brand, the region is facing stiffer competition from Asian destinations and will experience even greater competitive pressure when Cuba is fully opened up, as it would in the not too distant future,\" Williams noted. He also said the prospect of high unemployment in the United States and the United Kingdom for the next two to three years will have \"implications for workers remittances\" which are important to regional economies. Added to those strains, Williams said most countries in the Caribbean already have \"unsustainably high debt burdens\". \"This limits the extent to which Government spending could lead to recovery,\" he said. Williams said Trinidad and Tobago could be seen as an exception to that prevalent theme given the local energy resources and the stronger public finances and lower public debt burden. But while he gave hope in one breath, he tempered it with the other. \"Our proven energy reserves are fast dwindling and our fiscal space is being steadily reduced, the more private sector remains subdued and government steps in to lead the recovery. While public sector indebtedness is still at a comfortable level, it too is increasing rapidly to meet the high cost of the CLF/CLICO bailout,\" he said. \"In the period 2002-2006, real GDP (Gross Domestic Product) increased at an annual rate of close to ten per cent based on an annual growth of 16.7 per cent in the energy sector and 5.6 per cent per year in the non-energy sector,\" he said. Williams said the bottom line was that the entire region needed to embark on a new private-sector led growth strategy to ensure medium-term economic viability. He noted that the two largest Caricom members, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago. were ranked 81st and 97th out of 183 countries in the latest Doing Business Report, which is published by the World Bank and the IFC. \"The Global Competitive Index for 23010-2011 shows Barbados ranked at 43rd and the rest of the Caribbean ranked between 84, which was Trinidad and Tobago and 110th among 139 countries. William said the plus side was that the region was at a \"cross road of opportunity\" where the right combination of leadership, vision and commitment could help overcome the challenges. \"I am convinced that closer regional integration must be part of the solution and then we would need partnerships between the public and private sectors and other stakeholders including labour and our tertiary education. We need all hands on deck,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/financing-innovation-in-t-t/article_ff69d91c-896e-59ff-be86-df12be236fd1.html", "TITLE": " Financing innovation in T&T ", "DATE": "Oct 11, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "Senior counsel: Israel B Khan Senior counsel: Israel B Khan Generally the local private sector drives economic development via investment. However, the region's economic history, marked by the phenomenon of the plantation economy, inhibits such investment. In the region's resource-based economies (petroleum, bauxite, tropical agriculture) foreign investment normally plays the major role with the private sector investing in commerce. This is not a problem with a plantation economy; it is a defining characteristic. If T&T is to diversify its economy, i.e. provide other tradable goods and services off the plantation (including in energy) the driver of economic competitiveness has to be adequately financed, knowledge-based innovationnot cheap gas. This column has discussed centres of excellence (CoEs) and small manufacturing enterprises (SMEs) within a finance system that depends in the short to medium term on the Government's direct intervention. In some countries universities attempt to commercialise their research but encounter a fundamental mismatch between a traditional academic department, with staff accustomed to academic freedom, and a vehicle geared to the production and exploitation of intellectual property (IP) via spin-off companies. They try to force-fit these departments into this additional role by creating Technology Transfer Offices (TTOs) to support these departments in IP management, marketing etc. The conflict remains in which the academic department needs to publish as quickly as possible its research results (generally not directed to the economic demands of its society) while the TTO seeks to maintain confidentiality of these results while the invention is assessed and decisions made as to its protection. Further, the university is usually free to set its own research goals. For example, it may decide that it is about its own financial gainset up a university consultancyor that it is in general in the pursuit of new knowledge to boost its reputation or even that its work should benefit the society at large. Many governments, though they support the universities financially, do not put specific demands on them as to economic development and prefer to see universities as helping to build a knowledge-based society via the activities of their graduates. Locally, then, a vehicle should be developed that is primarily about the production of knowledge and its transfer, inventions, innovations and spin-off companies. It must be very concerned about the protection of the relevant IP and provide support in marketing, market development and business together with the usual technological strength of an academic research department. Hence, this column has recommended the creation of CoEs which could be associated with our certification universities but dance to a different drumbeatcreating spin-off companiesSMEswhich will provide innovative economic development. The recurrent funding for such a centre is three-part. One is grant funding that allows the research and development team to accomplish the basic work from which the ideas for spin-off companies flow. Grant funding also allows the CoEs to produce a \"proof of concept\" or even a basic laboratory prototype of the new idea. These are used to convince interested persons that the idea has commercial merit. The CoE will then require seed money for the founders (CoE, inventors, the government etc.) to set up a separate company to produce the first commercial prototype and to begin to meet with potential customers and clients. The seed stage should remain within the CoE's business incubator since the inventors are required full time during this stage. In establishing this stage a business plan is of no significance since it is really not yet possible to identify its elements. The CoE should be aware that the project can fail at this stage, which is not altogether a catastrophe since it allows the inventors to go on to another project. If the seed phase is successful, then the company will be looking for venture capital, equity funding and progresses to a stage in which the company gets more commercial, employs adequate staff, develops a business plan and goes into production. At this stage the CoE spins out the company and retains an investment in it via at least its IP vested in the company. The company will require further equity injections at some stage, and so allow the venture capital company to exitoffer Initial Public Offers on the stock market. On examining the local marketplace, there is an absence of, and unwillingness by the private sector to, provide research grants of the magnitude required to undertake the CoE's research, seed or venture capital funding. If we are to establish T&T's innovation system then our Government on our behalf (despite Minister Mariano Browne's reliance on the private sector for this investment) has to become initially the financier of last resort in order to jump-start this economic diversification. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-green-economy-and-sustainability/article_e4c26c0c-1110-506b-a5bd-033c15de69d8.html", "TITLE": " The green economy and sustainability ", "DATE": "Mar 7, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " This year the leaders of nations from around the world will converge in Brazil for Rio+20, the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development. At this major international event, the movers and shakers of the world will attempt to chart a way forward for the developed and developing nations of the globe. The three pillars of sustainabilityeconomic, social and environmentalwill be at the heart of the summit and the various missions will be looking to maximise their own positions and gain as many concessions as possible. Trinidad and Tobago is yet to submit any position papers or documents for the summit. This meeting offers a golden opportunity to analyse the failures of our country to prepare for the transition into sustainable development. On this issue we are falling further and further behind the rest of the world. The summit recognises the need for a global effort to combat worldwide poverty and inequality, environmental crises and climate change, and boost economic growth. Despite the tremendous strides that have been made over the past decades in reducing poverty, inequality has grown and there are still billions of people living in abject misery. The news of the rise of the powerful BRIC (Brazil, Russia, India and China) nations has been greeted with much enthusiasm from the developing world, but their rise has overshadowed the dire state many developing countries are in. These growing powers are unique, along with Turkey and some South East Asian nations, due to their large land mass and populations and substantial resource base. Most of the other developing nations have not been blessed with such abundant economic factors and have been struggling. Trinidad and Tobago is unique among the developing states due to its small size, political stability, good international credit rating and of course its abundance of natural resources. While many states are being burdened with having to import oil and gas, we have been richly blessed but we are not making the best use of our resources. Firstly, the world has come to recognise that natural resources will not last forever and there is a crucial need for investment in alternative energy sources. Many international banks and organisations have been granting generous subsidies and loans to nations that make the effort to invest in and develop alternative energy. Sadly, we are not on this list and it is very difficult for me to understand why. We have the income and finance, we have the facilities at the University of the West Indies and we have access to expertise from all over the worldfrom Germany to Brazil to Israel. We have abundant sunshine to begin a push toward solar powernot in the sense of replacing fossil fuels as a power base, but in helping citizens to outfit their homes with the technology to make use of solar power. These measures are already being used in places such as Germany and their sun exposure is nothing compared to ours. Other sources of power such as wind and wave can be seriously looked into, given our island status and exposure to steady winds off the Atlantic. Secondly, on the issue of poverty eradication, we are beginning to stall and even erode some of the amazing things we have accomplished. Our system is an interesting mix of free market and welfare. We have free health care and pharmaceuticals, we have free education and access to many other free services. We are, however, failing in delivering these services at a high quality and are not developing other much-needed systems. Our health care system is in a sorry state and, once again, we have the money and the expertise to fix it but we are lacking the will. Our free provision of HIV medication is extremely commendable, but many people are afraid to access them out of shame and the negative attitudes that pervade many public medical institutions. We are sorely lacking in dealing with mental conditions, addiction problems and stress. Our planners are concentrating too much on superficial buildings and projects, rather than investing in the population to eradicate poverty. We do not have enough jobs. Short-term programmes are not good enough. We do not have proper day care for young children and proper employment protection. Not enough is being done to provide affordable housing and not enough is being done to aid agricultural development and thus lower food prices. Then there is the issue of the environment. On this we are undoubtedly inadequate and should be deeply ashamed. Our environmental laws are a joke, illegal quarrying is still taking place but no one is doing anything. Houses are still being built without consideration for the environment. Farms and factories are polluting the rivers and seas with impunity. Cars and factories are belching toxins into the atmosphere. Vile, evil people are slaughtering pregnant leatherback turtles as they come on shore to nest after thousands of miles of swimming. The national bird has been mostly driven away. The average man and woman is still burning rubbish, engaging in illegal dumping and littering without a second thought. As a tiny tropical country, we should be taking pride on our pristine and spectacular beauty. Instead we have developed into a nation of people who care only about ourselves and our own pleasures. It is indeed sad that we will sit quietly during this summit where we could have shone as a brilliant star on the global stage. We have the resources, the knowledge, space and capacity to be a model nation, as close to utopia and a green country as is possible, but we are sorely lacking in political and popular will. It is indeed a shame that we are not living up to our full potential. Rajiv Gopie won the Presidents Medal in 2006 for business/modern studies.
