{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/how-economy-hurt-by-govt-s-sins-of-omission/article_998796d0-952e-535d-8e51-74e785a33c80.html", "TITLE": " How economy hurt by Govt's sins of omission ", "DATE": "May 27, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " The first anniversary of the People's Partnership in office has come around with little to celebrate through realised expectations for economic expansion. True, Trinidad and Tobago is far from being any economic basket case. Indeed, the Central Bank was earlier this month projecting growth in real gross domestic product of one to two per cent. This economy has been in recovery mode following the sharp decline from 2008-2009. It is in the pace of picking itself up and taking off, however, that the T&T economy has recorded a disappointing performance. Inevitably, fingers are pointing at the People's Partnership administration into whose hands the economic levers were placed one year ago. Finance Minister Winston Dookeran in mid-May praised his own defensive policy posture in protecting the economy through restraining expenditure, citing his braking manoeuvres in the Clico investor pay-outs and in the public sector wage increase offers. But Mr Dookeran has also acknowledged the State's role in priming the pump and stimulating economic activity. As the Central Bank has noted, however, the expected fiscal stimulus from Government spending on capital projects simply did not occur over the six months since the September 2010 Dookeran Budget. It was in November that, with Transport Minister Jack Warner and National Infrastructure Development Company head Carson Charles, the Finance Minister had talked up the economic stimulation and job-creation potential of the Point Fortin Highway. In January, Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar attended the sod-turning ceremony. But for that $7 billion project, so far only the most preliminary start-up signs are visible. Mr Warner had even promised highway construction, with a selected Brazilian contractor, would start in February. It turns out that the loan funding for the project is far from ready for drawdown. The spin-off effects of that unreadiness are being felt across the economy, as business stagnates, the banks are brimming with funds that companies see no need to borrow, and confidence evaporates. The Point Fortin highway project symbolises the larger failure of the State to kick-start public sector investment projects. Nor is that the only economic sin of omission attributed to the State. Business organisation leaders last week complained to the Business Express about intolerable delays in VAT refunds that complicate their financial arrangements. Meanwhile, the state also owes some $1 billion to contractors and is offering only a tortoise-paced process for rectifying such painful shortfalls in business receivables. Again, appointments to critical State boards have dragged interminably. \"Money needs to start flowing from Central Government in order to get the economy going again,\" said T&T Chamber of Industry and Commerce president Andrew Sabga. \"Not just money flowing, but money in the right channels that will trickle down to the common man.\" Mr Dookeran should keep tuned in to such review of his own and the Partnership's performance. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/rare-good-news-in-area-of-t-t-finance/article_7bb734d0-a9dc-5114-87ba-e4c1fd3f9637.html", "TITLE": " Rare good news in area of T&T finance ", "DATE": "Feb 5, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "AN impressive high-rise structure on the Port of Spain waterfront serves today as a timely reminder of T&T ambitions to become a world-class financial centre. The T&T International Finance Centre tower thrusts skyward, proclaiming forward-thinking hopes and aspirations, dating from the last Manning administration, toward the achievement and maintenance of vital economic returns. Such returns must be suitably differentiated against those deriving from oil and natural gas. It's in this regard that an advertorial published last week by the T&T IFC resonates with special relevance. For the focus is on diversifying the T&T economy by means of \u201cestablishing a robust financial services sector\u201d. It is heartening, in these times when energy export income, investment and employment describe a steadily downward trend to recognise and uphold the existence of an organisation whose mission boldly aims \u201cto make T&T the premier location in the western hemisphere for financial services\u201d. The advertorial, taking in stride the dread pattern of T&T economic downturn and the prospects of a dark cloud indefinitely hovering, actually asserts the possibility of a \u201csilver lining\u201d. Official policy, as notably articulated last December 29 by Prime Minister Keith Rowley, appears to encourage little hope for near-term advances in economic diversification. Initiatives, such as those by the IFC, aimed at \u201cexpansion of the nation's financial sector\u201d, enjoy at best a low-key emphasis. Tourism, agriculture, maritime services are among sectors routinely suggested, invariably in a vaguely futuristic sense, as promising for the T&T economy. It is for the IFC now to ring a bell and call attention not just to the possibilities in the field of international finance, but also to an achievement it claims in the listing of T&T among nations leading in \u201cfinancial attractiveness, people skills and availability, and business environment\u201d. So defined, such T&T attributes are all too rarely promoted to the end of raising national self-esteem and advancing this country's claims as a location or destination for investment. Little daunted by apparently widespread pessimism about T&T's prospects outside the energy sector, the IFC highlights positives that include low infrastructure costs, high literacy, strong telecommunications infrastructure, tax incentives In addition, the IFC cites assets \u201cnearshore location to Canada and the US\u201d. At a time when shortfalls even in Carnival production and attendant economic activity work a disturbing if not a depressing effect, T&T is responsibly encouraged to see itself as a place inviting not just to energy investors but also to major players in international finance. The IFC's is thus a good-news story, worthy of sober celebration. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/six-communities-to-get-m-boost-to-economy/article_372532fc-fa2a-59f6-8cbb-93fab69a7917.html", "TITLE": " Six communities to get $11.5m boost to economy ", "DATE": "Apr 14, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "IN an attempt to boost economic development, a three-year project costing $11.5 million will be carried out in six communities in South Trinidad. The project is entitled, \"Developing and Implementing a Local Development Framework for regions with Extractive Industries.\" It is being implemented by the University of the West Indies (UWI) Trade and Economic Development Unit. Funding for the project is being sponsored by the Inter-American Development Bank and Atlantic. Activities to be undertaken include business and entrepreneurial training, parenting workshops for teenage mothers, motivational series for secondary schools, community consultations, and workshop training sessions on micro financing options available for entrepreneurs in the south western peninsula. The six communities that will benefit from this project are Buenos Ayres, La Brea, Point Fortin, Chatham, Cedros and Icacos, said Justin Joseph, a researcher with UWI. Tomorrow, there will be the launch of an Awareness Campaign at Garden Jewelz, South Central Road, Point Fortin. The project is supported by the Point Fortin Borough Corporation. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/caribbean-business-confidence-falls/article_501cede0-d634-56e7-9f38-deafe69efa9c.html", "TITLE": " Caribbean Business Confidence Falls ", "DATE": "May 12, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Global business confidence is on the up, but the global economic recovery could be seriously flawed, reveals new research from the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Management Accountants (IMA) Global Economic Conditions Survey (GECS). GECS, the largest regular economic survey of accountants in the world, gauges the views of ACCA and IMA finance professionals globally, using the hands-on experiences of accountants in industry and practice to provide a truly global perspective of the economic recovery. The first GECS edition for 2014 saw global business confidence nearly cross over into positive territory for the first time in five years. But in the Caribbean, GECS Q1 shows that both business confidence and economic sentiment deteriorated in early 2014. Forty three per cent of respondents were optimistic about the state of their national economies, down from 45 per cent in late 2013. Over half (53 per cent) were pessimistic, up from 49 per cent previously. Only 14 per cent of respondents reported rising confidence in the prospects of their own organisations, down from 34 per cent in late 2013, while 39 per cent reported a loss of confidence, down from 48 per cent previously, the ACCA said in a statement last week. Emmanouil Schizas, ACCAs senior economic analyst, said: The shift in confidence is strongly supported by deteriorating fundamentals. Business opportunities in the region fell sharply for a second consecutive quarter, back to levels last seen in the third quarter of 2012. Investment opportunities also fell, and are now scarcer than at any time during the last three years. Cashflow and demand conditions tightened, although they remain close to average levels for 2013. Most importantly, a year-long trend towards increasing price and exchange rate stability was broken in early 2014, and the tentative recovery in access to growth capital was interrupted. As a result capacity building by businesses fell for a second consecutive quarter, to the lowest levels observed in the last three years. Brenda Lee Tang, head of ACCA Caribbean, commented: The role of the profession in supporting economic growth is one ACCA is passionate about, so this 21st edition of GECS comes with some interesting findings about accountants perceptions regarding business confidence and economic recovery. In this edition, it is worth noting that the Caribbean is not the only region to question the recovery - respondents in Central and Eastern Europe, Asia-Pacific and Africa have all slowly dropped out of the global recovery consensus over the least six months. Global findings Thirty per cent of respondents around the world were now more confident about the prospects of their organisations than they had been three months earlier, a figure unchanged since late 2013. On the other hand, 31 per cent reported a loss of confidence, down from 34 per cent in late 2013. Additionally, more than half of the global GECS sample (58 per cent, up from 55 per cent in late 2013) were optimistic about the state of their national economies, reporting that recovery was underway or about to begin. The pessimists only made up 38 per cent of the sample, down from 42 per cent in the previous quarter. However, a closer look revealed a worrying picture for the global economic recovery. Schizas added: Despite the best business confidence readings since the GECS began in 2009, ACCA and IMAs analysis of the influence of fundamentals on business confidence suggests that the economic recovery is flawed and has now become much more fragile. Since early 2013, global business confidence has become increasingly dependent on price and exchange rate stability. This trend is a sign of building financial turbulence, and has accelerated dramatically in early 2014. Financial stability is now a more significant contributor to business confidence than cash-flow and demand... {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/griffith-lifesport-fund-financing-criminals/article_defe4f23-22c8-5c60-9455-a1e8736ba1c1.html", "TITLE": " Griffith: LifeSport Fund financing criminals ", "DATE": "May 23, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "GHOST NAMES: Gary Griffith GHOST NAMES: Gary Griffith Last week, the Sunday Express reported on the growing force of the Jamaat-al-Muslimeen in Carapo under Imam Hassan Ali and his son, Rajaee Ali. Imam Ali acknowledged that his followers comprised criminals and former prisoners who sought refuge in Islam. The Express reported on how the Jamaat was able to set up a base in Carapo by squatting on State lands, was being funded through the Ministry of Sport's Life Sport Programme and the collusory/antagonistic relationship between the group and the police. In Part 4, the Sunday Express focuses on the funding from Life Sport and the relationship between the Carapo Muslims and crime, gangs and the Government. Rajaee Ali, through the Ministry of Sport's LifeSport programme is getting about $1.5 million a month in profit and has raked in about $18 million in the last year, National Security Minister Gary Griffith has alleged. Ali, the son of Jamaat-Al Muslimeen's Imam Hassan Ali, is coordinator of the Carapo arm of the Life Sport programme. Minister Gary Griffith alleged that the younger Ali is using ghost names in the programme. There are supposed to be 60 participants in one area, and overall, the programme operates in 33 areas. A stipend of $1,500 is paid a month for every participant enrolled in the programme. Griffith said in each area, 30 of the 60 participants are ghosts. Ali, Griffith alleged, is pocketing the stipend being paid on over half of the participants in the overall programme with the complicity of the Ministry of Sport. \"What they do is cut it by half-the other half are ghosts. Each person is supposed to be paid $1,500 a month, so you're looking at $1,500 by 30 by 33. So Ali and company get $1.5 million in net profit per month,\" he alleged in an interview with the Sunday Express on Friday. The LifeSport Programme is one way in which the Jamaat has been funded through the government in the past two years. The LifeSport Programme, which started at $6.6 million in 2012, increased to $29 million in 2013 and by 2014, the programme increased in cost by $84.4 million to $113,502,273. It was an initiative of the Ministry of Sport's permanent secretary Ashwin Creed. Its intent was to introduce sport and life skills to boys between 16-25 years old to curb crime in high-risk areas. Griffith said the sum Ali is able to pocket from the programme is exclusive of management fees and catering fees which are part of the Ministry of Sport's expenses in the programme.. \"We actually found out that the LifeSport fund was being used as a fuel stop off point for further activity,\" he said. But intelligence is not evidence, as Ali still conducts prayers at the Carapo mosque. Griffith observed that in the United States, there are hundreds of people on a terrorist watch list. \"What you don't do is allow them to paint the Pentagon. You don't give them a contract to paint the White House,\" he said. Sunday Express: \"The Jamaat had a contract to paint buildings\" Gary Griffith: \"Spanish (an alleged gang leader) was actually putting in CCTV cameras in the Duncan Street Police Station. And then people will try and pretend they didn't know.\" The Sunday Express understands that Cabinet, and certainly the National Security Council, were aware of this growing threat over the past two years. Rajaee Ali, \"the Don\" Griffith identified Ali as \"the one who has been (allegedly named) in most of the murders in Arouca and Maloney, D'Abadie and O'Meara and those areas.\" He has become the don, the godfather inside there,\" he said. In 2004, Ali was charged with the murder of Amadoo Huggins, when he was just 18. He has spent eight years in prison. In 2007, he was one of three prisoners who escaped from Golden Grove Prison in Arouca, but was eventually caught and sent back. He was released in 2011. Two weeks ago, following the murder of former independent senator and senior counsel Dana Seetahal, Ali was arrested for gang related activities. The National Security Minister was asked by the Sunday Express to explain just how profits allegedly made through the LifeSport Programme were used. \"The LifeSport Fund is one of the major things which has affected us,\" he said on the country's security apparatus to control crime. \"Most of the criminal activ ities, the gangs work on is the profit they get from these State contracts. So they use their profits. The funds they get, they use to pay their gang members, they pay police officers,\" he said. Asked how aware and complicit the Cabinet was to the fund financing criminals, Griffith said: \"In fairness to the government, they weren't aware till I brought it to their attention based on the intelligence I had.\" He did not want to disclose on the record exactly when the Cabinet was apprised of the LifeSport's other uses. Attempts to contact Ali by phone for comment have been unsucessful. Letter from Mr Hugh Grant As for how Ali became the coordinator, details were discovered in a memo from the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Finance to the Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Sport dated June 12, 2013. \"In addition, with respect to the letters of engagement between each coordinator and the Ministry of Sport, we have observed that a Mr Hugh Grant executed the contracts for the Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Sport for an on behalf of the Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. The Ministry of Finance and the Economy wishes to remind you that the Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Sport is the Ministry's Accounting Officer and is the appropriate officer for executing such documents. \"Further, with respect to the letter of engagement between Rajaee Ali and the Ministry of Sport for the provision of services as a community coordinator for the two month period commencing January 2, 2013, it should be noted that the letter bears the signature of Mr Rajaee Ali as both the Permanent Secretary and the Community Coordinator. Please clarify,\" the letter noted. \"Furthermore, it should be noted that whilst we are unable to approve the payment to coordinators until the contracts are executed by the Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Sport, we have observed that there are inconsistencies in the certification of the coordinators invoices. The Ministry of Finance and the Economy is very concerned abour the inconsistencies in invoices submitted for payment, most notably in respect of the fact that new invoices are being generated in lieu of our request for the original invoices to be appropriately certified,\" the memo stated. Auditor General's report In the Auditor General's 2013 report, it noted several financial irregularities in the Ministry of Sport and in the LifeSport Programme: 1. Three invoices for equal amounts totaling $259,350 for catering of meals for the LifeSport Programme in three different areas-Marabella, Morvant and Bagatelle did not reflect any business address or telephone contact number for the supplier. 2. From a review of one month's payments under the LifeSport Programme, 59 participants who were seen to have been paid stipends totaling $88,500 for St Joseph, were also seen to have been paid $88,500 for Maloney. In addition, a further amount of $76,500 was paid to 51 participants for Maloney. Also, payments for six participants in the Maraval area were made to the same bank account. The report noted that analysis of the internal audit programme of work for the year revealed that high risk areas such as the LifeSport Programme were not included for review. Cutting the Funding On Friday, Minister of Works and Infrastructure Surujrattan Rambachan told Parliament: \"Mr Speaker, I want to say that this Government has never and is not in the habit, now or ever been in the habit, of funding criminal elements in Trinidad and Tobago. \"That will not happen under this Government. \"The Government will always strive to ensure that people who conduct themselves within the law will be the beneficiaries of that which the Government has to offer the country, in terms of its development,\" he added. But Griffith explained that the Ministry of Sport was recently forced to host a family day for about $8 million to pacify the participants because he tried to force the Cabinet to hold back approval on the LifeSport payment. \"That is why I am so, you want to use the word, obsessed with destroying these gangs. If I cut their financial supply, its going to stop them from being able involved in the corruption of the criminal justice system by buying off police officers, paying off anyone, being able to pay gang members. Crippling the financial pockets will enable the law enforcement agencies to now move in,\" he said. Griffith elaborated: \"If they have good finance, good capital, they are able to invest assist and distribute their funds, on how they were able to be so successful. If they have no finance, they can't run a business. \"Gang activity is a business. That is how they thrive on it. To run a business, you need capital. Where are they going to get that capital from\" Griffith said he became aware of these activities when he was the Prime Minister's National Security Adviser but became more \"vociferious\" when he became Minister. \"I had the authority to start putting, squeezing the system. I was able to come and point the fact that gangs have tried to infiltrate into state funding,\" he said. Asked whether the Government would take steps in an election year, given that Imam Ali had said the Jamaat voted for the People's Partnership, Griffith responded: \"If it is that this Government or any Government feels that they need to liaise with criminal elements to be get in Government, I don't want to be part of that Government. I don't think any citizen would want to be part of it. \"For too long, we keep hearing of these insurgents, these radical people who say that if they give us money and you find us, we will get them to vote. Apart from lack of ethics, it is tantamount to treason in a country. And if you're starting to buy votes, what you're actually doing is selling the soul of the country. \" If you sleep with Devil there is going to be a price to pay. When you come into Government, you're going to have to pay the price.\" Howai on Life Sport Finance Minister Larry Howai said he was concerned about whether the Life Sport programme was potentially funding criminals. \"As Minister of Finance and the Economy I assure you that I am concerned about these allegations as reported in your articles. Notwithstanding our resource limitations (monitoring 30 ministries and 75 state enterprises/statutory bodies.which is not really the remit of the Ministry...is not easy) the Ministry of F&E has in the past few months re-doubled its oversight efforts of all Ministries and in particular of this Programme. An audit was done of the Programme following the discrepancies which were identified and the findings of the Report were forwarded to the Minister and the Sport Company to ensure that the controls and supervision exercised by these bodies over the Programme could be tightened and improved and appropriate action taken where persons were guilty of any wrongdoing. \"As the letter from the PS referred to in the article this morning indicated, the Ministry of F&E exercises great care and where irregularities show up, these are referred to the relevant Ministry for action immediately. While the The Ministry of Finance and the Economy does not in general, do disbursements for the Ministries, it tries as far as it possibly can to ensure that the money spent is of benefit not only to the individual participants in a programme but to the country as a whole,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/boosting-the-tobago-economy/article_7e9e0552-0a7b-503f-9702-6033a74d5240.html", "TITLE": " Boosting the Tobago economy ", "DATE": "Jun 11, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Sports Minister Anil Roberts Sports Minister Anil Roberts The Trinidad and Tobago Chamber of Industry and Commerce is pleased to note the Prime Minister's recent announcement that Cabinet has approved the establishment of a $250 million Tourism Development Fund for Tobago over 2013 to 2015, aimed at providing resources for two major areas affecting businesses on the island, namely, debt restructuring for tourism related businesses, and upgrade and maintenance of hotels having below 50 rooms. The Chamber, guided by our Tobago Division, and in concert with the Tobago Hotel and Tourism Association, has been a key driver in proposing a debt restructuring plan, aimed at businesses which would be viable, save for experiencing cash flow difficulties due to the slowdown of activity in the tourism sector in Tobago. We believe that the effort by the government to address the Tobago economy at this critical juncture is long overdue. This plan was presented to central government, the Tobago House of Assembly and other key stakeholders at several meetings during 2010 and 2011. It was a culmination of approximately four years of dedicated work and determination to see it to fruition. We have always stressed, that the injection of the money into Tobago's cash-strapped businesses is paramount and urgent. Consequently, with this new development, steps must now be taken to accelerate the process, so that businesses can take advantage of the windows of opportunity which may open from the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister. The Chamber looks forward to continuing to work with central government, the Bankers Association and the THA in order to fulfill our mandate with regards to ensuring the economic survival and viability of Tobago businesses. The very survival of the Tobago economy rests with a well-functioning tourism industry, and we therefore welcome the other proposals for boosting tourism in Tobago. These include Tobago as a duty free economic zone for shopping, and construction of additional hotel rooms and first-class marinas. These initiatives certainly seem to have the potential for significant impact on the development and modernisation of the island's tourism product, as well as the creation of much-needed sustainable employment on the island We however recognise that these initiatives may require further research and consultation in order to gauge accurately the net economic benefits to be realised from the proposed projects. Recent statements by the THA's Finance Secretary demonstrate that the most desirable approach is to achieve full stakeholder collaboration and buy-in. This will certainly go a long way to ensuring the success of any project being contemplated. Some commitments must also be made regarding the time frame for implementation of the proposals. The Chamber reiterates its readiness to assist, in any way possible, to move these projects from discussion to realisation, once it has been reasonably demonstrated that the proposals are economically sound. Yet, we note with concern, that no fully developed, holistic economic plan for Tobago has been developed. The Chamber strongly believes that in order to reap the fruits of these - or any - initiatives, an overall economic development plan for the island must be developed based on careful research, stakeholder input and with goals and timelines clearly defined. This is imperative if we are to attract investors wishing to participate in our development drive. The arrival of the energy industry to Tobago is imminent with the announcement that Centrica Energy is in discussions with the Ministry of Energy over the commercialisation of gas off the north-east coast of Tobago. Since this could represent the largest investment in the island's history, it is expected that numerous business opportunities will in due course emanate from this activity. There is still some time before this is activated, and we hope that central government and the THA will collaborate in ensuring that residents of Tobago are sensitised, and offered the necessary technical and artisan training to equip them to take advantage of new business and employment opportunities. The Chamber will certainly play its part by continuing our collaboration with the THTA and similar business representative organisations in order to widen ownership and strengthen our lobby. We are positive that Tobago can continue to build on this renewed momentum for a prosperous economy. We reconfirm our commitment to be part of any process that will be to the benefit to the island's business sector and indeed, all Tobagonians. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/small-businesses-key/article_55d031fe-bb29-5706-8c6c-247c126a4070.html", "TITLE": " 'Small businesses key' ", "DATE": "Mar 10, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "The Deputy Governor of the Central Bank Dr Shelton Nicholls has called for more to be done to ensure the survival of small and medium businesses during the current economic slowdown. Speaking at the launch of the Innovative Financing for Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises hosted by the Inter-American Investment Corporation (IIC), an arm of the Inter American Development Bank, he said: \"In the current economic climate the survival of many small and medium enterprises are going to be an even greater challenge but because of their size and flexibility small firms are likely to be able to adapt much faster to these challenging economic circumstances than their larger counterparts. \"It is quite important therefore that during this period of economic slowdown that even greater attention be place on polices that spur entrepreneurship.\" Nicholls said while the slowdown of economic activity is likely to impact most, if not all of the sectors of the economy, it is quite important that the country continues to promote and nurture the small and medium enterprises sector with a view to building a more dynamic business culture in the medium to long term. Minister of Planning, Housing and the Environment Emily Gaynor Dick-Forde, who also spoke at the launch, acknowledged the growing importance of small and medium businesses to the economy during the period of economic downturn. Dick-Forde said the IIC programme, which is being funded by the Governments of Korea and Austria, can help strengthen the ability of local small and medium enterprises to continue to make an even greater contribution to the development of the local economy. She added that in Trinidad and Tobago small businesses are often defined as comprising six to 25 employees while medium 25 to 50 employees and of 2006 there were 1,924 small enterprises and 740 medium-sized enterprises operating in this country. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/slowing-economy-could-be-blessing-in-disguise/article_d122c845-8098-5243-b16a-8ccba01e0a7b.html", "TITLE": " 'Slowing economy could be blessing in disguise' ", "DATE": "Jan 26, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "This country's economic slowdown does not have to be treated as a bad occurrence, but rather economists and businessmen alike are saying the low energy revenues and the subsequent budget cuts could be the \"wake up call\" which the country needs. Speaking to the Express yesterday, economist Jwala Rambaran said the slowdown and its effects on the local economy could lead to more responsible handling of taxpayers' dollars this year. The economist, who was among many financial experts who critiqued both the level of Government expenditure last year and the use of the $70 oil price in the national budget, said the fallout of the global economic crisis leaves room for the powers that be to do \"a complete re-assessment of this country's economic status, and to re-examine the road down which the country is headed.\" Like Rambaran, Imtiaz Ali, head of the San Juan Business Association, said the slowdown has created the opportunity for the government to do more with less, instead of the other way around. The businessman said, \"When we have less money, we always exhibit more discipline, we tend to control it better.\" Karen de Montbrun, president of the Trinidad and Tobago Manufacturers Association, said it is obvious the Government has already started moving towards \"tightening its belts.\" She said she was pleased to see this country's administration leading by example. While Gregory Aboud, president of the Downtown Owners and Merchants Association, said both the media and politicians are making the economic situation out to be a \"crisis\" when it is only a slowdown. He said that the exaggerated descriptions of the country's present economic climate are doing more damage than good, as they are scaring both average citizens and potential investors and therefore hindering the public's confidence and slowing growth even further. He is fearful that all the talk of a local economic crisis could become a self-fulfilling prophecy which citizens create for themselves. While Rambaran agreed with Aboud to some extent, he said the reality is that while the country is not in crisis mode, it is high time that both the man on the street and the man in charge embrace the fact that everyone, everywhere could be facing a global recession which can last up to two years. Attempts to reach Minister of Finance Karen Nunez Tesheira for a response proved futile. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ex-finance-minister-supports-liat-downsizing/article_31aba684-d7b5-532e-adbe-9d0f0d4a0312.html", "TITLE": " Ex-finance minister supports LIAT downsizing ", "DATE": "Mar 9, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "ST. John's Former Antiguan finance minister Harold Lovell is supporting moves by the Antigua-based regional airline, LIAT, to reduce its staff and downsize its operations in the face of continued economic challenges. Last month Prime Minister Gaston Browne said he wanted to hold a meeting with the shareholder governments of the airline after it announced plans to send home at least 180 workers and shift some of its operations to Barbados. In a letter to St Vincent and the Grenadines Prime Minister Dr Ralph Gonsalves, the Antigua and Barbuda prime minister is urging that the financially strapped airline take no further action until his administration discusses the matter. We understand that from time to time we will have to make changes, we understand that LIAT is in a very precarious position, at the end of the day our economy is also in a precarious position and I just want to get all the facts together, he said. But Lovell, speaking on Observer radio here, said that the airline has no choice but to review and downsize its operations. LIAT has to downsize, I mean, I know perhaps, its politically incorrect for me to say that. But the point is if you run a restaurant and you have 50 tables and you employ, for argument sake, one person per table, and then you have 20 tables you would not keep the 50 employees when you only have 20 tables. There has to be something which allows us to absorb those workers or to have a strategy thats going to deal with the excess capacity that you now have, he said, indicating that the government should examine other options to provide employment for the workers likely to be laid off. The former civil aviation minister said this could be done through creating business opportunities for complementary aviation services. If you incorporate a company, the business which would be the training of pilots, there is a market out there for that, because every airline that operates at the level of LIAT around the region they are using ATRs and this is an opportunity, Lovell said, noting that private investors and not the government should be involved in running the airline. LOOKS DELICIOUS: This dish is stuffed lamb with rice. SELECTING: Chef Sombat Mekhawawong selecting meats for a patrons. LOOKS DELICIOUS: This dish is stuffed lamb with rice. The United States narrowly averted a trillion-dollar debt default last Tuesday when President Barack Obama signed a bill raising the country's debt ceiling. But the debt deal might not be enough to maintain its coveted AAA debt rating, international credit rating agencies are saying. What may be more worrisome for Trinidad and Tobago, are the spillover effects likely to flow from a US economy on the brink of a downgrade. Fitch Ratings last week said the agreement to raise the debt ceiling and make spending cuts was an important first step but \"not the end of the process\". Moody's Investors Service assigned a negative outlook to US debt, but confirmed its AAA rating for now. A negative outlook means the rating agency could lower the rating in the next 12 to 18 months. Moody's said continued slow economic growth, higher interest rates could lead to a downgrade. Moody's also said weak fiscal discipline in the coming year could do the same. US debt has held the AAA rating since 1917. Fewer than 20 countries are currently rated AAA. Among them: the United Kingdom, Australia, Germany and Singapore. Scotiabank managing director Richard Young believes there could be negative and positive impacts for Trinidad and Tobago. \"In a broad sense as a country, as has been said publicly, there must be some spillover. Remittances from the US could decline but on the positive side, if there is a downgrade, US supplies (like food) could be cheaper. But there would be a gestation period for this if the US economy gets impacted because of a lower rating,\" he told the Business Express. If the US is downgraded, prices could come down and Trinidad could reap the benefits. But there are also currency concerns. If the US dollar gets weaker, it will make other currencieslike the Canadian dollar-even stronger, Young suggested. Canadian dollars are selling at almost TT$7 for one now. The value in absolute terms of Trinidad and Tobago's Heritage and Stabilisation Fund could also be affected if the value of the US dollar dips. One could speculate that oil and gas revenues could come down too, if prices slide on the international market. \"As a country, we must be concerned because it is not just the United States, the whole world is in a tailspin, and we must be part of that,\" Young says. \"We must be prudent. But there may also be a golden opportunity for the country to re-engineer itself.\" While he commended Finance Minister Winston Dookeran's efforts to stabilise the economy, Young suggested that any downgrade in the US will have some effect on Trinidad and Tobago. Dookeran maintained last Thursday that Trinidad and Tobago's economy remains stable even though Standard and Poor's lowered this country's long-term local-currency sovereign credit rating to 'A/A-1' from 'A+/A-1'; and the same time affirmed the country with an 'A/A-1' foreign-currency ratings. He said in a statement this new development is based on methodology rather than a change in perception. He noted that the change will still leave the country with an 'A' Grade and in his views it reflects the stringent measures taken by the rating agency in the aftermath of challenges facing the US economy. \"Under the revised methodology, the gap between the local- and foreign-currency ratings on most sovereigns we rate worldwide is narrowing. This is because we believe that given the increasing globalisation of markets, governments are likely to have fewer incentives to differentiate between their local- and foreign-currency debt in the event of debt restructuring.\" It also added that, \"The stable outlook reflects our expectation that the government's cautious macroeconomic policies should keep its fiscal and external debt burdens steady, which includes the expectation of no further erosion of the balance sheet because of the resolution of CL Financial Group bankruptcy.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/sport-is-a-business/article_04d15f91-385b-545a-a2ca-f6e4163a2623.html", "TITLE": " Sport is a business ", "DATE": "Dec 23, 2008 ", "CONTENT": "THE chorus of \"I told you so\" were audible even as far away as New Zealand. A host of sceptics were adamant from the start that Sir Allen Stanford's fanfared entry into West Indies cricket was too good-or too bad-to be true. His global financial empire might have turned over skillions annually but there appeared no business sense to his sudden heavy investment in a regional game restricted to small territories with small economies and small populations. Even in the long run, it surely could not earn a profit. Perhaps it was a message from accountants bold enough to deliver it that is one reason for his decision to \"review\" his involvement. It was similar advice that forced Kerry Packer to cut costs in his second season of World Series Cricket. There are clearly other grounds for Stanford's reasseement. He himself has cited as another the sponsorship clash with Digicel over his Super Stars' 20/20 for 20 million match against England that became the jewel in his crown. It led to an expensive, widely-publicised case in a London court, an embarrassment for which he squarely blames the West Indies Cricket Board (WICB). It was an event he clearly expected to boost his global image and that of his companies. Instead, the British media ensured it was a public relations disaster with its disparagement of every aspect of it. There were many who could not accept his stated motives at face value. \"My love for cricket is as great as any West Indians' and it is certainly something that, when it is at the top, we all rise to the top with it, businesses included, and I have businesses in the Caribbean and we all float up with it,\" Stanford said prior to this year's regional 20/20 tournament. \"Plus it's a very emotional thing and when cricket falls into the trough as it has been, you want to try and do something about it. \"In essence, this was the impetus for my venture into the business of cricket in 2005, and it continues to be the driving force behind my heavy investment in the game in the Caribbean,\" he added. Michael Holding was one of those who first sparked Stanford's interest in cricket. He spent a brief time as one of the 'legends' on his board of directors before resigning. Ironically, he became one of his sharpest critics. The revered fast bowler of the great team under Clive Lloyd (who also severed links with Stanford early in the piece) acknowledged that the initial plan benefited West Indies cricket through grants to individual associations to develop the game and its infrastructure. But he claimed that changed with Stanford's deal with the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) for the US$20 million Super Series in Antigua and subsequent projects in England. \"He wants to promote himself and his companies, that's all,\" Holding told the London Daily Mail last August. \"If people can't see that then I can't help them, it's their problem.\" Whatever the arguments and the causes for Stanford's change of direction, there can be no doubt that he injected a new excitement to Caribbean cricket to counteract the constant bungling and incompetence of the West Indies Cricket Board (WICB) and the depressing results on the field. Even Chetram Singh, long-serving Guyana board chief and WICB director, acknowledged that Stanford cricket \"pulled a lot of people in to the game and a lot of territories benefited from the money to buy equipment and renovate their grounds and hire coaches and so on\". If he now pulls the plug on his Caribbean cricket operations, as opposed to his English venture-as seems likely with the disbanding of his board of legends and the closing of the office in Antigua-the 20/20 tournament will be missed most of all. Quite apart from the huge prize money earned by the winning teams and playersTrinidad and Tobago pocketed US$1.5 million in the two years, Guyana US$1 million, Jamaica US$500,000it gave the anonymous weekend club cricketers from previously ignored smaller islands their moment in the television spotlight and their impoverished associations finances never forthcoming from the regional board. Characters like Dane Weston from US Virgin Islands who became a star with his stares, hip-wiggling wicket celebrations and \"war\" talk, like Lionel Ritchie, the batsman from St Maarten with the showbiz name, like construction worker Maxford Pipe from the BVI. It brought Lionel Baker and Andre Fletcher to wider public attention, both moving into the West Indies team, Baker as Montserrat's first Test player. The accepted modern maxim is that sport is a business and, like any other business, is guided by the bottom line. It led Stanford to sell his Caribbean Star and Caribbean Sun airlines and it now appears as if his venture into West Indies cricket will endure the same fate. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/economy-on-a-tightrope/article_2de970f2-a546-5ccb-a20d-6ce02ae364a9.html", "TITLE": " 'Economy on a tightrope' ", "DATE": "Mar 5, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "INSPECTION: Minister of Sport Anil Roberts, third from left, and other officials on a walkabout at Larry Gomes Stadium in Malabar, Arima on Tuesday. The stadium is one of four facilities having upgrades done to its track and football field. INSPECTION: Minister of Sport Anil Roberts, third from left, and other officials on a walkabout at Larry Gomes Stadium in Malabar, Arima on Tuesday. The stadium is one of four facilities having upgrades done to its track and football field. When it comes to projections on the Trinidad and Tobago economy, the International Monetary Fund's been \"dead wrong for the last three years\". That's the \"pessimistic yet realistic\" view of economist Dr Dhanayshar Mahabir in response to the IMF's optimism that the twin-island economy \"is turning the corner\" and is projected to grow by 1.7 per cent in 2012. \"The Fund has been very clever in their use of language. They did not show where the growth was going to come from. There's nothing by way of objective leading indicators. There's no hard data,\" Mahabir told the Business Express last Friday. Despite burgeoning new car sales often associated with prosperity, the country has been in recession since 2008, he said. The IMF's positive outlook, after years of economic stagnation, was widely quoted by Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar during political rallies in the lead-up to a no-confidence motion brought against her by Opposition Leader Dr Keith Rowley last week. Economic recovery is a victory the People's Partnership is hoping to claim after two years in office. Stymied by an inheritance with included outstanding debts to contractors, wage negotiations with unions and a resolution to the CLICO issue, Finance Minister Winston Dookeran could not see the blue skies he hoped for in 2011. With an expensive budget- over $50 billion which capitalises on a plan first set forward in 2011 to turn the economy around, the Government is hopeful that 2012 will be that year. With wage negotiations being gradually concluded, money being paid to contractors as well as CLICO policyholders, coupled with investments in the energy sector and from Government's overseas marketing to India and Brazil, the Persad-Bissessar administration is hoping the liquidity injection will positively impact the economy. But with an ironing out of some issues, says Mahabir, comes new challenges higher salaries for Petrotrin workers and the news that Trinidad Cement Ltd (TCL) will import cement to meet quotas. \"Ancel Roget has shown that there's nothing sacrosanct about a five per cent wage cap and Petrotrin settled to minimise pain to the country. And while cement is not critical as gasoline, it is important for construction which is the sector needed to pull the economy out of the rut,\" he reasoned. As far as Mahabir's concerned, T&T's economy is on a tightrope. And in that scenario, there'll be no economic growth for 2012, or for the next six years. \"We've had three years of decline. Though it's not been steep, it is slipping backwards. And 2012 does not appear to be a year of progress,\" he said during a telephone interview. He accused the Central Bank of practising loose monetary policy and the Government of loose fiscal policy. \"Fiscal policy does not hold much optimism for economic revival. We have exhausted our monetary and fiscal ammunition and the private sector has not responded. The private sector usually responds when expected profitability improves,\" he stated. Since 2008, Mahabir has been wary of economic projections and analysis of the economy. Quite simply, he doesn't believe his contemporaries understand the economy the way he does. And while he begs forgiveness for his arrogance, he explained that analysis usually relies on the superficial be it the healthy state of foreign reserves or the low level of foreign debt. \"In 2008, the Government was of the view that you had to spend your way out of a decline. That was a fundamental misunderstanding of what ailed T&T,\" he explained. During the period 2004-2008, significant investments were made by the Government and the private sector. He characterised this period as \"years of heavy spending by all actors of the economy\". Post 2008 though, the private sector withdrew from spending evidenced by the level of investments made in buildings, plants and equipment, he said. He observed that with manufacturing plants operating at two-thirds their capacity, there was simply not enough private sector activity. \"When the Fund gave projections, I did not see the source of growth,\" he said. For instance, Mahabir believes the CLICO money repaid to policyholders will be banked and not immediately re-invested, contributing to the liquidity crisis in the country. \"CLICO money will do nothing to stimulate the economy. The Government has gotten it wrong and they are misleading the country. People would not want to spend their funds immediately. They would keep it to spend for the rest of their lives or over a range of activity over a period of time. The fund would be parked up in the bank,\" he explained. Can the government policy achieve 1.7 per cent growth For that to happen, says Mahabir, the leading indicators would vary, such as: the amount of building permits approved by Town and Country Planning for execution (indicative of housing and construction activity), orders by manufacturers for new plants and equipment, the number of new office buildings the business class plans to construct and reduction in inventories of finished goods by manufacturers. \"In a boom period, sometimes you have to wait for two weeks to get building blocks. So how long you take to fill the order of a customer is also indicative of the state of the economy because there's a great demand for building blocks,\" he said. So what can the Government do to get out of this quagmire For Mahabir, that answer lies with Foreign Direct Investment a return on the government's trip to India, a return on big investments like Atlantic (which impacts on several sectors of the economy). \"Public policy has to be figured. Dookeran cannot afford any more deficits and the Central Bank cannot afford any more looseness,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/report-caribbean-businesses-losing-confidence/article_3633043c-990d-5d89-b579-c69cf90bfb14.html", "TITLE": " Report: Caribbean businesses losing confidence ", "DATE": "Aug 5, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "Caribbean finance professionals have less confidence in the future prospects of their businesses than earlier in the year, despite a rise in access to growth capital, according to new findings from the Global Economic Conditions Survey (GECS) from the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Management Accountants (IMA). GECS, the largest quarterly economic survey of accountants in the world, gauges the views of ACCA and IMA finance professionals working at the coal face of businesses. The Q2 2013 edition showed that just 24 per cent of respondents in the Caribbean reported increased confidence in the prospects of their organisations - up marginally from 23 per cent in the first quarter of 2013; while 45 per cent reported a loss of confidence, up 14 per cent from the first quarter of the year. On a global scale, the GECS found that both business confidence and optimism about the economy continued to rise during the second quarter of the year. Nearly half of the GECS sample 47 per cent felt that the state of the economy was improving or about to do so, up from 43 per cent in early 2013, while just under 50 per cent were pessimistic, predicting deterioration or stagnation, down from 54 per cent in the first quarter. This is the highest level of optimism about the national and global economies in two years, and the strongest year-on-year improvement in three years. The survey showed there was improved availability of growth capital on a global scale in the second quarter of 2013, which was driving confidence upwards. Emmanouil Schizas, ACCA senior economic analyst and editor of the GECS, said: While there has been a drop in the Caribbeans confidence levels, across the globe the survey shows the highest level of optimism about the national and global economies in two years, and the strongest year-on-year improvement in three years. Business confidence has inched upwards, following an overly-bullish first quarter, and is now in line with the fundamentals of the business environment. What is encouraging is that the marginal improvement in global business dynamism in early 2013 has now accelerated across all measures of investment, orders and employment. Employment in particular is recovering quickly and is now stronger than at any point in the last two years. Brenda Lee Tang, head of ACCA Caribbean, added: Although access to growth capital in the Caribbean improved in the second quarter of 2013 and appears to be on a generally upward trend, the improved trading environment isnt leading directly to a rise in investment in the region. Less demand and tightening cash-flow conditions, added to the rise in inflation may be making Caribbean businesses cautious about making long-term commitments. Despite that caution, the Caribbeans finance professionals are reporting that businesses are hopeful about the wider economic recovery, with 52 per cent optimistic about seeing economic conditions improve, up from 45 per cent earlier in the year, which may bode well looking to the rest of the year. Across the world, fewer respondents reported falling revenues and declining orders. There has been little change in the share of respondents worried about customers or suppliers failing, despite the tightening of cash-flow conditions. The second quarter also saw businesses reporting more investment and business opportunities being available particularly through investment in new markets, niche offerings, and high quality standards. A two year high of more than 26 per cent reported that their organisations had access to value-added opportunities and were not considering cost-cutting. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/new-small-business-boom/article_06c6657b-4289-534c-a0a2-b182b9c47396.html", "TITLE": " New small business boom ", "DATE": "Jun 22, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "DEMONSTRATING: Managing Director of TopLine Maintenance Sean Hanuman demonstrates cleaning of a toilet with his new equipment. \u0097Photo: AKILE SIMON DEMONSTRATING: Managing Director of TopLine Maintenance Sean Hanuman demonstrates cleaning of a toilet with his new equipment. \u0097Photo: AKILE SIMON IN search of a new and diversified revenue stream, more and more people are turning to entrepreneurship. Data obtained by the Express from the Ministry of Legal Affairs shows that the registration of new businesses has increased by an average of 10 per cent since the global financial meltdown in 2008, while company registration has increased by more than 20 per cent. \"Whether they are actually successful is something else,\" said local economist Indira Sagewan-Ali during a telephone interview last week. Nevertheless, she said \"entrepreneurs are integral to all capitalist economies, therefore vital to Trinidad and Tobago\". \"They are the drivers of the engine of growth-the private investing sector. Private sector investment generates employment and provides revenue to the government which is used to provide basic utilities and social services,\" she said. \"From an economic growth perspective\", Sagewan-Ali said \"increased emergence of small and micro enterprises in a crisis period is important for domestic stability\". She added, however, that necessity \"is the mother of all invention\". Something 23-year-old Sean Hanuman has fully embraced. \"I saw an opening for the maintenance industry because there are not a lot of companies that do drain cleaning and tank cleaning here in Trinidad, and honestly, the ones that are around, are highly overpriced,\" he said. The managing director of TopLine Maintenance, Hanuman recently started his business out of his apartment in Valsayn after coming to terms with rumours of restructuring at his old job. \"Up until January 5, I worked at Kimberly Clarke (Trinidad) Ltd for three years as a quality control technician\". \"Before that, the company was called Misons Industries, and I was there for two years doing the same thing so making it five years that I worked for that company,\" he said. Hanuman said he scraped up his savings and borrowed from his family to start TopLine Maintenance and strongly believes that if he keeps his focus \"I am going to give Century 21 a run for their money at some point down the line\". \"It was not life long, it was something that just happened, but I know it's going to work,\" he said. Hanuman admits that maintenance cleaning is a dirty business; after all, he cleans everything from clogged toilets to water wells. \"Somebody has to do it and I don't mind being that person being me\". Recalling how at one point in time he had to call out maintenance personnel, Hanuman said the people charged him $1,500 an hour to unclog a drain. \"I thought that was a lot of money, so I decided I could go lower than that, much lower and still make,\" he said. For a young person, however, starting a new business can be a scary endeavour says Sandrine Rattan, manager, Corporate Communications at the National Entrepreneurship Development Company Limited (Nedco). Which is why she said \"At Nedco, we recognise that for an entrepreneur starting a business, access to office space and sound, professional advice and guidance are critical so the ETIIC (Entrepreneurial Training Institute and Incubation Centre), an initiative of Nedco, was established as an institute of excellence to respond to such needs by providing a supportive environment where ideas can be transformed into successful, commercially viable, robust enterprises\". According to Rattan, Nedco receives 400 applicants per annum or 35 monthly. In addition to that, they have helped 2,089 individuals through loan financing within the last three years. But overall, she said, the retail services is the sector in greatest demand (34 per cent) followed by Food and Beverage (nine per cent) and Beauty Culture (eight per cent). Hanuman believes, however, that his choice was the best for him. \"Starting this new business, I mean it's a lot of work, but there is a joy in it for me 'you are not at the mercy of an employer who would decide to make your position redundant or lay you off'.\" \"Studies have shown that whenever there is an economic crisis, people want to maintain the ability to live life the same way, they just want to do it for a cheaper price and that's how TopLine came about\". \"We are providing a service, which is limited and very expensive here in Trinidad, for a cheaper price, and its not that I am using outdated equipment. \"I am using top of the line equipment, which is how I came up with the name TopLine\". As a new company, Hanuman said they have made themselves available 24/7. For more info about starting your own business contact Nedco at 821-5800. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/more-us-for-economy/article_7c921416-d0bf-54e9-aa3e-884b0a1c0139.html", "TITLE": " More US$ for economy ", "DATE": "Nov 23, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Government recognises that there is a foreign exchange shortage in the country, Finance Minister Winston Dookeran said yesterday. And therefore it supports the Central Bank initiative to increase its committment to the foreign exchange market from the current level of US$115 million per month to US$200 million per month and to try and deal with some of the queues that have developed, he said. He added that this would add more purchasing power into the system. He was speaking in the debate on the Finance Bill in the House of Representatives yesterday. Dookeran stressed that the country was fortunate because the level of foreign reserves continued to be good. But, he noted: \"We cannot become complacent because the trend is not always in the right direction.\" He said there was a recognition of the need \"to trigger the economy\". On the debt to the contractors, he said he was advised that between June and October, the Ministry of Finance spent $2.4 billion to deal with contractors' claims. He said there were other claims which were being dealt with by the Ministry of Housing and Environment. \"The problem is not over but we have made a dent in that situation and we hope to remove it over time,\" he said. He said on the issue VAT refunds, he noted businesses have been \"crying and are in great pain\". He said Government had increased the payout of VAT refunds from $350 million to $400 million and was hoping that the VAT office could take it to $500 million. This would also inject some purchasing power. Dookeran said much of the issues Government was grappling with, related to the inheritance which Government got from the PNM. It would have been nice if we could have inherited a clean balance sheet, he said. \"Regrettably this is not so,\" he added. He said however that \"it was comforting\" that the international community at large which had been watching carefully the vulnerabilities that the country was faced with and its reponses, had indicated their confidence in Trinidad and Tobago. He cited the \"extensive support\" of the Inter-American Development Bank which illustrated its \"direct support for the policy direction\" of the People's Partnership Government. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-business-of-leadership/article_79e34497-da35-574a-915f-25ac0e6eabad.html", "TITLE": " The business of leadership ", "DATE": "Dec 5, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Photos: Stephen Doobay Photos: Stephen Doobay President and CEO of the Neal & Massy Group of Companies Gervase Warner on November 24 addressed an American Chamber of Commerce conference in Port of Spain and advanced a thesis on how the business community was looking after its operations but niot necessarily leading the country collectively as it ought to. He also examined the impliecations for Trinidad and Tobago of the economic declines in the United States and Europe as well as the way the country was managing its oil and gas industry. Following is Warner's full statement: A couple months ago, I had the honour of attending the World Economic Forum in Dalian China. Neal & Massy is the first Trinidadian Company invited for membership into the WEF as one of the Global Growth Champions. The conference was fascinating and eye opening. The magnitude and scale of operations in China is important for us to all understand. Similarly, the effects of the global economic forces and their impact on our small economies is also important for us to understand. Thesis of my speech today is: We, the business community (and I generously include myself), are taking care of our business but we are collectively not leading this country like we need to. As I now understand and appreciate the global economic and geopolitical forces that are currently at work, there is an urgent need for us to step up to further leadership in our twin island republic. I would like to share some Insights World Economic Forum I will break my summary into two parts: (1) Western Trends and (2) Eastern/ Asian Trends (1) Western Trends US and UK shifted banking crisis to a Fiscal problem but do not have the policy consensus to deal with the Fiscal problem. Instruments to address Fiscal problems are politically unpopular. US consumer is deleveraging, slowing down consumption in US. Corporate sectors in the US and around the world is also deleveraging to assure financial strength in times of uncertainty Banking sector has tightened lending criteria with a more pessimistic outlook Large companies are OK, they have cash but SMEs are hurting cash crunch and little access to credit European countries have not taken medicine and seem to be delaying the inevitable In Europe, they have only just realised that the emerging Banking crisis needs to be addressed and there is now a call for increased capitalisation of European banks. However the European Banking Crisis which is arising from sovereign debt problems with the PIIGS (Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Greece and Spain) needs to be transferred to Fiscal debt and deficits across the wider European Union. The problem will require an international solution IMF (Global) coordination. European Union is being seriously challenged: -Monetary Union without Fiscal or Political Union -When fiscal requirements for membership (Debt/GDP limit, Fiscal Deficit limit) are out of compliance in anyone state, there are no mechanisms for correction other than coercion or threat of leaving the Union -Weakness in the model is being tested and will result in some major changes to the EU. - PIIGS are challenging the viability of the union. The prescribed medicine for Greece is: Improved tax collection, privatization and austerity. However the Greeks don't want to take the medicine and are protesting further assistance from the European Union - how ungrateful. On the other hand, the Germans are facing an increasingly angry public that does not understand why their wealth must be used to save countries like Greece, where the retirement age is much lower, fiscal discipline is not exercised and where help is resisted and resented. All indications are that the US and European markets are going to continue to struggle in the foreseeable future (2) Eastern/Asian Trends Cannot go back to US/Europe Dominance (US cathedral) - 1950s-1980s: US drove consumption and production across world. - 2010: US and Europe were out-produced, out-traded and out-invested by Rest of the World (ROW). - Now: US and Europe still hold the largest stake in base consumption. However, China and Asia drive production and are the primary drivers of consumption growth, along with the other BRIC countries. - By 2020: China and Asia replace US in driving both consumption and production. More economic growth to be driven by emerging market economies, especially China and India. What are the Implications for Trinidad and Tobago Our Caricom, US and UK trading partners are going to see tough times for some time ahead, as US and European consumers will continue to struggle in the medium term while US and Europe sort out their problems. Many of our Caricom partners are facing increasing problems of mounting debt. Barbados (112 per cent Debt to GDP) is on the brink of being downgraded by S&P and Jamaica (136 per cent Debt to GDP) is in a stalemate with the IMF over forward looking targets including: Reducing the wage bill from its 11 per cent of GPD to nine per cent by March 2016; Decline in the debt ratio from 130 per cent to 114 per cent by 2014, and 100 per cent by 2016; Reducing the current account deficit to GDP ratio to five per cent by 2014. Others in financial trouble include St Kitts (196 per cent Debt to GDP) and Grenada (120 per cent Debt to GDP). Although our Oil & Gas industry is providing a cushion, however note: it is not being particularly well managed. Let me summarise the current dynamics of the Oil & Gas Industry Oil production in Trinidad and Tobago has declined steadily over the last 26 years from an average of 176K bopd in 1985 to an average of 94Kbopd YTD 2011. The prize oil producing asset, Trinmar continues to under-perform, producing 22,000 to 23,000 bopd. From 34,000 bopd in 2006, Trinmar's production fell consecutively in 2007 and 2008 and has never regained despite the reserves and potential production of the field. Many experts are confident that the field could be returned to 35,000 to 40,000 bopd production with the right management. Successive Energy Ministers have stated that increasing oil production is of the highest priority, but the single lever that would make the most difference - changing the management paradigm of Trinmar (eg, through a JV or sale to a majority party) continues to be avoided. What's the definition of insanity Doing the same thing over and over again, expecting a different result. Even more depressing is the outlook from the Gas perspective. Over the years, our government did an excellent job of maximising Trinidad & Tobago's take from Oil & Gas operations. When I researched this as a consultant in 2002, we were already among the best. Well we have played this hand beyond its utility. Trinidad is no longer considered among the most attractive investments for gas exploration opportunities and we can see the result in our bid rounds. We fail to attract interest and the little interest we do attract is from second and third tier companies, which do not have the level of technical or financial resources follow deliver new production reserves. As the cost of finding gas increases with exploration taking place further offshore in deeper waters, the price at which gas can be sold to the domestic market increases. Without any relaxation on the government take from upstream producers, downstream plants are experiencing an increase in the cost of their most significant raw material. As a result, our petrochemical downstream industry is also getting less attractive. The only new plant completed for the downstream in the last 3 years was the AUM plant, even though there is always a long litany of prospects that are read at every budget speech. So what, you may ask, should be the Role of Government The role of government is best served as an enabler. The government served very useful catalytic functions in getting the Point Lisas Estate established and kick-starting the petrochemical industry. As much as possible, Government should stay away from running things. Governments are seldom the most efficient agent for manufacturing or delivering any product or service. They are just not structured to do that. Why should the government own a commercial bank, far less two Why must the government operate ports and airports Why does the government own 51 per cent of TSTT Why does the government maintain a monopoly on petroleum marketing Why is our government so big for just 1.3 million people While the Minister of Finance has held out his hand for collaboration with the Private Sector, I have one main problem with the 2012 Budget - it is too big. A $54.6 billion for Total Expenditure net of Capital Repayments and Sinking Fund Contributions represents an 11.4 per cent increase above the budgeted expenditure for last year! Governments, in general, are addicted to expenditure. Once expenditure levels are raised to a level, it is nearly impossible to reduce them - just look at the difficulties in Greece. We are being far too reliant on the Government to spark economic recovery through its spending. It's a dangerous precedent that get increasingly hard to reverse. So what's the Role of Business against this backdrop There is a wave consciousness sweeping across the globe demanding greater responsibility from corporations and businessmen - witness the spread of the \"Occupy Wall Street\" movement. We are being attacked and criticised for being greedy and acting selfishly. While don't have the protests in Trinidad (yet), we certainly have the commentary. I think the Trinidad business community needs to be a more proactive interlocutor for Minister Dookeran's outstretched hand. I think we need to be more vocal about what we see needs to be done and we need to start taking some bold actions and leading by example. I know this is difficult because we have seen the consequences of speaking up under the different regimes. We have also seen the advantages that accrue from staying in good favour. This however is NOT leadership. This is self-preserving cowardice. I know, I practise it myself. I don't want to jump out of my crease and find myself run -out or stumped and everybody else still batting. We need therefore to find a mechanism to join forces to lead a new initiative, not unlike the original Vision 2020 (which was started as a Masterplan to sustain economic growth, by businessmen and led by businesses, NGO, academics, labour leaders and community based organisations before it became politicised). In 2001, Trevor Boopsingh (RIP) recognised Tsumani of Revenue that the GORTT would receive from the Gas industry and set about getting business people to recognize the need to create a long-term plan to use the wealth that was going to be created to sustain economic growth. A great deal of analysis and consensus building went into that effort at the time. Well it's more than a decade later and times have changed. It's time for us to take the lead again. This time the rallying cry is not the Tsunami of Revenue corning; it's the cliff that lies ahead when the Revenue falls off of it. So I call upon you, this esteemed body of businessmen and women to deliberate on this challenge and hatch a new initiative to thrust business back into the business of leadership. We can bring together other stakeholders such as labour, Universities, NGOs community based organisations and even government to chart a course together through these times of unprecedented uncertainty. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/dookeran-japan-s-devastation-may-slow-up-global-economy/article_586ccfac-aeae-5859-8f4a-20e7dd7ba3d1.html", "TITLE": " Dookeran: Japan's devastation may slow up global economy ", "DATE": "Mar 19, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "THE progress being seen in the global economy may be temporarily stymied as Japan looks to cope with the devastation of the March 11 earthquake, Trinidad and Tobago Finance Minister Winston Dookeran has said. The 9.0 earthquake and subsequent tsunami that destroyed part of the Asian business giant's northeast coast could also lead to higher prices of commodities such as wheat, which may trickle down to the region. Goods coming out of Japan could also reflect the change. \"I am sensing a realignment of the currency between Japan and the United States,\" the acting Prime Minister said during a telephone interview on Saturday. \"It could happen. If it does, we could see an increase in prices of commodities coming out of Japan. Locally, that would mostly affect the auto industry directly. In terms of commodities, it would eventually indirectly affect is, if it were to happen.\" Dookeran said, however, there is a possibility that natural gas prices could go up as a result of the disaster, from which this country could benefit. \"Since nuclear power may now be in short supply, it is possible that we will see a short term rise in natural gas prices, which will be a positive for us,\" he said. Japan was up to late last week fighting to prevent a meltdown at its Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant, where the reactor has overheated several times since the disaster after a series of explosions destroyed its core cooling mechanisms. Up to late yesterday, Japanese authorities said engineers had managed to lay a cable to Reactor no.2 and were hopeful of reconnection to the power grid, which would restart the pumps that cool the core. A 20-kilometre Exclusion Zone is still in effect around the plant amidst fears of a radiation leaks. Dookeran said the Government has continued its partnership with the Red Cross Society, through which donations can be made to aid in the relief of those in Japan affected by the disaster. \"We are allowing donations to pass through them (Red Cross) and we encourage citizens to take part,\" Dookeran said. He added this country has not so far been able to reap any benefits from the increased oil prices of the last quarter but this could change if the increase is sustained throughout this fiscal quarter. \"It was as we had projected for the first quarter but we have not been able to benefit yet,\" Dookeran said. Local oil production has also not been as vibrant as was hoped, further inhibiting profit. \"We might lose out because of low production but that depends on whether the price is sustained for this quarter,\" Dookeran said. Dookeran will be a speaker at the fourth meeting of Finance Ministers of the Americas and the Caribbean, in Calgary, Canada. \"I will be making some presentations on the Trinidad and Tobago economy,\" Dookeran said of the March 25-26 meeting. Finance Ministers from 34 nations in the Western Hemisphere will be in attendance.
