{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/to-be-the-voice-of-business/article_a93ac999-89d4-58e0-8162-fee41aa00262.html", "TITLE": " To be the voice of business ", "DATE": "Mar 31, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "President of the Trinidad and Tobago Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Moonilal Lalchan President of the Trinidad and Tobago Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Moonilal Lalchan This week the Chamber is pleased to reproduce the first part of an edited version of the address delivered by the president of the Trinidad and Tobago Chamber of Industry and Commerce, Moonilal Lalchan, at its Annual Business Dinner on March 26 at the Hyatt Regency (Trinidad), Port of Spain. Celebrating 135 years of Service to our business community is no small feat. The Chamber has a rich history of community building and of being one of the leading change agents for our nation. Our Vision today To be the Voice of Business in the ongoing development towards a strong, sustainable national economy is, most likely, much the same as it was when we were established in 1879. This celebration in 2014 is more than a remembrance of the Chambers past accomplishments; it is also a celebration of a new vision to inspire leadership for our future. It is a purpose-driven celebration, delivering meaningful results while enhancing public awareness and perceptions of the Chambers role in advancing our business community and our wider nation to achieve a strong, sustainable economy. This is a mandate that requires strong, sustainable and responsible leadership at all levels of society whether in the context of government, business, education, community and civic organisations, and neighbourhoods that will strengthen and truly transform our nation. This is the second time I have been given the privilege to address our Annual Business Meeting as president of the T&T Chamber, and, one year ago I introduced myself as the leader who wanted to define my presidency at the Chamber by Building Bridges for the Common Good of business and the wider national community. I said we would create or reinforce those bridges between the public and private sector and civil society that would help take our country forward, based on openness, courage and innovation. I believe that over the past year, the Chamber has made great strides in achieving what we set out to do. In 2013, we gave more focus to undertaking much research, and were able to take some strong stands on a number of matters which are very important to you, our Members. Increased and efficient trade is a crucial area in the growth and development of business. Recognising this, our Chamber is the only business service organisation which offers a Unit dedicated to International Trade Negotiations services: our International Trade Negotiations Unit. This is our mechanism for facilitating national trade policy and facilitating growth of business in Trinidad and Tobago. In 2013, the ITNU continued to represent our members interests in ongoing negotiations with Guatemala, El Salvador and Canada. The ITNU has been working closely with the Ministry of Trade, Investment and Industry and other business organisations to solidify preferential access for local companies in the areas of goods, services and investment. Minister, we publicly thank you and Minister of Finance for your financial support of this initiative. While the negotiations with Guatemala concluded in 2013 and those with El Salvador are almost complete, negotiations with Canada now face a June 2014 deadline that is rapidly approaching. Due to the significant trading interest involved, I use this opportunity to strongly urge the Government to do all possible to ensure the maintenance of preferential access into the Canadian market. Also on the Trade Negotiations front, the Chamber continues to seek our members interests at numerous Continues on Page 17 meetings relating to the operation of the Caricom Single Market and Economy, the most significant of which is the meeting of the Council for Trade and Economic Development (Coted). Private sector input and interaction is vital for the enhanced operation of the Single Market, and so I encourage our Members to actively participate and use every opportunity to contribute to the CSME, via the Chamber. Lobbying and advocacy on behalf of the business community continue to be the mainstay of the Chambers efforts. We have hosted closed-door meetings with several Government Ministers and Leaders of State Agencies, including the Minister of Trade, Industry and Investment; the Minister of Finance and the Economy; the Minister of National Security; the Governor of the Central Bank; and the Comptroller of Customs and Excise, just to name a few. We have seen positive outcomes from these discussions the most recent being our meeting with the National Security Minister. In 2013, we continued our participation in the 2013-2014 National pre-Budget consultation process, canvassing the views our Members via e-surveys and at our Annual Pre-Budget Panel Discussion, which offered us the opportunity to coordinate the interests and concerns relevant to the business community for inclusion in the National Budget. Using this feedback, we submitted our recommendations to the Finance Ministry in May, and met with the Minister of Finance and the Economy to make our formal presentation, where we advocated for change or improvements in various areas of national importance. We have also called on the government to give a formal account of its specific commitments outlined in the Budget. In particular, our Tobago Division, currently chaired by Diane Hadad, has done tremendous work over the past few years lobbying to the Central Government and the Tobago House of Assembly on the issues that have affected the development of our sister isle, such as air and sea transport. The Division has worked steadfastly to assist in the implementation of the $250million Tourism Development Fund, the brainchild of the Division, which offers debt restructuring for tourism-related businesses and upgrade of room stock for small to medium sized hotels. Tobagos economy continues to decline and we advocate to the authorities to deal with Tobagos issues with some level of urgency. For several years, our Chamber has been insistent that the authorities must put the necessary mechanisms in place in the best interest of the development of our business community, and, by extension, the economy. Happily, our collaborative relationship with successive Governments has always allowed a willingness on their part to listen and take our views on board. However, we believe that it takes too much time for the authorities to translate willingness into action and full implementation. The successive changes in Government Ministers and Permanent Secretaries, and their portfolios, have all had a drastic impact on timely implementation. What causes further delays, is that each new leader in their respective Ministries wants to review and put their own stamp on already-agreed plans. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-need-to-develop-tobago-s-economy/article_f60ef61d-ef9c-58ab-90d5-e521aaaa38b7.html", "TITLE": " The need to develop Tobago's economy ", "DATE": "Aug 20, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Tourists arrive at the Port of Scarborough in Tobago Tourists arrive at the Port of Scarborough in Tobago In the lead-up to this year's national budget presentation, and following the recent cabinet reshuffle the Chamber wishes to highlight the need to develop the Tobago economy and discuss strategies that can possibly be employed by private stakeholders as well as the Central Government and the Tobago House of Assembly. It is important, however to examine Tobago in a historical context before proceeding. Tobago was initially incorporated as a ward of Trinidad during the colonial period in 1898. It was mainly a peasant economy with a few plantations producing for export - sugar and cocoa. Small scale farming supported the subsistence needs of the domestic population. Additionally, these farmers also worked for the plantation owners under the Metayage System (to produce crops and give half to the plantation owner, as payment for rental of land) and provided some cash crops for export, mainly to Trinidad as well as sugar and cocoa production for export by the plantation owners. By the mid 1970s to the early 1980s, as a result of mega-projects and investments in oil in Trinidad, the Central Government became the main driver of the economy through state corporations, the expansion of the public sector and social programmes. Whether Tobago benefited equitably from the increasing government revenues became a moot point which led to the passage of the Tobago House of Assembly (THA) Act which was established in 1980. In that year, it had become clear that Trinidad and Tobago could no longer depend on the energy and petrochemical sector for growth and foreign exchange. As the country became more sensitive of the need to diversify, greater focus was given to tourism as an engine of growth. Some thirty-odd years later, while several sectors for diversification have been identified, there has been no clear way forward for their development. This includes the tourism sector in Tobago, despite several strategic plans for the development of the sector which have been articulated by successive governments. Nevertheless, tourism in Tobago has still grown in strength over time, and has managed to become a well- established destination in the international tourism market. Apart from the public sector it remains the main employer and generator of foreign exchange. It is well-known that Tobago's tourism industry has seen sharp declines over the past five years. When the decline started after the events in the USA of September 11, 2001, steps were taken to revive the Industry and average occupancy levels moved from about 17 per cent to over 60 per cent, with the Tourism Rolling Plan introduced by the Government. Since 2006, the decline has been devastating to the Industry. It is important to note that this sector is estimated as representing 46 per cent of Tobago's GDP, 57 per cent of its employment and 96 per cent of its exports, and has thus had a tremendous adverse effect on the economic activity in Tobago. The decline of the tourism industry in Tobago represents a major loss in revenue for the Government and increasing tension on already strained resources. Furthermore, many of Tobago's large businesses are subsidiaries of Trinidad-based organizations and thus their negative bottom lines with increasing risk impacts on their Trinidad counterparts. Also, the free movement of the labour force between Trinidad and Tobago would imply that as the economic situation in Tobago worsens there would be increasing migration to Trinidad and emigration to other countries, which represents another major loss of resources and a loss of industry knowledge. The Chamber, through our Tobago Division, has been one of the stakeholders involved in drafting a Stimulus Plan for the Tobago Tourism industry. We support its implementation in order to rescue Tobago from this current crisis. However, the stimulus plan should be only one component of an overall development plan for Tobago's tourism sector. The question now becomes who should draft and implement a long-term development plan for Tobago and how does this fit into the wider nation The lack of success of the Tobago House of Assembly is not dissimilar to many parts of the world where centralized governments have failed to bring desired outcomes. This phenomenon has brought about the advent of Local Economic Development (LED) as an alternative approach to centralised government. According to the World Bank, 'the purpose of LED is to build the economic capacity of a local area to improve its economic future and the quality of life for all. It is a process by which public, business and nongovernmental sector work collectively to create better conditions'. LED, therefore basically refers to development strategies and while these work best in more developed areas there has been considerable success in areas of employment, development of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) and engaging underprivileged groups such as the informal sector, women and the uneducated in society. While traditional strategies adopt a sectoral approach, LED takes a territorial approach; traditional strategies generally take a top down approach and LED strategies are structured to take a bottom up approach; also, local institutions which plan and implement LED programmes are more adaptable and interact with local economic stakeholders. Further, there have been whispers of making Tobago a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) which essentially incorporates the principles of a geographically delimited area, singularly managed with separate Customs (duty-free benefits) and streamlined procedures and eligibility for benefits based on location within this zone. The Chamber sees such an initiative as one that would complement the stimulus plan for Tobago and which would form part of a wider plan for the island and a national development plan. It should be part of an overall growth strategy to enhance industry competitiveness and attract Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) to develop and diversify exports. The Chamber notes that such zones are most successful when they are privately owned, developed and operated, and when they are used as a supplement to country wide reform in regulatory, trade and investment. In terms of the incentive framework, encouraging zones to compete not on the basis of the provision of incentives but on that of facilitation, facilities and services has been identified as a best practice. Emphasis should also be placed on the importance of operating on a cost recovery basis that is market-oriented rather than a subsidized basis. With all this said the Chamber therefore encourages structured, inclusive dialogue to be held in Tobago with key stakeholders to come to agreement on its social and economic priorities to improve Tobago's future. The Chamber's Tobago Division has begun the process of identifying key areas that need immediate improvement in Tobago which was submitted to the Ministry of Finance and the Economy and can be found on the Chamber's website. To take the discussion further there needs to be greater collaboration with stakeholders and the recognition and discussion of their recommendations on the way forward. Thus, the Chamber stands able and willing to engage key stakeholders on this issue with the hope of finding a way forward for Tobago and the wider Trinidad and Tobago economy. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/dr-anthony-we-can-fix-our-broken-economies/article_d4fb5022-9fb6-56b4-a587-6a95e9871099.html", "TITLE": " Dr Anthony: We can fix our broken economies ", "DATE": "Jun 15, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "St Lucia prime minister Dr Kenny Anthony says Caribbean governments are not managing failed economies even though he admits these economies are struggling against high unemployment, weak economic performance and natural disasters.Anthony, who is also minister of finance, was speaking yesterday at the opening of the 3rd Caribbean Growth Forum at the Sandals Resort here, a 15-minute drive from the capital city Castries.The two-day Forum has been organised by the World Bank and other global financial institutions and aims to chart a way forward for Caribbean countries to divest and depend less on commodities, tourism and agriculture.More than 200 economists, bankers and regional government officials are gathered for the Forum which will address topics like harnessing growth in the region, private/public sector partnerships and competitiveness and jobs.Anthony described the economic development of the Caribbean as anemic, pointing to average growth of just 1.1 per cent from 2008 to 2013.But he remained optimistic, saying: We need to dispel the widespread view that we are all managing failed economies. I do not subscribe to that perspective. These economies may be broken but I believe we can pick up the pieces. I believe that our task is to conceptualise, shape and define and economic model that answers to the times and to our needs.He recalled that the launch of the Forum three years ago initiated dialogue for development amongst business groups and governments.Trinidad and Tobago, St Lucia, Jamaica and the Dominican Republic are some of the 12 countries that have committed to construct reforms in areas of investment climate, skills and productivity and connectivity, Anthony recalled.But problems remain.He said that foreign direct investment flows into the region declined by 4.7 per cent in the region.Declines in tourism, commodities prices and workers remittances have exacerbated the negative impact that the financial crisis had on economies, he said.The Forum continues on Wednesday morning. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/revitalising-the-economy/article_51f34e3f-e136-5158-932a-9a6ca6959c3d.html", "TITLE": " Revitalising the economy ", "DATE": "Jul 12, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "As the People's Partnership government plans for the future, one of its first challenges will be to restructure a still-struggling local economy. The odds are immediately stacked against Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar and Minister of Finance Winston Dookeran. By his own account, and in a June 11 report on the state of the economy, Dookeran points out \"in simple terms\" that the government's total cash balances have declined from $17.7 billion at the end of fiscal 2008 to a $5.43 billion as at June 2010. An even though crude oil prices have risen steadily to around US$75 a barrel , the price of natural gas- the country's main revenue earner- has been weak and has averaged around US$4 per mmbtu. The Dookeran report projects that this could fall even lower given the significant gas exports from Australia and Qatar and the large deposits of shale gas in the United States that are now being economically produced. The minister has also suggested that the large sums of excess liquidity in the commercial banking system be used in more innovative ways to encourage the development of small and medium-sized businesses. As Minister Dookeran and his team at the ministry prepare the 2010 national budget, there will have to be a reexamination of how Trinidad and Tobago governments have spent the country's earnings. There will also need to consistent attention given to revitalising the economy which is still feeling the effects of the global downturn and which is projected to register little or no growth this year. Government, business and labour will need to seek innovative ways to work together if we are to escape this crisis. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/burdens-that-hurt-business/article_a87ef393-d1de-51f4-9fa9-e04a009b4dad.html", "TITLE": " BURDENS THAT HURT BUSINESS ", "DATE": "Apr 6, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "We congratulate the countrys largest conglomerate, the ANSA McAL Group, on its sterling performance in 2012. In what was the fourth consecutive negative-growth year for the national economy, the Group enjoyed revenues of $5.9 billion, improving its profit before tax to $952 million. With an asset base of more than $11 billion, the conglomerate boasts of contributing upward of $1 billion in taxes and employing 6,000 persons. By any measure, here is a corporate citizen of which we can be proud. In its long history, it has expanded and grown through a clever combination of vision on the part of its founders and principals, innovation, acquisition and plain hard work. Interestingly, McAL has built its fortunes on only minor interventions in the lucrative energy sector, proving that even in and oil and gas economy it is possible to thrive outside the hydrocarbons orbit. As the corporations board and senior executives celebrated another successful year, Chief Operating Officer Gerry Brooks made some noteworthy statements. He observed that companies in the Group accounted for 15 per cent of the capitalised value of the Trinidad and Tobago Stock Exchange, and the Group was the biggest taxpayer outside of the energy sector. He also trumpeted the Groups corporate social interventions, particularly those in education, research and innovation. Brooks hinted that the Group was aiming at breaking into the elite global club of the Fortune 1000, which would be quite an achievement if or when that happens. What is remarkable about ANSA McALs consistent performanceit topped $1 billion in profit in 2010 and 2011is the conglomerates diverse spread. Its 60-plus subsidiaries encompass manufacturing, brewing, construction, automotive, trading, distribution, insurance, finance, real estate and media. While its main activities are located in Trinidad and Tobago, it conducts business in other Caribbean countries and in North America. The corporations success has not been without challenges, negatives that most private sector enterprises complain about, but which successive governments seem to be powerless to rectify. A major obstacle lies in the operations of the countrys principal ports at Port of Spain and Point Lisas. Companies like McAL, which rely heavily on import and export of goods, complain about inefficiencies at these ports that increase the cost of doing business. Brooks described the ports as a perennial hindrance, adding, When you are trying to export in the last quarter and the Port lacks efficiency, you will have afforded shelf space in a key market and you simply cannot export your goods. What happens is that space is taken by someone else. With containerised cargo being the prime means of international shipping trade, efficiency is measured in moves per hour, and our ports are said to lag behind international benchmarks. A related and costly anomaly is the fact that Port Point Lisas, the countrys second biggest port, is still deemed an outport by Customs. What this means is that for any work conducted by Customs personnel outside of regular working hours, overtime payment kicks in (rather than a shift system, as obtains at Port of Spain). This additional cost is borne by PLIPDECO (the port operators) and consignees. It is a grossly unfair burden that hurts business, and by extension, the economy. In an interview with the Business Express last week, Brooks alluded to a public and private sector partnership relative to the countrys ports, in which, presumably, ANSA McAL might have an interest. Shortly after it assumed office, the current Government listed a number of state-owned and state-controlled enterprises that it proposed to divest. The Point Lisas Port was one such company. In noting other challenges his company faced, Brooks pointed to crime being a disincentive to investment and a major cost by way of security measures. He also lamented the continuing complexities of doing business in the absence of a single electronic window, something a number of trade ministers have grappled with, thus far unsuccessfully. The success of conglomerates like ANSA McAL bodes well for the economic well-being of the country. Such corporate giants do not seek state subvention. They ask only that Government pave the road to doing business, removing obstacles to success. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ish-steve-and-jack-financing-elections-and-party/article_03f748a8-922c-50ab-a3dd-ad2c04ecb66d.html", "TITLE": " Ish, Steve and Jack: financing elections and party ", "DATE": "May 24, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "Standing with minister: Sport Minister Anil Roberts speaks with Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar during the People\u0092s Partnership fourth anniversary rally at Mid Centre Mall, Chaguanas on Saturday. The PM has described a video showing a man resembling a government minister wrapping what appears to be a marijuana cigarette as \u0093dirty tactics\u0094 by the opposition People\u0092s National Movement (PNM). \u0097Photo: DEXTER PHILIP Standing with minister: Sport Minister Anil Roberts speaks with Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar during the People\u0092s Partnership fourth anniversary rally at Mid Centre Mall, Chaguanas on Saturday. The PM has described a video showing a man resembling a government minister wrapping what appears to be a marijuana cigarette as \u0093dirty tactics\u0094 by the opposition People\u0092s National Movement (PNM). \u0097Photo: DEXTER PHILIP The e-mail crisis which we are currently experiencing can be traced directly to the issue of the funding of elections and political parties. Two of the individuals who are said to be at the centre of the controversy about Section 34, Ish Galbaransingh and Steve Ferguson, are major financiers of the United National Congress (UNC) and the People's Partnership. Another alleged financier, Jack Warner, was heard to say that he was in a way responsible for many of the UNC parliamentarians being in office. I assume he was saying that he invested in the UNC's election campaign and bought out its leader and its parliamentary team. One recalls the adage that election campaigns are occasions when political leaders earn money, whether their party wins, loses, or draws. After every election that is stained by scandal, proposals arise seeking to fix the rules relating to campaign financing, including demands for public funding of such campaigns. The demand is usually made by the losing parties As we reminded readers in last Sunday's Express, money has always been one of the prime sinews of politics. In many contexts, it is the most important political resource, the sine qua non which determines most though not all outcomes. As we argued, it is particularly the case in small societies. In the contemporary era, one needs money to purchase television time which in most societies is the most expensive commodity. Money is also needed to acquire the skills and services of advertising companies, polling consultants, vehicular equipment and all the other supports that are required to enhance and improve performances in contemporary elections. \"Treating\" has become big business. In most Caribbean island societies T-shirts are also an expensive electoral commodity. Wearing these shirts not only advertises political identity but also indicates how much support one's party has. Some people accumulate several just for the sake of doing so because they have not yet made up their minds. There has been much debate in the region and elsewhere as to how the funding problem might best be addressed. One strongly held point of view in the Caribbean is that political parties are private organisations even though they serve a very important public purpose. These political \"clubs\" should therefore be left to manage their own affairs, including the sourcing of funds to meet the cash needs of their operations. Why, many ask, should scarce taxpayers funds be used to support private organisations and their leaders who are in the main corrupt, power driven, and ineffective The other view, which is strongly held, is that political parties are much too important a public resource to be left unregulated. In some parts of the Americas, they are seen as the only remaining bulwark which prevents states from becoming narco-states in which power is bought and sold as a commodity. They need to be strengthened rather than be left to fend for themselves. Parties and elections have however become much too expensive to maintain. The main problem is that legitimate funding for them has become very scarce. In the post-Independence era, political elites were able to secure funding from members and well wishers, and from the new industries and from businesses which were being established. They were also supported by friendly governments and organisations which had an interest in making capitalism and democracy work sustainably or who saw them as milch cows. The economic structures of most Caribbean economies have however changed significantly and so too have investment patterns. Money is rapidly drying up or forthcoming mainly from Asian states such as Japan, or one or other of the two Chinas. Absent these sources, significant money is only available from big contractors, narco-traffickers and money launderers who are buying protection, or strategically placed elites who expect to be paid back. In many cases, offshore narco traffickers are rapidly replacing the small firms of yesterday. Dirty money significantly distorts our electoral processes, calling into question their transparency and legitimacy of our democratic systems. No Anglo Caribbean state has yet become a fully blown narco-state, but some leaders and those who want to become leaders are becoming dependent on drug money for the wherewithal to fund elections. Many states have become satellites of either Taiwan, Beijing and, more recently of Caracas. We have witnessed unseemly rivalries in countries such as Grenada, St Lucia, Antigua and St Kitts. Recall the role of Stanford in financing elections in Antigua. Complaints have also been forthcoming from Jamaica and Guyana that drugs are influencing, if not determining electoral or policy outcomes. In Trinidad and Tobago, the search for the dozen \"Mr Bigs\" said to exist continues. FIFA money is also reported to have been used to fix elections. The procurement regimes in all these states are seriously compromised. Money which is made available to fund elections or bribe elites invariably has to be paid back once the outcomes are determined. Section 34 is directly related to funding for elections. With the possible exception of the Bahamas and Trinidad and Tobago, Caribbean ano-states are not fiscally viable. Seven of them are among the most indebted states in the world. They are all drowning in debt and constantly have to approach bondholders and the IMF for accommodations to avoid the wolf at the door. Costs involved in servicing this debt represent a heavy burden on taxpayers and a disincentive to investment, foreign or local. Given the scarcity of money, and given the rising costs of elections, the question arises as to where does one get the wherewithal to service the routine needs of parties before and after elections. The answer, say some concerned groups, is not whether one resorts to public funding or not, but how much to allow them to spend and the form the distribution should take. What then is to be done Is public funding the answer All the states with the exception of Suriname share roughly similar views about public funding. They consider it an essentially un-British thing to do, even if Britain herself has adopted the arrangement, all be it in limited form. As we have argued however, the question is not whether there is public funding or not, but funding in what proportions and under what conditions. The answer to that question depends on what is already on the ground in terms of the type of electoral system that exists, the nature of the political and community values, the social stratification pattern which obtains and the amount of money that is available. Critically too is the viability, audit capability and regulatory integrity of the institutions that are available to the society. It is also pointless establishing public funding regimes if the elites steal the funds with impunity, spend it without due care and attention, find ways to avoid being both politically and legally accountable. The big question is whether it is practically possible. If the answer to the latter is in the negative, what do we do The one option that is not available to us is to leave things as they are to the modern buccaneers and picaroons. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/crime-the-economy-and-a-chance-for-real-change/article_c2611dab-b292-5102-9f3a-29abad4b07eb.html", "TITLE": " Crime, the economy and a chance for real change ", "DATE": "Aug 27, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "Since I started writing this column I think I have written about four or five articles on the issue of crime in our country. Each of those articles said much the same thing and gave the same general prescriptions. The key point made in those articles was that we would never deal with the crime situation until and unless we stopped seeing it through partisan political lenses. The war against crime, I argued, had to be a national effort if only because it would involve decisions and actions which would bring down any single government and therefore had to be the responsibility of the nation as a whole. In the period since I wrote the first such article the viciously partisan nature of our politics has grown more extreme and the prospects of building a national effort on crime, or on anything else, have become almost non-existent. Because of this view I did not see any reason for writing any more articles on crime every time there was a surge or spike in the murder rate or, as one official used to say, in the number of \u201chomo-cides\u201d. While this reality has not changed it is true that there has been a change in the national context which is significant enough to dramatically change the whole structure of our crime problem. I am referring here to the financial and economic problem being faced by the country as a result of the precipitous decline in international oil and gas prices. It is not difficult to see how the resultant decline in revenues could in turn have an impact on the crime problem. The fact is that in the absence of any effective crime-fighting plan and in the absence of capable and trusted crime-fighting agencies, the one strategy which has been used by successive governments to try to stem the rate of escalation in crime has been that of buying off with money transfers poorly disguised as make-work contracts \u201chotspots\u201d and those persons who it is perceived are likely to turn to a life of crime. This is what Sir David Simmons was referring to recently when he is reported as saying that \u201cthroughout the Caribbean, especially Trinidad and Jamaica, there was evidence which showed political parties embraced gang leaders and drug lords\u201d including politicians involving those criminals in state-funded projects. Now that the national coffers are considerably depleted and it is difficult to find the wherewithal to fund even legitimate development projects, it is evident that the policy of buying off criminals, established and/or potential, cannot continue on the same scale as it did before and will not work, if it ever did, to reduce the rate of crime escalation. We may already be seeing the impact of this reality. There is no question that violent criminal activity and murder in particular, has been on the increase over the course of the year. Nothing the Government has done or tried to do, from increasing the number of ministers in the Ministry of National Security, to reintroducing join military/police patrols, has had the slightest impact on that relentless increase. When therefore Gregory Aboud of the Downtown Owners and Merchants Association (DOMA) recently issued a call for Prime Minister Rowley to take charge of the Government's crime-fighting effort he was merely reflecting the desperate insecurity which many citizens feel. In fact Mr Aboud had called for more effective action on crime several times this year. And when the heads of two business associations could say in response to Dr Rowley's statement that the Government was doing its best that \u201cthat best was not good enough\u201d we begin to understand that the national mood is on the boil with regard to the crime issue. Unfortunately there is no relief in sight. If, as I have argued, the steady escalation in violent crime over this year is attributable to the declining financial and economic condition of the country, then we also have to realise that, notwithstanding the Minister of Finance's proclivity for living in a fool's paradise, that financial and economic situation is not going to get any better any time soon. Because of that the old practice of throwing money at the criminals is not going to work anymore. The country simply does not have the resources to continue with that strategy. But in the face of that reality there is a chance for the Government to abandon all the old, discredited and unworkable \u201ccrime plans\u201d we have essayed so many times before. The Leader of the Opposition has called for talks with Dr Rowley on the crime situation. It may just be the opening that the country needs to forge a real commitment to a national war against crime. If we fail in this again then we had better prepare ourselves for a long winter of discontent. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/central-bank-says-local-economy-continues-to-face-challenging-times/article_3cd1e25e-c870-5d72-a200-c77ced3256f3.html", "TITLE": " Central Bank says local economy continues to face challenging times ", "DATE": "Sep 17, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Sept 17, CMC \u2013 The Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago (CBTT) says the local economy continues to face challenging times with gross domestic product (GDP) contracting again in the first quarter of 2016. \u201cProvisional estimates from the Central Bank's Index of Real Quarterly GDP indicate that domestic economic activity declined by 5.2 per cent year-on-year due to declines in both the energy (9.1 per cent) and Non-energy sectors (2.8 per cent),\u201d the CBTT said in its latest Economic Bulletin. It said during the quarter ending July, production in the energy sector was affected by planned maintenance and upgrade related downtime at the major oil and gas producers and by lower output associated with maturing oil fields. In recent years, energy companies have placed increased focus on maintenance in order to meet higher safety standards. On the non-energy side, construction slowed in the context of slower execution of government-related projects. On the other hand, some uptick in activity was observed in the Finance sector,\u201d the CBTT said. It said that the contraction in the domestic economy is slowly impacting the labour market, as the unemployment rate trended upwards and the labour force participation rate declined. \u201cNevertheless, unemployment remains low and there are anecdotal reports of shortages in certain specialist skill areas as well as in some low-wage jobs in the distribution sector. \u201cThe labour market data for the fourth quarter of 2015 shows that the rate of unemployment rose to 3.5 per cent from 3.3 per cent in the corresponding year-earlier period, and of the estimated 22,300 persons unemployed, 57.0 per cent were males. Moreover the number of persons without jobs rose by 400 persons, but the effect on the unemployment rate was attenuated by a fall in the labour force.\u201d The CBTT said that retrenchment data filed at the Ministry of Labour and Small Enterprise Development point to continued softening of the labour market, as some 690 persons were retrenched in the first seven months of 2016. In the midst of a subdued domestic economy, headline inflation remained relatively contained, increasing to 3.4 per cent at the end of June 2016 from 2.4 per cent at the beginning of the year. The CBTT said other price indicators such as building material and producer prices indices also showed moderate increases. Since jumping sharply in February 2016 following the broadening of the Value Added Tax (VAT) base, food inflation has settled around nine per cent. The Central bank said that more broadly, some price increases have been linked to the depreciation of the domestic currency vis-\u00e0-vis the US dollar. It said the currency depreciated by roughly four per cent during the first six months of 2016. \u201cHowever, the full pass-through of these increases may not yet have occurred given the lag in transmission, while some businesses may have chosen to absorb rising costs in the interim. Police said the husband also went to the Chaguanas District Health Facility on the night of the incident. He allegedly told officers that his wife\u2019s lover chopped him with a cutlass on the arm and finger. He received three stitches to the finger and five stitches to the arm. Officers took the husband into custody after he was treated and discharged. The 19 year old son left the home after the incident. Police officers are looking for him. Police said the husband faces charges of assault occasioning bodily harm and assault by beating. Police said the lesbian lover could also be charged with assault occasioning bodily harm. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/business-in-education/article_869da7dd-254c-564c-b257-3aec6983daf1.html", "TITLE": " Business in education ", "DATE": "Jun 8, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "Educational systems at all levels are oriented by a scientifically minded business ethos and ideology. This is incorporated in a desire for, and practices of, technological solutions, managerial accountability, standardised assessment, and hyper-competition, which generate a consistent and reliable product efficiently and economically. In Education and the Cult of Efficiency (1962), Raymond E Callahan, presented an in-depth social-historical analysis of the personalities and sociocultural forces that influenced the actions of educational administrators in the first three decades of the 20th century, and through which business values, practices, and ideology had come to influence, if not dominate, the culture of educational administrators and schools. His analysis has a lot to offer us. Beginning in 1900, he argues that the visible successes of science, business, and industry in the 19th century gave them a position of ideological prestige and influence in the American psyche. This manifested in demands for more utilitarian, vocational or practical curricula within a changing national context of mass immigration, semi-literacy, cultural diversity, poverty, inflation, and suspicion of inefficient institutions, and created conditions for the emergence of efficiency experts who successfully advocated the application of business methods in education. From these ideas about economy and efficiency flowed rational and justifiable decisions to increase class size or the number of classes taught by a teacher, reduce salaries, narrow or eliminate inefficient curricula, and remove unproductive \"laggards\" from the schools. In the next two decades, these ideas would be elaborated in attempts to maximise the use of the school plant by shuffling students among rooms and so reduce the unit cost of education, and to develop systems of educational accounting that made simple acts stiflingly complicated and ushered in a bureaucratic hegemony that weakened the bonds of trust among teachers, administrators, and clerks. Finally, in the period following WWII, marketing and the science of propaganda's potential for shaping and directing public perception of business and creating \"good will\" would give rise to the public relations expert, who, like his efficiency expert counterpart of the earlier era, would bring fresh ideas and insight gleaned from business and industry into the educational realm and cement the standardisation of the operation of schools as a \"businesslike organisation.\" In trying to understand what he perceived as the unexpected capitulation of educational administrators to public criticism and the demand for business-like success and industrial efficiency, Callahan proposed what is now referred to as the vulnerability thesis. He argued that because of the way their school systems were financed and organised, those responsible for educational administration perennially found their security of tenure vulnerable to public criticism and subsequent dismissal. This corporeal fear of dismissal, he argued, often resulted in their abdicating their leadership responsibilities by yielding to the external demands for the application of business methods in education, with neither sufficient nor appropriate considerations as to whether such methods were suited to educational goals beyond efficiency, standardisation, and accountability. Similarly, he showed that teachers' instructional focus over the same period had shifted to student/class management, as they had come to adopt and implement some of the business strategies in their classrooms in order to please their administrators and their school boards, which had become dominated by businessmen. To reduce the vulnerability of educators, Callahan concluded that the organisation and financing of school systems would have to be changed, that the quality of the preparation of educational leaders in universities would have to be improved, and that both of these would have to occur more or less concurrently. These would help to counter the tragedy of modern education in which \"educational questions were subordinated to business considerations; administrators were produced who were not, in any true sense, educators; a scientific label was put on some very unscientific and dubious methods and practices and an anti-intellectual climate, already prevalent was strengthened\" which resulted in education being practiced in a \"businesslike, mechanical, organisational way.\" Very little has changed and the situation will continue to worsen until we review this ideology of \"business\" in education and make education/evocation a human(e) business. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/st-lucia-business-climate-improving/article_842b5234-1d57-5c4f-a670-4361af295977.html", "TITLE": " St Lucia business climate improving ", "DATE": "Dec 1, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Kenny Anthony Kenny Anthony TheWorld Banksays theKenny Anthonyadministration is reporting concrete advances in investment climate, connectivity and productivity in St Lucia. The Washington-based financial institution said the St Lucia government, the private sector, civil society, youth and academia have concluded that the country has made significant progress in meeting its commitments made at the start of the second accountability workshop of the Caribbean Growth Forum (CGF) held here. The World Bank said the St Lucian Growth Forum (GF) chapter is coordinated by the Department of Planning & National Development of the Ministry of Finance, and comprises representatives of the Government and private sector in collaboration with the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), Compete Caribbean and theCaribbean Development Bank(CDB). Over the last decade, St Lucia has grabbled with the challenge of reshaping its economy; growth has been slow and unemployment, particularly among the youth, high. The CGF has provided a forum to assist the government in implementing reforms needed for the country to become more competitive and innovative, The World Bank said. The Washington-based financial institution said the discussion underscored enhanced Internet, information communications technology (ICT)-related services and infrastructure, fiscal incentives for improved business climate, and boost in productivity. It said the St Lucia Ministry of the Public Service has established Wi Fi hot spots at key locations throughout the island, that a community access centre is now accessible and available to residents in the town of Soufriere, and construction of two new ICT access centres has commenced in Micoud North and Vieux-Fort South. St Lucia will be the recipient of a Government Island Network Project destined to create Wi Fi hotspots island-wide, the World Bank said, adding Wi Fi hot spots will also be created at libraries throughout the island to increase access to communities and schools. In assessing fiscal incentives for improved business climate, the bank said the St Lucia Department of Finance has commenced work to enhance the effectiveness of the current incentives regime and improve transparency of incentives. This project is expected to provide additional support to private sector development by re-focusing the incentives regime on specific development objectives, it said. Through the National Productivity Council, the World Bank noted that the St Lucia Government completed the first productivity assessment, an innovative approach that includes teaching youth and providing tools to increase on productivity in the workplace. It also said that the Economic Planning Unit within the St. Lucia Department of Planning & National Development is facilitating continued dialogue and implementation of CGF activities. The CGFs St Lucia Chapter was formally launched in January 2013 under the leadership of the Ministry of Finance, Economic Affairs, Planning and Social Security. The World Bank said the CGF provides a platform for private sector and civil society to give feedback on national and regional reforms and help track the implementation of actions needed to spur sustainable growth and opportunities for all in the Caribbean.
